A former Japanese school principal, 64-year-old Yuhei Takashima, has been arrested after telling police he paid for sex with more than 12,000 women and girls—some as young as 14—during repeated visits to the Philippines over 25 years, according to CNN Tokyo reporting. Japanese police arrested Takashima on charges of photographing obscene acts with a 13 or 14-year-old girl and producing pornography, seizing over 147,000 photos he had taken of his activities. Takashima, who worked as a school principal until 2011, told police he began this behavior in 1988 while working at a Japanese school in Manila and continued because it was inexpensive and helped relieve work pressure.

A Brazilian online football store claims to be selling next season's Chelsea kit on its website, featuring the incoming 'Yokohama' sponsor across the front but notably missing the Adidas emblem from the club's kit manufacturer. Most intriguingly, the alleged new kit can be purchased with 'Gareth Bale 9' printed on the back, despite the Real Madrid star having no confirmed connection to Chelsea. The website has published three different Chelsea kit designs for sale, though the authenticity of these kits remains questionable.

Clarence Taylor, 44, remains at large after police in Akron, Ohio ordered his arrest in connection with a bizarre faked kidnapping incident last fall. Police charged Taylor with falsification after determining he had staged his own abduction by duct taping his mouth and tying himself to a tree, then claiming to authorities that armed men had kidnapped him and stolen $2,500. Despite a warrant being issued last month, Taylor has not been apprehended and police have not revealed the motive behind the fake kidnapping scheme.

Rita Wilson and other actresses, including Mamie Gummer, star in a satirical PSA by the Make it Fair Project that uses tongue-in-cheek humor to highlight gender inequality in Hollywood and beyond. The video ironically laments that men "only" hold 70-95% of influential positions in film, government, and Fortune 500 companies, with the actresses singing "it's only fair that men should have it all" to draw attention to the stark disparities. Created by an all-female team, the PSA uses statistics showing male dominance across industries to advocate for greater gender equality in entertainment and other sectors.

A new study suggests that climate warming 1.4 million years ago enabled the earliest humans to venture into Western Europe for the first time. Researchers believe that the spread of hominins, our distant human ancestors, had previously been halted by colder and drier temperatures, but as conditions warmed above 13°C (55°F) and became more humid, they were able to migrate from Africa into Spain and eventually across Europe. The study, based on analysis of ancient tools found in southeast Spain, indicates that early human migration was strongly constrained by climate rather than cultural or geographical factors.

Former NFL running back Lawrence Phillips, who is serving more than 31 years in a Central California prison for choking his girlfriend in San Diego and driving into three teens in Los Angeles, is suspected of killing his 37-year-old cellmate who was found lifeless on Saturday morning. Phillips, 39, was once one of Nebraska's top college football players and played for the St. Louis Rams until being released in 1997 for insubordination, as well as the Miami Dolphins and San Francisco 49ers. Prison officials are investigating the death along with authorities, and a second similar incident involving different inmates occurred at the same prison.

Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final defeat to Aston Villa has put the club under intense scrutiny and guaranteed that this campaign will be judged a failure, falling far short of their burning ambition to be Champions League regulars with the potential to win the Premier League. The defeat highlights deeper issues at Anfield, including poor transfer decisions by the club's committee, tactical missteps by manager Brendan Rodgers, and questions about the squad's character and resolve. With major squad changes looming this summer and pressure mounting on both Rodgers and the transfer committee, Liverpool faces a crucial period to address their shortcomings and return to their expected standards.

Google launched an April Fools' Day prank a day early by combining Google Maps with Pac-Man, allowing users to play the classic game featuring characters like Blinky, Pinky, Inky, and Clyde on real-world streets including the Champs Elysees, Broadway, and the Embarcadero. Users can access the throwback fun by clicking the Pac-Man icon on Google Maps' desktop version, which transforms any map location into a playable Pac-Man course complete with power pellets. The creative prank has delighted Twitter users who have been sharing their gameplay experiences from various locations around the world.

Rangers boss Stuart McCall has been reassured that the club's removal from the London Stock Exchange will not affect his squad's promotion push, after the Ibrox faithful were rocked by Thursday's news that the club had been de-listed from the AIM market. The de-listing occurred because chairman-in-waiting Dave King failed to find a new nominated advisor, but McCall was told by club officials not to worry as funding and plans for the club will remain unchanged. McCall also expressed surprise at learning Rangers will owe Newcastle United £500,000 if they achieve promotion to the Premiership as part of their January loan deal for five Newcastle youngsters.

The US body that regulates Internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company called Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for allegedly using the new '.sucks' domain name to extract exorbitant fees from celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies seeking to protect their reputations. The company has been charging around $2,000-$2,499 annually for trademark holders and celebrities to secure their '.sucks' domains before releasing them to the public for just $10 per year in September. ICANN has referred the matter to U.S. and Canadian regulators, with industry groups calling it a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory" business practice.

Edinson Cavani's poor Champions League performance against Barcelona in PSG's 2-0 defeat may have ended any chance of him making a switch to Manchester United. The Uruguayan striker's lackluster display and underwhelming domestic form this season (11 goals in 32 games) would appear to have put to bed his prospects of filling Manchester United's looming striker void at Old Trafford. At 28 years old and with the painful experience of Radamel Falcao's failed loan spell still fresh, Louis van Gaal is unlikely to pursue another seemingly-fading South American striker.

The title race appears to be over, but the Premier League survival battle heats up with just seven points separating Sunderland (15th, 29 points) from Leicester (20th). Sunderland's recent derby win has done them the world of good, and they need to make the most of initial fixtures against teams like Crystal Palace, Stoke, and Everton who have little to play for, before facing difficult closing matches against Arsenal and Chelsea. The analysis predicts Sunderland will be safe with 34 points, while Leicester and Burnley are expected to be relegated despite having some winnable home games remaining.

Real Madrid star Karim Benzema showcased his talents beyond the football pitch by posting a video of himself demonstrating his rapping skills while cruising in his Bugatti Veyron, singing along to Tupac's "Check Out Time." As Real Madrid prepare for their La Liga clash against Granada at the Bernabeu on Sunday, Benzema shared the video while also expressing confidence that he can win the Ballon d'Or award in the future despite competition from teammates like Cristiano Ronaldo and Barcelona's Lionel Messi.

Pope Francis has been told by Vatican doctors that he must lose weight and cut his pasta intake to just two servings per week, according to reports from Italian news agency ANSA. The 78-year-old Catholic leader has been advised to take daily walks like his predecessor Pope Benedict XVI did, as medical staff are concerned about his sedentary lifestyle and significant weight gain since taking office two years ago. The extra weight is reportedly aggravating his sciatica condition, though the Pope, who jokingly calls himself "the undisciplined one," continues to eat pasta daily despite the medical warnings.

Google has released an update to its Android software that allows phone owners to unlock their devices using voice recognition through a feature called "trusted voice," which activates when users say "OK, Google." According to Android Police, multiple users have reported that this fully formed feature is now rolling out and can be accessed through smart lock settings in the Google app. However, Google warns that trusted voice is less secure than traditional unlock methods, as someone with a similar voice could potentially unlock the device.

The lawyer for Robert Bates, a 73-year-old Oklahoma reserve deputy who fatally shot a man he meant to subdue with a Taser, released documents on Saturday that he claims verify Bates' law enforcement training. The documents show that over a six-and-a-half-year period, Bates had one Taser training class, three firearms training classes, and qualified 10 times to carry a handgun, though questions remain about the authenticity and completeness of his training records. Bates is charged with second-degree manslaughter in the death of Eric Harris and claims he accidentally fired his handgun instead of his Taser during the April 2 arrest.

Peter Tait, headmaster of Sherborne Preparatory School in Dorset, has criticized parents for becoming "dervishes ready to battle with anyone and anything on behalf of their child" and urged them to keep their distance and trust schools and teachers instead. The leading head teacher claimed that modern parents' interference in their children's education, driven by being bombarded with parenting information, could actually hinder their natural development. His comments come amid growing concerns about "Tiger Parenting" and increasing reports of parents using social media to intimidate and abuse teachers.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the Iran nuclear deal framework announced last week, arguing that it gives Iran too much flexibility by allowing thousands of centrifuges to keep operating and not shutting down any nuclear facilities. Netanyahu advocated for a "third alternative" of maintaining pressure for a better deal rather than accepting "this bad deal or war," while Democrats like Senator Dianne Feinstein defended the framework as a workable opportunity to change regional dynamics. Republicans, including Senator Lindsey Graham, echoed Netanyahu's concerns about the deal giving Iran excessive flexibility and suggested that future presidents from either party could negotiate better terms.

Catalans Dragons winger Vincent Duport, a France international, has been ruled out for the rest of Super League XX after suffering a shoulder injury with a ruptured tendon during the Dragons' 33-22 defeat at Hull FC on March 20. Head coach Laurent Frayssinous described the news as a hugely disappointing blow for both the player and the whole team, though he expressed confidence that Duport will bounce back as he has from past injuries. The Dragons, who sit sixth in the table, will need the team's support as they face their next challenge with a trip to Wigan on Sunday.

Police discovered a body they believe to be Samantha Fleming, a young Indiana woman who was reported missing with her newborn daughter Serenity weeks ago, in a city 180 miles away from their home. Fleming was last seen in Anderson on April 5 when she left with a woman who claimed to be from Indiana's Department of Child Services, telling Fleming she needed to appear at a court hearing. The three-week-old infant was found unharmed at a home in Gary, Indiana, where police also discovered the body wrapped in plastic and doused with bleach, while the alleged kidnapper remains a person of interest located at a Texas hospital.

A geologist claims that a megalithic site in West Java, Indonesia, hidden beneath volcanic rubble, may contain the world's oldest pyramid built between 9,000-20,000 years ago - potentially four times older than Egypt's oldest pyramid which was built almost 5,000 years ago. The site at Gunung Padang, located 75 miles south of Jakarta at 2,903 feet above sea level among volcanoes and banana plantations, consists of chunks of volcanic rock arranged in terraces that may represent evidence of a powerful and advanced ancient civilization. However, the controversial findings are disputed by other experts who question whether such primitive peoples could have constructed such a complex structure thousands of years before previously known advanced civilizations.

Shocking footage has emerged showing the moment a man stabbed a bouncer outside a Melbourne nightclub just before the Easter long weekend. Police say the man had been ejected from the club late Thursday night at 10:13pm, but soon returned and attacked the security guard from behind, stabbing the 29-year-old bouncer in the back before fleeing the scene. In a separate incident early on Good Friday, another security guard was stabbed in the leg by a 24-year-old man who had been refused entry to a different Melbourne nightclub.

Carlisle United manager Keith Curle launched a scathing attack on his players following their limp 3-1 defeat away at Accrington Stanley, even suggesting that some players "don't deserve to be professionals." The Cumbrians are without a win in five games in League Two and sit dangerously close to the relegation zone with just five matches remaining this season. Curle criticized his squad's lack of character and spirit, and is considering staging an open forum where supporters can directly confront the players about their poor performances.

Victoria's Secret's latest campaign features Angels Candice Swanepoel, Elsa Hosk, and Jasmine Tookes showcasing that getting caught in the rain can be a glamorous affair when you're a supermodel, as they pose in see-through macs, glossy blow-dries, and the brand's new Dream Angels lingerie collection. The campaign promotes the romantic underwear range in blush pink and white tones, with customers receiving a free pink striped umbrella when purchasing two bras. Despite her confident appearance in campaigns, Candice Swanepoel admits she had to overcome shyness and create a persona to cope with the spotlight after being discovered at age 15.

Ukrainian wannabe singer Kristina Karo is suing Hollywood actress Mila Kunis for $5,000, claiming that Kunis stole her pet chicken named "Doggie" when they were children in Ukraine 25 years ago. Karo alleges she and Kunis, who moved to the U.S. from Ukraine in 1991 at age seven, were classmates and that the theft traumatized her and prevented her from pursuing the American dream. The lawsuit seeks damages for emotional distress and therapy costs, though there are discrepancies in their claimed locations in Ukraine, with Karo living over 100 miles away from where Kunis actually lived.

Richard Howarth, a 35-year-old father from Milton Keynes, claims he has developed an "allergy" to UKIP leader Nigel Farage that causes him to sweat, shake, and feel physically sick whenever he sees the politician on television. The medical recruitment consultant says he has to immediately change the channel when Farage appears or he becomes ill and anxious, with symptoms sometimes lasting for hours. A psychologist suggests Howarth's reactions are more likely the result of a phobia rather than an actual allergy, describing it as an irrational fear response to someone whose views are fundamentally opposed to his own.

A 17-year-old boy named Rahul Kumar was rescued by security after jumping into a lions' enclosure at the Kamla Nehru Zoological Park in Ahmedabad, western India, while shouting that he would kill the animals. Mr Kumar explained afterwards that he was drunk and thought he would "stand a good chance" against the predators. Fortunately, he fell into a moat before reaching the lions and was quickly rescued by zoo guards, then handed over to police for psychiatric evaluation.

This Easter weekend, popular chocolate treats require significant exercise to burn off their calories, with a single Crème Egg containing 177 calories that takes 19 minutes of skipping to work off and nearly seven teaspoons of sugar - more than half the World Health Organisation's recommended daily limit of 50g. Exercise coaches recommend various activities to offset Easter indulgences, such as 30 minutes of core circuit training to burn off a small Lindt bunny (275 calories), 1 hour on a rowing machine or other muscle-activating cardio equipment for a larger bunny (540 calories), and 50 minutes of Zumba step class to burn the whopping 444 calories in a packet of mini eggs. Nutritionists warn that excessive sugar consumption during Easter can lead to obesity, type 2 diabetes, and other health issues, particularly in children who may consume an average of eight chocolate eggs totaling 8,000 calories over the long weekend.

The Havasupai tribe, America's smallest Indian nation with just over 600 people, lives in the concealed village of Supai located eight miles from the nearest road in the heart of the Grand Canyon. The picturesque settlement, which was claimed by the tribe from National Park rangers in 1975 after court battles, is accessible only on foot via a rugged hike, by helicopter, or by mule. This hidden community relies primarily on tourism for income, with about 20,000 visitors annually making the journey to experience tribal life and witness the stunning Havasu Falls.

A new malaria vaccine known as RTS,S, which took 30 years to develop, has completed final testing stages and could potentially save millions of lives by preventing millions of malaria cases, scientists claim. Researchers say the vaccine reduced clinical malaria cases by 36% over four years in trials involving 15,500 children in sub-Saharan Africa, though its effectiveness waned over time. If approved by European regulators, RTS,S would become the world's first licensed malaria vaccine and could be recommended for use as early as October this year.

According to undercover police teams, Chilean pickpockets have become the most effective thieves operating in central London, with gangs of up to six members following wealthy shoppers in the West End to steal their cash and belongings. In one notable case, Metropolitan Police stopped two Chilean women wearing burkas who had been targeting rich Arab tourists in the Park Lane and Mayfair areas, discovering they were carrying €130,000, £20,000, and valuable jewelry. Plain-clothes officers working to reduce theft in the area report that these Chilean gangs are highly organized and intelligence-led, specifically targeting wealthy tourists rather than random victims.

After almost 90 years since the traditional electricity pylon was introduced to the UK, thousands of 165ft towers that have been spoiling scenes of beauty across the land with their cat's cradle of high-voltage cables may have their days numbered. National Grid has revealed a new, more elegant T-pylon design that is a third shorter than the old lattice pylons but can carry the same amount of power (400,000 volts) and can be erected in just one day rather than a week. While these new T-pylons won't replace the existing 88,000 pylons currently in use, they will be used for new transmission routes, particularly for clean energy purposes, starting with the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station in Somerset.

Arizona woman Holly Nicole Solomon, 31, pleaded guilty to aggravated assault after hitting her husband Daniel with their SUV in a Mesa parking lot following an argument about his failure to vote in the 2012 presidential election. Solomon admitted to running over her husband after saying her family would face hardship due to Barack Obama's reelection, chasing him in circles around the parking lot before accidentally hitting him when she meant to scare him. She will serve three and a half years in prison for the incident that left her husband hospitalized in critical condition with a shattered pelvis and torn artery.

Student Drew Hollinshead, 21, was given a £70 parking ticket after he pulled over into a disabled parking bay to help an elderly woman who had collapsed on the pavement and whom he thought might be dying. The good Samaritan stopped in the first available space and helped the pensioner for less than a minute, but a traffic warden issued the ticket despite being able to see what was happening. Hollinshead called the situation "ridiculous" and said he was being punished for trying to do something good, though the council stated that motorists can appeal tickets and mitigating circumstances are taken into account.

Workers in China are constructing a dangerous mountain walkway thousands of feet above ground in Pingjiang County, Hunan province, using only basic safety equipment like hard hats while carrying heavy wooden planks and concrete across rickety scaffolding. The precarious construction project is part of local officials' efforts to attract tourists to the mountainous region dominated by the Mufu Mountain range. Despite the extreme danger, the workers treat it as routine work, with one engineer stating it's "not as dangerous as people think" as long as safety ropes are worn.

Independent investigators have uncovered a catalogue of failings at two NHS hospitals - Royal Oldham and North Manchester General - after seven babies and three mothers died in the space of just eight months. The investigation found notable absence of clinical leadership in maternity wards, failure to adequately plan care, and below-standard risk management, with deaths occurring between December 2013 and July 2014. The hospitals are now developing action plans to strengthen clinical leadership, ensure adequate staffing, and improve safety protocols following these tragic deaths.

After months of turmoil and upheaval following the death of Michael Brown, the beleaguered city of Ferguson, Missouri has elected a new governing board that looks very different from the old one. Two African-American candidates won their wards in Tuesday's election with a higher-than-normal 30% turnout, making the six-member City Council 50% black for the first time, despite the city's 70% black population. The new council members, including the first black woman ever to serve on Ferguson's council, campaigned on platforms of change and reforming the city's policing practices.

Australian cricket captain Aaron Finch underwent surgery on Tuesday in Melbourne for a high-grade left hamstring injury sustained while playing for Mumbai Indians in the IPL. Scans confirmed the severity of the injury, leading to the surgical intervention, and Finch will be sidelined for up to three months during his rehabilitation period.

AP McCoy secured his second win at his final Aintree meeting by riding Don Cossack to victory in the Melling Chase, trained by Gordon Elliott who also trains Cause of Causes - a horse owned by McCoy's boss JP McManus that McCoy could have ridden instead of his chosen mount Shutthefrontdoor in Saturday's Grand National. The irony is that McCoy will be hoping Elliott doesn't win Saturday's Crabbie's Grand National with Cause of Causes, making this a bittersweet victory for the retiring jockey at his last Aintree meeting.

Vince Cable, the Business Secretary who prides himself on being the least popular Cabinet member among Tories in the Coalition government, says he is willing to work with the Conservatives for another five years and even wants to replace George Osborne as Chancellor. Despite acknowledging that Cameron and Osborne privately regard him as a "closet Labour politician" (he was indeed a Labour councillor in the 1970s), Cable describes them as "highly intelligent guys" with whom he can have "perfectly affable discussions." The 72-year-old politician seeks a "substantial role" in government and suggests he could help prevent the "nasty tail of Right-wing MPs wagging the Tory dog" if Cameron remains Prime Minister.

A survey has found that the average British worker will sit through 6,239 meetings during their career, with 60 percent finding most meetings "pretty pointless." The study of 2,000 workers revealed that 70 percent constantly zone out during meetings, with the average person switching off after just 20 minutes, and one in five admitting to falling asleep during work meetings. Many employees engage in distracting activities like doodling, daydreaming about dinner plans, or staring out windows, with one in five making mistakes due to not paying attention.

A maths problem designed for 14-year-olds in the Singapore and Asian Schools Math Olympiad baffled people around the world when it went viral on social media. The cryptic logic puzzle involved determining fictional character Cheryl's birthday from a list of 10 possible dates, using clues from conversations between two friends who were each told different pieces of information. Those able to reason through the logical steps were allowed to systematically eliminate dates and work towards the correct answer of July 16.

An Army major and his wife are on trial for engaging in a "regimen of abuse and neglect" against their three young foster children over several years, which left the toddlers with broken bones and numerous other health problems, according to a federal prosecutor. The couple, John and Carolyn Jackson, allegedly forced the children to drink hot sauce, withheld food and water as punishment, and physically abused them, while their three biological children showed no signs of abuse. This is their second trial after the first ended in a mistrial when a prosecutor inadvertently mentioned that one of the foster children had died.

Every day Sportsmail takes a look at European papers to see the biggest stories creating talking points on the continent. Starting in Spain, Marca and AS report that Real Madrid are set to be without key players Karim Benzema, Gareth Bale, and Luka Modric for their Champions League quarter-final second leg against Atletico Madrid, following injuries sustained during Saturday's match. Meanwhile, other European papers celebrate Barcelona coach Luis Enrique's impressive record and Juventus's march toward the Serie A title after their Saturday results.

The culprits behind the Hatton Garden raid may have carried out a similarly audacious burglary two years earlier in Berlin, it has emerged. In a case with strikingly similar traits to the £60m London heist, thieves targeted 294 security vaults at a Berlin bank in January 2013, stealing diamonds, gold and silver worth £8.3m. The gang behind the Berlin robbery have never been found, and both crimes involved heavy-duty drilling, disguises as construction workers, and raids conducted over weekends when buildings were empty.

A father from Baltimore captured his toddler daughter Viktoria's emotional reaction as she watched The Lion King for the first time, specifically the tear-jerking scene where Mufasa dies. The video shows the little girl's crestfallen response, with her bottom lip trembling and tears filling her eyes as she witnesses one of Disney's most haunting scenes. The heartwarming footage, posted to Facebook, has garnered over four million views and ends with the father offering his daughter a comforting hug.

A couple in their 40s became unusual victims of age discrimination when HSBC rejected their £250,000 mortgage application because the bank deemed the husband too old, as he would be over 65 when the 18-year deal finished. The banking industry watchdog found that HSBC "relied on untested assumptions, stereotypes or generalisations in respect of age," and ordered the bank to pay £500 compensation to the couple for distress and inconvenience. Although HSBC defended its decision by arguing it was entitled to apply a maximum age policy, this marked the first time the Financial Ombudsman Service has upheld a mortgage complaint specifically on the grounds of age discrimination.

A Texas veterinarian named Dr. Kristen Lindsey created a social media whirlwind after she allegedly shot a cat with an arrow and posted a photo on Facebook showing herself smiling while dangling the limp body, with a comment saying "My first bow kill, lol," according to CNN affiliate KBTX. The post triggered massive public outrage, leading to her firing from Washington County's Animal Clinic, and authorities are now investigating the incident as the cat may have been someone's pet rather than a feral animal. The case demonstrates how a social media post can quickly spiral into real-life consequences, with animal rights activists offering a reward and pushing for criminal charges against Lindsey.

Professor Ninian Peckitt, a 63-year-old facial surgeon, is facing a medical tribunal after being accused of repeatedly punching a patient in the face to correct fractures caused by an industrial accident at Ipswich Hospital in February 2012. While Peckitt claimed he had simply "digitally manipulated" the patient's face as part of standard hospital treatment, witnesses testified that he had actually been hitting the patient during what should have been a routine closed reduction procedure. The world-renowned surgeon, who now works in Dubai, emphatically denies the allegations and claims he has been victimized, but faces being struck off the medical register if found guilty.

Ben Powers, an actor who appeared on the long-running sitcom Good Times, died on April 6 at the age of 64 at his New Bedford, Massachusetts home. Powers played the character of Keith, Thelma's husband, during the show's sixth and final season from 1978-1979. His family has not revealed the cause of his death.

Darren Bent scored a stoppage-time equalizer to secure a 1-1 draw for Derby against Brentford at the iPro Stadium, after Alex Pritchard had put the visitors ahead with a brilliant 21st-minute strike. Brentford controlled much of the game and missed several second-half chances that came back to haunt them, including shots from Andre Gray and a Jonathan Douglas effort cleared off the line by Craig Forsyth. Derby made key substitutions including Simon Dawkins replacing Johnny Russell at halftime, but it was Bent's 92nd-minute goal from a Jeff Hendrick shot that rescued a point the Rams barely deserved, with referee Graham Scott overseeing the match.

A gang of armed robbers in the West Midlands used pink umbrellas to hide their identities during a two-month crime spree, stealing £145,000 from 13 shops including supermarkets, convenience stores, and electrical shops. The brolly-clad thieves also swiped £2,000 worth of cigarettes and cars valued at £30,000, while threatening staff with weapons including hammers, knives, and screwdrivers. The four gang members have now been jailed for more than 27 years combined after pleading guilty to conspiracy to rob.

Italian explorer Alex Bellini is seeking funding for his daring project called "Adrift," which involves spending a full year living inside a ball-shaped survival capsule on top of an iceberg in Greenland starting in November 2016. During this extreme isolation challenge, Bellini will be subjected to the full force of the iceberg as it melts, cracks, and potentially flips over, all while remaining trapped inside his 10-foot-wide spherical cabin with no means of escape. The goal of this cabin fever-inducing stunt is to raise awareness about global warming and climate change by documenting the final stages of an iceberg's life as it melts into the ocean.

A photograph circulating on social media site Snapchat is believed to show principal Andrew Barr watching pornography in his office at the elite private school Geelong College, located south-west of Melbourne. The picture was taken by a person who claims to be a student at the school and shows a man with his back to the camera viewing graphic images on his computer screen. Following an investigation that confirmed the breach of school standards, Mr Barr resigned from his position as principal.

Francis Pusok, who was released from jail on Sunday, spoke out in an NBC 4 interview on Monday to detail how he was beaten by police officers following a two-and-a-half hour chase on Thursday. Helicopter cameras captured footage of a swarm of cops kicking and punching Pusok more than 80 times after he fled his southern California home when they tried to arrest him for identity theft charges. Pusok revealed that he had been handcuffed for "99 percent" of the beating and that near the end of the incident, a deputy whispered "This isn't over" in his ear.

Hizb ut-Tahrir, an extremist Islamist group that advocates for a single Islamic state like ISIS, has reportedly joined forces with al-Qaeda in Syria and has been linked to the radicalization of several British men including ISIS executioner Mohammed 'Jihadi John' Emwazi, who came into contact with the group while studying at Westminster University. The group, which is banned in countries like Pakistan and Turkey but remains legal in the UK and Australia, has been recruiting at British universities, with recent cases including Waheed Ahmed, a Manchester University student whose father was arrested last month trying to cross into Syria with eight other Brits. Liberal Democrat candidate Maajid Nawaz, who spent 13 years in the group and was jailed in Egypt before renouncing his views in 2006 and setting up a counter-extremism think tank in England, has also come under scrutiny after being filmed at a strip club.

Marks & Spencer is stocking a new tropical fruit called the Bouea macrophylla, nicknamed the 'plango', which is a cross between a mango and a plum that will go on sale in the UK this weekend. The latest tropical fruit has a bright orange edible skin and offers the sweet taste of an Alphonso mango with a softer texture, allowing customers to eat it without the usual preparation hassle since the skin is edible. This follows the trend of other hybrid fruits like the Meyer lemon and Nectacotum that have become available in the UK market.

The University of Cape Town, South Africa's oldest university, voted to remove a statue of British colonialist Cecil Rhodes after a month of student protests, with black students saying the monument made them feel uncomfortable as a symbol of historical white oppression. White solidarity groups, including the Afrikaner group AfriForum, are now protesting the removal and demanding protection for their heritage, fearing their historical figures are being portrayed as criminals. The controversial statue of Rhodes, a 19th-century imperialist who critics say helped pave the way for apartheid, was successfully removed today and will likely be relocated to a museum.

Hannah Bluck, an 18-year-old teenage Welsh international footballer from Porthcawl, south Wales, has had her promising career halted for two years after being diagnosed with a rare condition called avascular necrosis that caused her shin bone to die from lack of oxygen. The teen football prodigy, who played for Wales youth teams at multiple levels, was warned by doctors that her leg could collapse into her ankle if she continues playing, effectively shattering her dreams of professional football. Despite the devastating setback, Hannah continues training and coaching while hoping to secure treatment from specialists that could potentially allow her to return to the pitch and pursue her dream of earning a senior Wales cap.

Paris Saint-Germain forward Edinson Cavani has rejected rumours of a breakdown in his relationship with team-mate Zlatan Ibrahimovic, insisting they respect each other professionally despite not being close friends. Cavani clarified that his only issue is being played out of his preferred striker position alongside Ibrahimovic, rather than in a front three formation. Earlier this season, coach Laurent Blanc had publicly stated that the pair must improve their on-field partnership amid speculation about their relationship.

England coach John Peacock has named his squad for next month's UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, with the Young Lions looking to defend their title after beating Holland on penalties in last year's final. The 18-man squad includes talented youngsters from top Premier League clubs, notably Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and several players from Everton and Leicester City. England will face Italy, Holland, and Ireland in Group D, with matches scheduled for May 7, May 10, and May 13 respectively.

Fireball Cinnamon Whisky has become a phenomenon in the American liquor market, growing from just under $2 million in retail sales in 2011 to $130 million in 2014, making it the sixth-most popular liquor brand in the U.S. The sweet, cinnamon-flavored Canadian whisky is especially popular among young drinkers and women due to its lower alcohol content (33%) and easy-drinking taste that masks the whiskey flavor. While the brand has cultivated a strong social media presence and party culture around the product, it now faces competition from copycat cinnamon-flavored spirits and questions about whether its rapid growth is sustainable.

A study led by the University of Montana found that eating fast food after a workout may be just as beneficial as dietary supplements during recovery periods between exercise sessions. Researchers tested 11 male athletes who were given either fast food meals or sports nutrition products after a 90-minute workout, and found that performance remained the same regardless of what food was eaten, with glycogen levels actually being slightly higher in the fast food group. The study suggests that it doesn't matter what type of food is consumed during recovery periods, as long as calories, carbohydrates, and protein content are similar.

Gael Monfils delivered a captivating performance that showcased his potential, defeating Roger Federer 6-4, 7-6 in the Monte Carlo Masters last-16. The Frenchman, who is sometimes fantastic, often frustrating, and always flamboyant, brought all the good parts of his game to bear in this thrilling encounter that makes one wonder just how good Monfils could have been and perhaps still can be. The match featured breathtaking athleticism and shotmaking from the 28-year-old, who will now face Grigor Dimitrov in what promises to be an explosive quarter-final.

Reverend Al Sharpton appeared in North Charleston, South Carolina on Sunday to deliver a sermon addressing the Walter Scott case, where a black driver was fatally shot by white police officer Michael Slager after fleeing a traffic stop. Sharpton preached at Charity Missionary Baptist Church with local officials and police in attendance, calling for national policing reform and praising the mayor for firing the officer. He was also expected to attend a vigil near the shooting scene later that day.

Stewart Brand, president of the Long Now Foundation and editor of the Whole Earth Catalogue, claims that the diversity of life on Earth is actually increasing despite dire warnings that the planet is facing a mass extinction. Brand argues that the rate of discovery of new species currently outstrips the loss of species to extinction, and believes that focusing on widespread extinctions may be harmful as it makes conservation problems seem overwhelming rather than local and solvable. He contends that current extinction rates are far lower than historical mass extinctions and points to successful conservation efforts and species recoveries as evidence that biodiversity trends are actually positive.

ISIS has established a comprehensive bureaucratic system in territories it controls, issuing official documents for everything from birth certificates to university curricula and fishing regulations, all stamped with Islamic State authority. The group operates hospitals, schools (with girls allowed to attend until age 15), and other public services while enforcing strict Islamic law interpretations, such as banning subjects like archaeology and democracy from universities and removing heads from foosball figurines to prevent idol worship. This governance strategy aims to demonstrate ISIS can provide stability and order while using extensive religious justification to present itself as a legitimate moral authority to both followers and local populations.

Archie Brown Jr. was shot and killed at the scene after his van struck and killed a 2-year-old who ran into the street in Milwaukee on Sunday evening. Milwaukee police say the driver, who had stayed at the scene waiting for officers, was shot dead possibly in revenge for the child's death. A 15-year-old teen was also shot and later died at the hospital, though his connection to the incident remains unclear.

Odds on the new royal baby being a girl have tumbled after a bookmaker revealed that 90 per cent of bets placed on the sex have been in favour of a female child, with a Scottish punter from Edinburgh placing a £2,000 wager on a princess. If the Duchess of Cambridge produces a boy instead, favorites include James (which has been used by two kings of Britain and is also the name of the Duchess' brother) and Arthur, while Alice and Victoria are the top choices for a girl's name. The betting frenzy comes as preparations begin at the Lindo Wing hospital, with the official due date being April 25th though punters favor earlier dates.

National sweethearts and television's golden girls Holly Willoughby and Davina McCall have joined forces for their first campaign together with Garnier Nutrisse, celebrating finding the perfect hair shade. The two presenters star in the campaign showing off their glossy locks, with Holly choosing shade 10.01 as her perfect multi-tonal blonde and Davina selecting 4.3 as her ideal brunette match. The campaign features the duo cuddling up and playfully posing with their hair pulled over their mouths to resemble mustaches.

A New York judge has ruled that Facebook is an acceptable way for Brooklyn woman Ellanora Arthur Baidoo to serve her husband with divorce papers, after she was unable to locate him through traditional means. Justice Matthew Cooper said social media sites like Facebook represent the "next frontier" for delivering legal summons, though Baidoo had to prove the Facebook account belonged to her husband and that he regularly uses it. This landmark decision means Facebook may need to add "Just got served divorce papers" to its list of relationship statuses, as reported by CNN.

The Turin Shroud, one of Christianity's most celebrated relics, went on public display in Turin's cathedral on Sunday for the first time in five years, with over one million people already booking slots to view it through June 24. The piece of linen, which devotees believe to be the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, bears the faded image of a crucified man and has been a source of wonder and debate for centuries. While the Church values its symbolic representation of Christ's suffering, scientists have dated the shroud to the 13th century, though researchers remain unable to explain exactly how the mysterious image was created.

A four-bedroom Mayfair mansion on central London's Farm Street has gone on the market for £25 million, built on the site that was originally used as a milking parlour over one hundred years ago. The luxury property features all the trappings of modern living including an indoor swimming pool, gym, lift, cinema room, and roof terrace, replacing what was once used to house cows for milking on one of London's busiest trading streets.

As the final episodes of Poldark approach, men across the nation who longed for respite from the hysteria over heartthrob Aidan Turner received bad news - at least for them - that any well-earned break won't last long. TV chiefs yesterday announced that the Cornwall-set drama will return for eight more episodes after helping BBC1 deliver its strongest start to a year for a decade. The second series will continue following Turner's broody Ross Poldark alongside Eleanor Tomlinson's Demelza, with the show averaging 8.1 million viewers per episode.

According to a CDC report, gastrointestinal illness has affected 100 people aboard the cruise ship Celebrity Infinity, with 95 of the ship's 2,117 passengers and 5 crew members suffering from vomiting, diarrhea, and other symptoms. The CDC has not yet determined the cause of the outbreak and will send two staffers to meet the ship in San Diego on Monday. This marks the third time the Celebrity Infinity has experienced a gastrointestinal illness outbreak, with previous incidents occurring in 2006 and 2013.

UltraHaptics is developing technology that uses ultrasound waves to create tactile sensations in mid-air, allowing users to feel three-dimensional shapes and surfaces without physically touching anything. The technology has significant potential when combined with virtual reality systems, enabling users to not only see but also touch virtual objects, and could revolutionize interfaces for cars, smartphones, and other devices by creating invisible buttons and controls. The company is currently working with 15-20 clients across various industries and aims to have their first commercial product on shelves within a year.

While most mothers dream of their children's birthdays, graduations, and weddings, 28-year-old Jodie Barden faces the heartbreaking task of arranging both her daughters' funerals, knowing that neither eight-year-old Ella nor one-year-old Chloe will make it to adulthood due to an incredibly rare illness called Cockayne Syndrome. This rare genetic disorder gives the girls a life expectancy of just 12 years and causes premature aging, developmental delays, and eventual loss of sight and hearing. Despite the devastating prognosis, Mrs. Barden and her family are focused on making the most of their time together while raising money for charity and creating special memories for the girls.

Damon Muller, an 11-year-old boy from Queensland, Australia, has been diagnosed with Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM), a rare life-threatening autoimmune disease that prevents him from going out in the sun without breaking into severe rashes and can cause his throat to swell so much it almost closes. Since his diagnosis in November, Damon has almost doubled in size due to swelling and bloating caused by the high-dose steroids and chemotherapy-type drugs required to treat his condition. The disease has transformed him from an active child who loved playing outside to someone who can barely move and must stay indoors most of the time, with his family now seeking support and information by fundraising to attend a medical conference in America.

Prince Harry's former girlfriend Chelsy Davy, 29, debuted a grown-up and glamorous style as she stepped out in a sophisticated summer outfit for the launch party of London restaurant The Ivy Chelsea Garden on Tuesday. The Zimbabwean socialite seemed in high spirits as she was seen laughing and joking with friend Irene Forte at the event, wearing a white chiffon top paired with navy trousers and tan accessories. Davy, who dated Prince Harry for six years until 2010, appeared to be embracing a more sophisticated approach to dressing as she approaches her thirties.

Hundreds of mourners gathered at a packed St. Peter's Church in Calais, France, for the funeral of nine-year-old Chloe, a schoolgirl who was raped and murdered by Polish migrant Zbigniew Huminsk after he snatched her from a playground while she was playing with a water pistol. The tragic killing sparked a national outpouring of grief in France after her body was discovered in woodland near a former migrant camp, with the perpetrator confessing to the crimes and facing charges that could result in life imprisonment.

Iron deficiency, particularly in women, is known to trigger hair loss possibly because it means less oxygen is delivered to hair follicles, but taking iron pills as treatment remains "a bit of a moot point," says Dr. Vicky Jolliffe, a consultant dermatologist at the Royal London Hospital. While some experts recommend iron supplements and report success in their practice when correcting low ferritin levels, other specialists remain skeptical about the strong evidence supporting most hair growth supplements. The article also discusses the importance of protein intake for hair health and notes that dietary changes typically take 2-6 months to show visible results in hair growth.

Suma, a 36-year-old orangutan at Melbourne Zoo who has suffered from arthritis since being diagnosed with the condition in 2013, underwent a thorough health examination on Thursday that was captured in photographs. Although arthritis is not unusual for middle-aged orangutans, doctors had to anesthetize Suma in order to check how her condition has progressed over the past two years. She was treated by orthopaedic surgeon Associate Professor Marino Pirpiris, who gave the orangutan a steroid injection to reduce her pain for months or potentially years.

New pictures have emerged showing One Direction star Louis Tomlinson's wild night of partying with a group of five girls at London's Soho Hotel on Wednesday night. The 23-year-old singer was seen barefoot, sitting on the edge of a sofa in his hotel room, where he appeared to be rolling a joint next to a box containing a suspicious substance. Snapchat images from the raucous gathering show the party continued until at least 5:48am on Thursday morning, with Tomlinson returning to the hotel after leaving a nightclub at 4am.

These century-old photographs from 1900-1911 during the Qing dynasty offer a rare glimpse of Beijing's most popular tourist attractions at a time when they barely had any foreign tourists and no one had ever heard of a selfie. The images represent some of the earliest holiday snaps of the Chinese capital, showing famous landmarks like the Temple of Heaven, Summer Palace, and Western Qing Tombs almost completely devoid of visitors. This stands in stark contrast to modern-day Beijing, which now attracts tens of millions of domestic and international tourists annually to these same sites, many of which are now UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

With many homes going under the hammer this weekend, Australian capital cities can expect record-breaking profits on their properties at auctions across the country. A Pain and Gain report released by CoreLogic revealed that only 8.6% of home resales recorded a loss, while profit-making resales totaled over $17 billion. Notable examples include a three-storey home built in South Perth with garage parking for three cars expected to sell for $3-4 million, and a Bondi property purchased for $1.46 million in 2005 now expected to fetch over $3 million.

West Bromwich Albion produced a typical Tony Pulis performance to beat his former club Crystal Palace 2-0, with the 57-year-old manager claiming he will never change his approach. Pulis's gritty, resilient playing style is well reflected in the touchline attire he insists on wearing at every game - his signature cap, tracksuit, and white trainers. The victory moved West Brom to 36 points, virtually guaranteeing their Premier League survival under Pulis's proven methods.

Crystal Palace co-chairman Steve Parish described a "great moment" as he basked in the glory of his club's 2-1 win over champions Manchester City at Selhurst Park. After the game, Parish posed for a picture with Palace manager Alan Pardew, England boss Roy Hodgson, and Bill Wyman, one of the original members of The Rolling Stones and a lifelong Palace fan who has supported the club for 68 years.

The Solar Impulse 2, an experimental solar-powered aircraft attempting to fly around the world without using any fuel, has been grounded for two-and-a-half weeks in Chongqing, China due to unfavorable weather conditions. The lightweight plane, weighing only 2,300 kilograms, requires near-perfect weather with cross winds under 4 knots to fly safely, forcing the 60-person team to wait as flights to their next destination of Nanjing have been repeatedly canceled. This 12-year project by pilots Bertrand Piccard and Andre Borschberg aims to prove the power of renewable energy, having already successfully flown through Oman, India, and Myanmar since departing Abu Dhabi in March.

Fresh from his Masters triumph, Jordan Spieth made a visit to the observation deck of the Empire State Building on Monday, still proudly sporting his green jacket as the Augusta record-equalling champion. Spieth broke several scoring records on his way to a four-stroke victory, including equalling the 18-under total set by Tiger Woods in 1997 and becoming the championship's second-youngest winner of all time. The 21-year-old's dominant performance has positioned him as golf's next big star and potential rival to current world No. 1 Rory McIlroy.

This article presents a tongue-in-cheek household audit created by etiquette expert William Hanson to determine how "posh" someone's home is, inspired by scrutiny of politicians' living quarters, particularly Prime Minister David Cameron's kitchen. The scoring system awards points for items like cafetieres, Agas, fabric sofas, and plain toilet paper, while penalizing middle-class preferences such as celebrity chef cookbooks, leather furniture, and quilted toilet roll. The quiz categorizes homes from "upper class" (14-18 points) down to "lower-middle" (1-4 points), poking fun at Britain's ongoing class obsessions and the middle classes' aspirational household choices.

Andy Murray tied the knot with Kim Sears on Saturday at Dunblane Cathedral, after announcing their engagement in November last year, with thousands of fans waiting outside to greet the couple. The tennis star married before a relatively small group of family members and close friends, with Reverend Colin Renwick leading the service at the 12th century cathedral around 4:00pm. The wedding generated significant excitement in Murray's hometown, with locals describing it as "the nearest we'll have in recent times to a royal wedding."

Alastair Cook has been working on a new, more open batting stance with former England batting coach Graham Gooch over the past few months, but the author believes he overdid it during the first Test against the West Indies. Comparing pictures from Cook's successful performance against India at Lord's in 2007 to his recent match, the analysis shows his front foot is now positioned too far open, making it difficult for him to reach off stump deliveries and forcing him to play shots with his hands away from his body. Despite this technical issue contributing to his dismissal for just 13 runs, the author remains optimistic about Cook's prospects, noting his mental strength and improved form in recent net sessions.

Dani Alves, the Brazilian right-back who has won the Champions League twice with Barcelona, is set to leave the Catalan club this summer after his agent confirmed he rejected their final three-year contract offer that required him to play in 60% of matches. The 31-year-old defender, who has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, has been linked with Manchester United, Manchester City, and Paris Saint-Germain, with his agent stating they currently have two three-year offers on the table.

Robin Ellis, who shot to fame in the Seventies as the original Ross Poldark and retained his slim physique much like current star Aidan Turner, was diagnosed by chance with type 2 diabetes in 1999 aged 58 despite being fit and healthy. The article highlights how type 2 diabetes rates have soared, with 3.1 million over-16s in the UK having diabetes in 2010 (90 per cent with type 2), expected to rise to 4.6 million by 2030, and the condition now being diagnosed at a much younger age. Robin successfully managed his diabetes for ten years through diet changes inspired by Michel Montignac's "Dine Out And Lose Weight" book, eliminating refined carbohydrates and developing healthy cooking habits.

Former New England Patriots tight end Aaron Hernandez, 25, was moved to the maximum-security Souza-Baranowski Correctional Center in Shirley, Massachusetts, a week after being convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison. Hernandez had been held at Cedar Junction prison in Walpole since his April 15 conviction for killing 27-year-old Odin Lloyd in 2013. The new facility is considered the state's most advanced prison, housing over 1,000 inmates with 366 surveillance cameras and strict security measures.

Jamie Robbins, a 35-year-old robber, handed himself into police a year after he stole £1,600 from a Select 'n' Save convenience store in Birmingham with an accomplice, saying he preferred life in jail because he could not cope outside of prison. Robbins was sentenced to four-and-a-half years after pleading guilty to robbery and possession of a bladed article at Birmingham Crown Court, though he had a change of heart when he discovered his girlfriend was pregnant the day before his court appearance.

Scientists claim that Injaz, the world's first cloned camel who was created from ovarian cells of a slaughtered camel in 2009, is now pregnant at six years old. The mother-to-be, whose name means "achievement" in Arabic, was born from a surrogate mother and has conceived naturally, according to Dr. Nisar Wani from the Reproductive Biotechnology Centre in Dubai. This pregnancy will prove that cloned camels are fertile and can reproduce like naturally born camels.

Former Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson, the most successful manager in British football history, revealed why he rates Cristiano Ronaldo above Lionel Messi while speaking with John Parrott over a frame of snooker as part of the BBC's World Championship coverage at the Crucible. Ferguson argued that Ronaldo could score for any team including lower-league sides like Millwall or QPR, while suggesting Messi is specifically suited to Barcelona's style of play. The 73-year-old also discussed his love of snooker with presenter Hazel Irvine and shared anecdotes about beating former player Paul Ince at the game.

The team bus carrying Fenerbahce players and coaching staff back from an away game was shot at on Saturday night near the city of Trabzon, with Trabzon governor Abdulcelil Oz confirming the driver was hit by a bullet. Among the 40 players and officials on board, none were injured except the bus driver who suffered a head injury, while the attack occurred hours after Fenerbahce's 5-1 victory over Caykur Rizespor. Separately, Caykur Rizespor midfielder Ludovic Obraniak, who is on loan from German side Werder Bremen, was taken to hospital with a suspected heart problem during the match but was given the all-clear after tests.

Nicola Sturgeon delivered a confident performance in stilettos and a new hairstyle during a televised political debate, clearly reveling in addressing a nationwide audience of Britons rather than her usual five million Scots. Her strong showing prompted exultation from supporters including Judy Murray, mother of tennis star Andy Murray who had been widely criticized for voicing support for Scottish independence. The article argues that while Sturgeon's poised performance impressed viewers across Britain, she poses a significant political threat as her SNP could potentially hold the balance of power in Westminster and push Scotland toward independence.

Ulster and Ireland prop Declan Fitzpatrick, 31, has been forced to retire from rugby on medical grounds after experiencing multiple concussive episodes in recent seasons, with his symptoms taking progressively longer to resolve. Following medical consultation with neurologists, it was recommended that retirement would be in Fitzpatrick's long-term health interests. The player, who won seven caps for Ireland and made 98 Ulster appearances, expressed gratitude for his career while acknowledging that his symptoms continue to improve under medical care.

Oregon-based defense contractor FLIR Systems Inc. agreed to pay $9.5 million to settle bribery charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday, involving expensive trips and gifts given to Middle Eastern government officials. The SEC said the thermal-imaging company earned more than $7 million in profits from sales influenced by the gifts, which included luxury watches for Saudi Arabia Ministry of Interior officials and elaborate travel arrangements including a 20-night international trip.

Showtime has released a short promotional video that takes viewers inside Floyd Mayweather Jnr's training camp as anticipation has ramped up for the $300 million mega fight against Manny Pacquiao on May 2 in Las Vegas. The video shows the undefeated American working in the gym as he prepares for what's being called the biggest fight the sport has ever witnessed, with Mayweather stating he has "never wanted to win a fight so bad in my life." The fighters will contest the WBA, WBO and WBC welterweight titles in this highly anticipated bout at the MGM Grand.

A heroic 58-year-old mother, Diwalinen Vankar, saved her 19-year-old daughter Kanta from the jaws of a 13-foot crocodile in a 10-minute battle, armed only with a wooden washing paddle. The attack occurred when they had gone to wash clothes at the bank of the Vishwamitri River, 40 kilometers from Vadodara in west India, where the crocodile grabbed Kanta's leg and dragged her into the water. After initially trying to pull her daughter free by hand, Vankar used the washing paddle to repeatedly strike the crocodile's head until it finally released her daughter, who survived with leg injuries.

Ahead of the 79th edition of the Masters, Sportsmail counts down the 20 greatest shots ever seen at Augusta National Golf Club, featuring numbers 20-11 in this installment. The list includes Mark O'Meara's winning 20-foot putt in 1998 when, at age 41, his chances of a major championship appeared to have gone despite his successful PGA Tour career. Other memorable shots featured include Billy Joe Patton's hole-in-one in 1954, Seve Ballesteros' chip-in for par in 1983, and Louis Oosthuizen's remarkable 253-yard albatross on the second hole in 2012.

The stars of Married at First Sight embark on their honeymoons in tonight's episode of the FYI series, but all three couples quickly find themselves experiencing serious trouble in paradise. Jaclyn Methuen, who nearly left husband Ryan Ranellone at the altar because she deemed him too unattractive, continues to put him in the "friend zone" and admits she wanted to be a runaway bride. The other two couples also face significant relationship issues during their romantic getaways, with arguments and emotional breakdowns threatening their new marriages.

CNN reports that the Taliban has published a biography of Mullah Mohammed Omar, the reclusive militant credited with founding the group in the early 1990s, with the primary message that he is still the leader of the Taliban's self-declared Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. The 11-page document appears aimed at dispelling persistent rumors about Omar's death, as he has not been seen or heard from publicly in years since the U.S.-led invasion in 2001. Afghan observers suggest the biography's release is intended to reassure followers of Omar's continued leadership at a time when ISIS has declared its own caliphate, challenging the Taliban's authority among jihadist groups.

The NFL draft begins on April 30 with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers holding the No. 1 overall pick, but the New England Patriots are still awaiting results from the "Deflategate" investigation that has already lasted more than three months since January. The NFL launched the investigation after 11 of 12 game balls provided by the Patriots for the AFC Championship game were found to be underinflated, with attorney Ted Wells leading the probe. While the Patriots won the game 45-7 and went on to the Super Bowl, the league continues its thorough investigation with no clear timeline for completion or announcement of findings.

Former model Bianca Gascoigne, the 28-year-old daughter of ex-England footballer Paul Gascoigne, was mugged by a gang of eight hooded attackers on bikes in central London's Marylebone area on Tuesday afternoon. The gang targeted her while she was talking on her mobile phone, stealing the device which reportedly contained private texts from her father, and attempted to snatch her bag before fleeing when she fought back. Bianca later took to Twitter to brand her attackers "lowlifes on bikes" and expressed devastation over the theft due to the personal nature of the messages stored on her phone.

Aberdeen striker Adam Rooney, who made the shortlist for PFA Scotland Player of the Year after scoring 27 goals this season, admits it would be a painful experience to watch Celtic celebrate their fourth successive Premiership title at Pittodrie on May 10 if the current eight-point gap remains intact. Despite Aberdeen sticking close to the champions all season, Rooney acknowledges this would be the most unwelcome ending imaginable after such an outstanding campaign. The striker is determined to prevent Celtic from celebrating on Aberdeen's home patch, though he recognizes Aberdeen have lost all three previous meetings with Celtic this season.

Former rap mogul Marion "Suge" Knight was ordered Thursday to stand trial for murder and other charges stemming from a deadly hit-and-run confrontation on the movie set of "Straight Outta Compton" earlier this year. In addition to that ruling, a Los Angeles judge lowered Knight's bail to $10 million from $25 million after holding a two-day preliminary hearing this week. Knight, who faces up to life in prison if convicted, is accused of running over two men with his vehicle during an argument, killing one of them.

Hillary Clinton's campaign staged a supposedly spontaneous coffee shop visit in LeClaire, Iowa on Tuesday morning, according to Austin Bird, one of the men pictured sitting at her table. Bird revealed that Clinton's Iowa political director Troy Price called him and two other Democratic Party insiders to a meeting, then drove them to the coffee shop to participate in what was portrayed as an impromptu "roundtable" discussion with ordinary Iowans. The revelation highlights concerns about Clinton's "astroturf" campaign tactics, where staged events are presented as genuine grassroots encounters with everyday voters.

An HIV self-testing kit is on sale for the first time in the UK, with the 99.7 per cent accurate BioSure HIV Self Test enabling people to test themselves at home and receive results in just 15 minutes using a finger-prick blood sample. An estimated 26,000 people in the UK have HIV but are unaware of it, and the kit's founder said knowing your HIV status is critical for health, adding that this represents a significant step towards normalizing HIV testing. Those who test positive are 11 times more likely to die in the first year if diagnosed late, making early detection crucial for managing what is now a treatable disease.

Among California's approximately 162,000 inmates, the most dangerous serve their time in Level IV maximum-security facilities where an estimated 97% are gang affiliated, but the California Department of Corrections offers Sensitive Needs Housing Units for those who choose to leave their gang life behind. These special units allow former gang members from rival groups like the Aryan Brotherhood, Black Guerilla Family, and Mexican Mafia to live together safely, engaging in activities like basketball and shared meals that would have been impossible in regular prison populations where racial violence and segregation dominate. While inmates outside these units remain subject to strict gang hierarchies and spend exercise time in caged "dog runs" to prevent violence, those in Sensitive Needs Housing experience dramatically reduced racial tensions and can even earn federal minimum wage through work programs.

Direct Assist, a personal injury claims company based in Bolton, Lancashire, has collapsed after being fined £80,000 by the privacy watchdog for plaguing households with nuisance calls. The company told one complainant they were likely to be called for three years until they made a claim, despite repeated requests to remove their details, and continued making calls even to elderly and deaf individuals registered with the Telephone Preference Service. The Information Commissioner's Office received 801 complaints about the company's deliberate disregard for cold calling rules before it went into liquidation.

Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho has the best clean sheets record in Premier League history with an astounding 101 clean sheets from 189 games (53.4%), edging out Rafa Benitez who achieved 114 clean sheets from 254 matches with Liverpool and Chelsea (44.9%). This stern defensive record has twice helped Mourinho win the league, with a third title likely by the end of the current season, while Roberto Mancini's 133 games at Manchester City produced a 44.4% clean sheet rate that narrowly beat Sir Alex Ferguson's 44.3% record.

Authorities in South Africa detained a 15-year-old girl from Cape Town at the city's airport after receiving information that she was attempting to leave the country to join ISIS, according to State Security Minister David Mahlobo. The girl had been using social media to interact with suspicious individuals and reading material that indicated her interest in joining the terrorist group. Officials are still conducting an investigation into how she was recruited, and the girl has been released into her family's care.

Ben Powers, who played Thelma's husband Keith Anderson on the final season of the CBS sitcom "Good Times" from 1978-1979, has died at age 64. Powers died April 6 in New Bedford, Mass., with no cause of death revealed, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The actor also had roles in the CBS detective drama "Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer" from 1984-1985 and appeared in films including "Things Are Tough All Over" (1982).

A 39-year-old father of six, known on Facebook by the nickname Karl Kay, was killed in a cold-blooded execution-style shooting while sitting in a car in his mother's driveway in Melbourne's southwest at about 2am on Sunday. The man was shot numerous times in what police believe was a targeted attack, leaving six children without a father. Police have cordoned off the Altona Meadows area and are investigating the incident, with no arrests made yet.

Alexander Kutner had a thrilling close encounter while crawling commando-style underneath a Land Rover to photograph a 4,500lb horned rhino that looked straight at him, along with three other rhinos in what's honestly called a "crash" of rhinos, at Sir Richard Branson's private Ulusaba Game Reserve in South Africa's Sabi Sands. The amateur photographer needed to stay calm to capture images of these potentially soon-to-be extinct animals during a graduation reward safari with his mother, Sky TV presenter Kay Burley. The luxury safari experience allowed them to document various African wildlife including lions, leopards, elephants, and the increasingly rare rhinos that face threats from poaching.

George Lucas is retaliating against neighbors who blocked his plans to build a film studio by proposing the largest affordable housing development in the area instead. The Star Wars director plans to fund and design a $200 million complex that would provide homes for 224 low-income families on his 1,039-acre estate in Marin County, California. This move represents a unique way that only someone of Lucas's stature in Hollywood could respond to neighborhood opposition.

A stunning series of photographs captures the dramatic moment a great grey owl with a five-foot wingspan swooped down on a tiny field mouse in Ontario, Canada. The bird stalked its rodent prey from snowy treetops before launching a precise attack, landing in the snow to snatch up the mouse with its sharp claws. Photographer Marc Latremouille documented this impressive display of the owl's hunting prowess during one of his photography workshops, offering viewers a remarkable bird's eye view of nature's predator-prey dynamics.

A new book by author Martin Fletcher claims that Stafford Heginbotham, the former chairman of Bradford City, was linked to eight other fires at his business premises before the devastating Valley Parade blaze on May 11, 1985, that killed 56 people. Fletcher, who lost four family members in the fire, spent 15 years researching the disaster and revealed that Heginbotham's businesses had experienced fires resulting in insurance payouts totaling around £27 million in today's terms over 18 years. While the original 1985 inquiry concluded the fire was caused by a discarded cigarette, West Yorkshire police have said they will review any fresh evidence surrounding the tragedy.

Manchester City defender Bacary Sagna insists he has no regrets about leaving Arsenal for City last summer, despite City currently sitting fourth in the Premier League while Arsenal are second. The France international, who has only played 16 times this season, departed Arsenal after winning the FA Cup but now faces ending the campaign trophyless as City's Premier League title defense has faltered. Sagna maintains he would make the same decision again, saying he's happy to have joined the then-champions despite the underwhelming season.

Nigel Farage took a dig at Prime Minister David Cameron today, suggesting that the Tory leader has been secretly using hair dye to reverse the greying process while in Downing Street. The Ukip leader said he was "jealous" of how Cameron has turned back the years with his appearance, making the comments after they clashed at last week's televised leaders debate. Cameron has previously been accused of using artificial help to maintain his youthful look, though Downing Street has denied claims that he dyes his hair.

It has been revealed that Dr. Victor Ramirez, the plastic surgeon who gave a Brazilian butt lift to young Australian tourist Evita Nicole Sarmonikas who died during the procedure in Mexico, had lost another patient just a year before her tragic death. The family of Ms. Sarmonikas flew to Mexico on a mission to bring her body home and arrived back in Sydney on Tuesday, after the clinic pressured them to have her remains cremated before an official autopsy could be conducted. Dr. Ramirez's certification had lapsed and he has been suspended, while the Mexican hospital has been closed down amid reports of poor hygiene and unsafe practices.

Help for Heroes has launched a fundraising drive to keep 96-year-old World War II veteran Robert Clark in his own home after Brent Council refused to continue paying for his live-in carer, despite Clark having spent his £50,000 life savings contributing to his care costs. The council wants to move Clark, who is one of Britain's oldest surviving prisoners of war and a survivor of Hitler's death march, from his home of 50 years into a care home because they claim it's cheaper. Help for Heroes has provided an emergency grant and started a JustGiving page that has raised over £2,700 of its £5,000 target, while more than 165,000 people have signed a petition supporting Clark's wish to remain at home.

FC Chernomorets Odessa, a Ukrainian Premier League team, is offering their players luxury houses near the sea valued at around £67,000 to cover unpaid salary debts due to severe financial struggles from lack of funding and sponsorship. The club's dire financial situation has forced them to sell their best players and slash remaining players' salaries from over £7,000 to £2,000 per month, with the threat of relegation and UEFA disqualification looming if they cannot settle their outstanding debts.

Kestutis Martuzevicius, a 52-year-old Lithuanian gangster accused of two murders and 22 crimes in his home country between 1993 and 1997, cost British taxpayers hundreds of thousands of pounds by repeatedly stalling deportation efforts for nearly five years, claiming he was too depressed to leave Britain. After being treated at Broadmoor psychiatric hospital and having his condition improve by June, the European Court of Human Rights finally rejected his "manifestly ill-founded" human rights claims and ruled he should be extradited to Lithuania.

Police are trying to find a gang of vigilante paedophile hunters accused of posing as children online and then beating up men who agree to meet them. The group has targeted at least two men, including a 19-year-old who was attacked in a church car park after believing he was meeting a 14-year-old girl, and Andrew O'Neill, 25, who was assaulted in Wigan town center and lost two front teeth after arranging to meet what he thought was an underage girl from the internet. The vigilantes have been filming the attacks and allegedly demanding money to keep the footage secret, prompting police to launch an investigation to find the group.

Real Madrid's Champions League starters, including Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale, and James Rodriguez, took a break on Wednesday while the rest of the squad returned to training a day after their 0-0 draw against rivals Atletico Madrid in the Champions League quarter-final first leg. The fringe players and substitutes from Tuesday's match, including Isco, Pepe, and Sami Khedira, participated in the training session at the Valdebebas complex. Real Madrid will face Malaga in La Liga on Saturday before the crucial second leg against Atletico next Wednesday, as they continue searching for their first win against their city rivals this season.

David Hibbitt, a 33-year-old bowel cancer patient who was told he had just 18 months to live, claims he has been cured by cannabis oil after being diagnosed with the disease in July 2012 and undergoing chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery to remove his large bowel. Despite doctors telling him the cancer was terminal, Hibbitt decided to try cannabis oil as a last resort, purchasing it from a local dealer for £50 a gram, and says he has been cancer-free since his last scan in January. However, Cancer Research UK emphasizes there is currently no good clinical evidence to prove that cannabis can safely and effectively treat cancer in patients, though they are supporting clinical trials to gather more data.

President Barack Obama visited the shrinking Florida Everglades today to deliver a speech at Everglades National Park commemorating Earth Day, holding up the deteriorating ecosystem as proof positive that climate change is real and threatening America's national treasures and surrounding towns that depend on tourism. In his speech, Obama declared that "climate change can no longer be denied" and "action can no longer be delayed," while throwing a spotlight on his administration's efforts to lead the United States in combatting the threat through carbon emission reduction. The president emphasized that climate change poses immediate dangers to communities through rising sea levels and saltwater intrusion, calling for political will to solve the problem in ways that can enhance rather than disrupt the economy.
