Real Madrid failed to activate their first option to buy Manchester United striker Javier Hernandez outright as the deadline passed on Thursday night, despite the 26-year-old's impressive form with five goals in his last six games including the decisive strike against Atletico Madrid in the Champions League quarter final. With the exclusivity period now expired, Real Madrid must compete with other suitors including Newcastle if they wish to sign Hernandez, whom United value at around £10million.

Bonnie Doll, a 28-year-old Swedish-Australian gamer from Brisbane, has turned her skill at playing Call of Duty into a lucrative career by live streaming on Twitch, earning enough to quit her hospitality job. With over 45,000 followers and nearly one million channel views, she makes money through subscriptions, donations, and ad revenue while playing from home. Despite facing online trolls and overzealous fans, Bonnie has built a successful gaming community and now works regular hours (8am-2pm, Monday-Friday) playing video games instead of working in a traditional office setting.

YouTube is set to offer an ad-free, subscription-based service for the first time, according to an email sent to YouTube Partners that revealed the plan. The service will offer consumers the choice to pay a monthly fee for an ad-free version of YouTube, with creators receiving 55% of subscription revenue. While the exact price and public launch date haven't been disclosed, the updated terms go into effect on June 15, 2015, and sources expect the service to launch sometime this year.

Marion 'Suge' Knight was transported to a hospital on Thursday after a Los Angeles judge ruled he will stand trial on murder and attempted-murder charges for a hit-and-run incident where he struck two men with his pickup truck, killing one and seriously injuring the other. The judge reduced Knight's bail from $25 million to $10 million during the hearing, which focused on testimony from victim Cle 'Bone' Sloan, who was hit outside a Compton burger stand but refused to cooperate as a witness against Knight. Knight's parents and girlfriend were seen outside the Los Angeles courthouse following the ruling, while sheriff's spokeswoman Nicole Nishida confirmed Knight's hospitalization but said no further details could be released.

Bailey Murrill, a patient from Denton, Texas, who had been inexplicably paralyzed for 11 days, surprised her favorite nurse by suddenly getting up from her wheelchair and walking towards her after regaining feeling and movement in her legs. The shocked nurse screamed with joy and then burst into tears as she hugged Bailey, with the emotional moment being captured on video by Bailey's mother while they were at the hospital. The heartwarming video has since been viewed over 1 million times, though the cause of Bailey's temporary paralysis remains unknown.

WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has agreed to be interviewed by Swedish prosecutors in London, according to his lawyer in Sweden who spoke to CNN. Assange has been staying at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London since June 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden, where prosecutors want to question him about 2010 allegations of rape and sexual molestation. Swedish prosecutors previously refused to come to Britain but changed their approach due to time constraints, as some alleged crimes will be subject to a statute of limitations in August 2015.

Big Brother winner Pete Bennett, who won £100,000 in 2006, revealed on the Jeremy Kyle show that he is now homeless and broke after developing a ketamine addiction following his reality TV fame. Despite releasing a successful autobiography and initially receiving prize money, Bennett struggled with drug dependency for years, losing seven friends to drug-related deaths, and found it difficult to secure work due to his Big Brother association. Although he has made progress overcoming his Tourette's Syndrome and is now clean from drugs, Bennett is currently sofa-surfing and trying to rebuild his life through acting while dealing with the aftermath of a failed marriage and years of personal struggles.

Despite Wednesday's shocking news that manager Jurgen Klopp will quit Borussia Dortmund at the end of the season, the players showed no signs of being affected as they returned to winning ways with a comfortable victory against Paderborn on Saturday. Goals from Henrikh Mkhitaryan, Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, and Shinji Kagawa secured the win, moving Dortmund to eighth in the table and keeping their European qualification hopes alive. The victory came just three days after Klopp's surprise announcement, with fans displaying signs thanking the manager for his seven years of achievements at the club.

Lee Min-bok, a North Korean defector living in Seoul, South Korea, is sending thousands of copies of "The Interview" movie across the border via balloons, despite not finding the film funny himself. The regime hates the Hollywood comedy because it portrays leader Kim Jong Un as a vulnerable, Katy Perry-loving man with daddy issues rather than the godlike figure promoted by North Korean propaganda. Lee conducts these balloon launches at night under police surveillance, believing the film helps show North Koreans that their leader is "afraid like us" and can be challenged, though he faces opposition from both North Korea and local South Korean residents concerned about potential retaliation.

An Israeli team of developers has created a "thermal protection" case called Optimal that addresses the problem of phones overheating from intensive use like sending dozens of messages or playing games for hours, which can drain battery and damage the device. The case uses built-in micro-fans to cool down overheated phones and resistance coils to warm up phones that get too cold, while constantly monitoring temperature through Bluetooth connectivity and sensors. The company Amited plans to launch an Indiegogo crowdfunding campaign in April to bring this thermal protection case to market for various smartphone brands.

At least 54 people died and 15 others are missing after a Russian fishing trawler carrying 132 people sank in Russia's Far East off the Kamchatka Peninsula. Of those on board, 78 were Russians while the remaining 54 were foreign nationals from Myanmar, Ukraine, Lithuania and Vanuatu, with the majority coming from Myanmar. The shipwreck occurred within 15 minutes, likely caused by collision with an obstacle that damaged the hull, and the trawler may have keeled over from hauling 80 tons of fish onto the deck.

This article reviews ten essential food and drink apps that every foodie should have, ranging from meal planning and recipe apps like Jamie Oliver's Recipes and Love Food Hate Waste, to dining discovery tools like Where Chefs Eat (which features over 3,000 chef recommendations) and OpenTable for restaurant bookings. The apps cover various aspects of food culture including street food finding, wine selection, cocktail deals, nutritional tracking, and even cheese appreciation, with prices ranging from free to £10.99.

As Jeremy Clarkson continues to battle to save his career after being sacked from Top Gear, his estranged wife Frances Clarkson has been enjoying a family break in the Caribbean. The 53-year-old showed off her tanned figure in a white bikini as she relaxed on a beach in Barbados during the Easter holiday. The couple, who married in 1993 and have three children together, are said to have been living apart for years amid reports of Clarkson's extramarital affairs.

Discount supermarket Aldi is facing criticism for failing to properly notify customers about a 0.5 percent credit card surcharge six months after promising the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) it would do so. ASIC took action against Aldi last year after an investigation revealed the company failed to disclose the surcharge on credit card and tap-and-go transactions in its stores. Despite promising to install clear signage and have cashiers inform customers, many Aldi stores still lack proper notification signs or display them in tiny print, leaving customers unaware of the additional fees.

Evidence has emerged of a wartime blunder that resulted in millions of pounds worth of Russian bullion, supposedly bound for America, being lost in the river Clyde during World War II. The gold and silver bars had been loaded in Murmansk onto the HMS Ulster Queen, a converted ferry, as payment to Americans for weapons shipped to Russia, but one case of precious metals slipped and fell overboard during a transfer operation at Greenock in November 1942. This incident has only come to light through a secret diary kept by ship engineer Leonard H. Thomas, whose daughter has now revealed the story for the first time in a new book.

Luis Suarez's wife Sofia revealed that the Barcelona star initially told her he didn't bite Italy defender Giorgio Chiellini during the World Cup in Brazil, before admitting the truth 10 days later. The Uruguayan received a four-month ban for the incident and was condemned by world football, but still completed a £75million move from Liverpool to Barcelona. Sofia explained that Suarez genuinely believed he hadn't done anything wrong at first, but eventually confessed after being confronted with television replays of the biting incident.

Ranulfo Perez, a 48-year-old man who dresses as the Cookie Monster to greet visitors in New York's Times Square, was arrested by police for allegedly groping the breasts of a 16-year-old girl outside a Toys R Us store. However, he was later released by the Manhattan District Attorney due to concerns that the teenager lost sight of her attacker and could not be certain it was Perez. This incident is part of a growing pattern of problems with costumed characters in Times Square, with nearly 20 such performers arrested last year for various offenses including sexual assault and disorderly conduct.

Marc Wabafiyebazu, 15, the son of Canadian Consul General Roxanne Dubé in Miami, has been arrested for felony murder after a gunfight erupted on Monday during what police say was an attempted robbery of drug dealers. His 17-year-old brother Jean was shot dead in the incident, which occurred when the two brothers reportedly tried to rob a group of men during a marijuana deal at a Miami home. The boys had allegedly planned to purchase two pounds of marijuana for $5,000 but instead intended to rob the dealers, leading to the deadly shootout.

Dr Omar Saadi Al-Atraqchi, a 42-year-old urology specialist working at Custom House Surgery in East London and other North London surgeries, faces being struck off the medical register after he was caught secretly filming men in gym showers. The doctor cut holes in Lynx shampoo bottles, emptied and dried them to hide his iPhone inside, then slid the bottles under shower cubicle partitions to record footage of naked men without their consent. Al-Atraqchi pleaded guilty to four counts of voyeurism and was fined, but now awaits a tribunal decision that could end his medical career permanently.

A former U.S. Army enlistee who posted on Facebook about "the adrenaline rush" of dying in jihad was arrested Friday and charged with trying to detonate a car bomb at Fort Riley military base in Kansas. John T. Booker Jr. of Topeka was taken into custody near Manhattan, Kansas, in a van containing what he believed was a bomb, though it was actually made with nonexplosive materials by FBI informants. A second man, Alexander E. Blair, was also charged with failing to report the felony after allegedly knowing about Booker's bomb plot but not contacting authorities.

Swedish scientists analyzed more than 10,000 families with children aged two to 14 and found that children who experience stressful events such as death or illness in the family, divorce, or separation could be three times more likely to develop type 1 diabetes. The researchers suggest that damaging childhood events may affect beta cells in the pancreas and raise insulin demands to cope with elevated stress hormone levels. While genetic predisposition remains the most important risk factor, this study indicates that serious life events during the first 14 years of life may contribute to the development of type 1 diabetes.

Jamar Nicholson, a 15-year-old African American teenager, was shot in the back by a Los Angeles police officer while he and his friends were hanging out in an alleyway before school, after one of his friends was holding a toy gun that officers mistook for real. Nicholson is now suing Los Angeles for $20 million, with his attorneys arguing that the LAPD "shot first and asked questions later" when the teenagers posed no actual threat. The incident has left both Nicholson and his friend traumatized, with Nicholson saying he now gets nervous around police officers.

Incredible footage from Russia's Domodedovo Airport shows a man sleeping in the fetal position on a baggage claim conveyor belt, possibly due to jetlag or alcohol, while other passengers waiting for their luggage appeared more concerned with collecting their bags than the fate of the dozing traveler. Despite the swinging motion making it a less-than comfortable snooze compared to the airport floor, the man seemed completely unaware as he circled around. This isn't the first instance of such behavior, as similar incidents have occurred at airports and train stations in China and Rome, where intoxicated passengers have also decided to rest on luggage conveyors.

For the first time in its 100-year history, Cadbury's is set to release a special "Dairy Milk Spectacular" bar containing seven different flavors in one bar, which may end the woes of people who dither between classic options like Dairy Milk, textured Fruit & Nut, and crunchy Daim when choosing chocolate. The limited-edition bar features seven rows with different fillings including Caramel, Fruit & Nut, Whole Nut, Oreo, Daim, and Turkish varieties. However, only 50 of these special bars were created for a competition to encourage British chocolate lovers to try new flavors.

The victory of 72-year-old former general Muhammadu Buhari in Nigeria's elections represents a moment of maturity in West African politics, marking the first peaceful transition of power in the country's history as he defeated incumbent President Goodluck Jonathan. Buhari, who was Nigeria's harsh military leader 30 years ago, won by running on an anti-corruption platform that resonated with Nigerians exhausted by years of misrule, corruption, and the government's failure to effectively combat Boko Haram terrorism. While Buhari could prove to be another disappointing reformer like many self-described reformers before him, his victory suggests that ordinary Nigerians have finally had enough of elite corruption that has plagued the oil-rich but poorly governed nation.

Dapper Laughs, the controversial persona previously "killed off" by disgraced comedian Daniel O'Reilly after he told a female audience member at one of his shows she was "gagging for a rape," has arrived in Australia via Melbourne. The British star documented his journey to Sydney by chatting up air hostesses and mocking airport cleaners along the way, showing he hasn't changed his sexist approach despite the backlash that led to his TV show being cancelled last year.

Nine British Muslims, including the son of a Labour councillor, were caught trying to cross into Syria and arrested in Turkey, prompting Labour's Simon Danczuk to declare they are no longer welcome in England and should find a new country to live in. Danczuk said it was "unacceptable" that people prepared to join ISIS should be free to return to civilian life in Britain without facing terror charges. The group, which included members of the same family ranging in age from 1 to 47, were apprehended while attempting to enter ISIS-controlled territory in Syria.

Avril Lavigne revealed in an interview with People Magazine that she has Lyme disease, a debilitating bacterial infection that explains her months-long absence from the public eye. The 30-year-old singer said she has no idea where she got the tick bite that infected her, and was bedridden for five months with severe symptoms including weakness, fatigue, and difficulty breathing. She is now about 80 percent recovered and wants to raise awareness about the disease.

An Egyptian court sentenced 71 people to life in prison for their role in the August 2013 burning of the Virgin Mary Church in the Giza province village of Kafr Hakim, according to state news reports. The Christian church was torched and looted by a mob that chanted against Coptic Christians, and was one of at least 42 churches targeted during that period. Most of those sentenced were tried in absentia, with the attacks blamed on supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood following the ouster of President Mohamed Morsy.

Australian police have charged a second individual in connection with an ISIS-inspired terror plot, following the arrest of five young men on Saturday in Melbourne during a major counterterrorism operation. The suspects allegedly planned to attack police officers during Anzac Day commemorations on April 25, which marks the centennial of the Gallipoli Campaign. Two of the arrested teens have been released pending further investigation, while 18-year-old Sevdet Besim was previously charged and denied bail.

Tim Sherwood's famous gilet has put the Aston Villa boss's sense of fashion in the spotlight, making it easy to imagine his thoughts on teammate Carles N'Zogbia's outrageous flamboyant shirt and trouser combo worn to Tuesday's training session. Goalkeeper Shay Given certainly wasn't a fan of N'Zogbia's flowery attire, taking to Twitter to ridicule the Frenchman's outfit as "the worst ever." The fashion incident comes as Villa sits six points clear of relegation and prepares for their FA Cup semi-final against Liverpool.

British photographer Laura Stevens, 38, who lives in Paris, created a therapeutic photography project called "Another November" after experiencing a painful breakup, asking friends and other women to pose based on how she was feeling to capture the stages of grief following the breakdown of a relationship. The photo series shows women in various emotional states - from sitting in foetal positions to dining alone - as Stevens used this photographic narrative to process her adjustment to being a single woman and reconstruct her identity as an individual. Each staged portrait, titled with the model's first name, depicts intimate moments of isolation and melancholy in domestic spaces, helping both Stevens and the participating women process their own experiences of loss and heartbreak.

Andy Murray, the former Wimbledon champion known for his nerves of steel on the tennis court, appeared nervous during his wedding rehearsal at Dunblane Cathedral on Friday. The British No 1 is marrying his long-term girlfriend Kim Sears in his hometown of Dunblane on Saturday, with the pair running through the wedding service alongside friends and family at the cathedral.

Lawyers for Pennsylvania police Officer Lisa Mearkle, who was charged with criminal homicide last month, are trying to prevent video footage of her fatally shooting unarmed motorist David Kassick in the back from being shown in courtroom. The footage, recorded by her stun gun on February 2, shows Mearkle shooting two bullets into Kassick's back as he lay face down on the ground, but has not been made public. Mearkle claims she shot Kassick in self-defense because she believed he was reaching for a weapon, while prosecutors say the video clearly shows Kassick was unarmed and lying face down when shot.

Mick Schumacher, the 16-year-old son of seven-time Formula 1 world champion Michael Schumacher, returned to the racing circuit just weeks after being involved in a 100mph crash and once again went off the track during his Formula 4 pre-season test debut in Germany. At one point during the test session at the Oschersleben circuit, he was pictured accidentally driving through gravel by the side of the track. The teenager is following in his legendary father's footsteps as he progresses through junior racing categories, having previously finished second in world, European and German kart championships last season.

Following Bruce Jenner's revealing Diane Sawyer 20/20 special, TV viewers will be able to follow his transition journey in a forthcoming eight-episode docu-series on E! starting July 27. However, his sons Burt, Brandon, and Brody Jenner, along with stepdaughter Kim Kardashian, are allegedly concerned about how much their father will reveal on reality TV and are warning him to slow down and finish his transition process more privately. Despite their concerns, Bruce remains committed to the docu-series, believing it will educate people and create empathy for the transgender community.

The RSPCA is considering abandoning its controversial policy of pursuing fox hunting prosecutions after dropping the case against William Bryer of the Cattistock Hunt in Dorset last month, leaving the animal charity with no remaining legal actions under the Hunting Act. The organization is now reviewing its prosecution policy following criticism over spending £22.5 million on animal welfare prosecutions last year, with experts recommending they leave such cases to the Crown Prosecution Service and focus instead on their core mission of animal rescue and rehabilitation.

Former police officer Darren Stanton, who has become the UK's top human lie detector and body language expert with a background in psychology, appeared on ITV's This Morning to demonstrate his skills in detecting deception. Contrary to the old adage that liars can't look you in the eye, Stanton explains that liars often stare and maintain eye contact for longer than normal (more than 3-5 seconds). He successfully caught both presenters Amanda Holden and Philip Schofield lying during the show by spotting micro-expressions like mouth flicks and raised eyebrows, and shared other telltale signs of deception including twitching, clutching objects as barriers, and giving brief hesitant answers.

CNN explores how Easter stands as a unique and significant point on the Christian calendar that has resisted the commercialization and culture wars surrounding other religious holidays, largely because it genuinely reflects how religious impulses and patterns operate in ways that affect our lives. The article explains that Easter's three-day progression (the Triduum) - from Good Friday's suffering through Holy Saturday's transition to Easter Sunday's resurrection - represents a spiritual pattern that people experience repeatedly throughout life, moving from darkness and suffering into hope and transformation. This makes Easter particularly meaningful for those in the Christian tradition and offers insights into the human condition that transcend mere calendar observance.

Facebook has opened up its Messenger platform to third-party developers for the first time, allowing apps like Camoji to integrate seamlessly with the messaging service. Camoji is one of the first apps to take advantage of this integration, enabling users to create 2-second animated GIFs with Instagram-style filters directly within Messenger conversations. This represents Facebook's strategy to transform Messenger into an independent platform that competes with email and other messaging services, with over 600 million users and 40 different apps becoming available.

Labour leader Ed Miliband warned that everyone who comes to Britain should know how to speak English, admitting that his party had been "too timid" in the past about making clear that communities must use a shared language to live together. Miliband acknowledged that Labour made mistakes on immigration, particularly regarding EU expansion in 2004, and promised new measures including a crackdown on illegal exploitation of migrant workers and requirements for healthcare professionals to speak sufficient English. However, the Tories criticized Miliband's plans, saying they contained nothing to actually reduce the number of people moving to Britain after net migration reached 298,000 in a year.

Four terrified puppies strapped in a cage to the roof of a van were rescued after concerned drivers called 911 and police stopped the vehicle on a freeway in Akron, Ohio. Wendell Steiner, his wife, and their four children were traveling on a 300-mile journey from Nova, Ohio to Pennsylvania when police pulled them over. The incident drew comparisons to Mitt Romney, who came under fire during his 2012 presidential campaign for once driving with his dog strapped to the roof of his car.

Louis Smith has been named to represent Great Britain at the European Championships for the first time since winning pommel horse silver and team bronze at the London 2012 Olympics, after which he pursued a media career. Smith earned his selection by winning gold on the pommel horse at the recent British Championships, and will join a six-man squad that includes Olympic teammates like Daniel Purvis for the championships taking place in Montpellier from April 15-19.

A New York taxi driver, Mohammed Dahbi, has been ordered to pay $10,000 in damages to a lesbian couple after he discriminated against them by telling them to stop kissing in the back of his cab and to "keep that behavior for the bedroom." The couple, actress Kassie Thornton and TV executive Christy Spitzer, were also subjected to verbal abuse when they refused to pay the fare, with Dahbi calling them derogatory names. A judge ruled in favor of the couple and also required Dahbi to attend anti-discrimination training and pay an additional $5,000 civil penalty to the city.

Jonas Gutierrez, the Argentinian midfielder who has twice beaten testicular cancer, was dropped from Newcastle's squad for their 3-1 home defeat to Tottenham on Sunday following a fallout with head coach John Carver. The 31-year-old was not even named among the substitutes after a heated exchange with Carver over being dropped from the starting lineup, and he is now set to be released at the end of the season after seven years at the club. Gutierrez has previously criticized Newcastle's treatment of him during his cancer battle, saying the club told him to find a new team when he returned from his first bout with the illness in 2013.

Islamic State militants infiltrated the Yarmouk Palestinian refugee camp in Damascus today, marking the terrorist group's deepest foray into the Syrian capital and seat of President Bashar Assad's power. ISIS entered the Yarmouk camp in coordination with the Al Qaeda-affiliated Nusra Front, while Jordan simultaneously closed its only functioning border crossing with Syria following heavy clashes between rebels and government forces on the Syrian side. If ISIS gains full control of Yarmouk, the jihadis could potentially use the camp as a base to threaten the heart of Damascus and challenge Assad's government directly.

Amanda Peake Glover, a South Carolina mother of four and devoted youth ministry teacher and choir singer, died over the weekend after collapsing moments after completing the Palmetto Half Marathon. The fitness center co-owner had completed the Myrtle Beach marathon with her brother just one month prior to her sudden death. She is survived by her husband Benjamin and four children, leaving behind mourning friends and family shocked by the unexpected tragedy.

Ed Balls, Labour's shadow chancellor, was left briefly stumped by a basic maths question today after giving a speech in Leeds. When asked what seven times six equals, Balls looked down at his feet and laughed nervously before eventually answering correctly with "42" following a ten-second pause. The incident occurred after Balls had previously revealed that he relies on his mother-in-law, a maths teacher, for help with mathematics.

Alastair Cook and Jonathan Trott have become the sixth English pair to score more than 100 runs together on 10 occasions, with England captain Cook being part of three such partnerships including those with Andrew Strauss (14 occasions) and Kevin Pietersen (13 occasions). Their recent opening-stand century was England's first in Test cricket for more than two years, since Cook and Nick Compton's 231 against New Zealand in Dunedin in March 2013. The article also covers various other cricket news including injury concerns and bowling performances during the current series.

Manhattan-based Skin Laundry offers a popular 10-minute Light and Laser facial treatment that promises to tighten skin and improve complexion, but clients must sign an extensive 8-page waiver that includes releasing personal information to funeral directors and coroners in case of death. Despite the ominous legal language and potential risks like burns, scarring, and infection, the $100 treatment has attracted devoted customers who visit multiple times per week, allowing the company to expand to six locations across New York, California, and Arizona. While no deaths have been reported from the procedure, some medical professionals question its effectiveness given the frequency of treatments required.

Tickets for Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao's weigh-in on May 1 sold out within minutes on Friday evening after going on sale at 3pm from MGM property box offices in Las Vegas. Fight fans queued around the block to get their hands on one of the 10,000 available tickets for the face-off, which takes place 24 hours before their mega-fight. This came after tickets for the main bout itself had sold out within a minute on Thursday night, with some tickets immediately appearing on secondary markets for over $128,000.

Victoria's Secret Angel Alessandra Ambrosio is recovering at UCLA Hospital in Westwood, Los Angeles following a medical procedure for constant headaches, Daily Mail Online can reveal. The Brazilian supermodel, who was seen partying at the Coachella festival in California on Sunday, underwent the scheduled procedure on Tuesday after booking the appointment two weeks prior. Despite appearing healthy at the festival, Ambrosio had been suffering from persistent headaches and is currently being monitored at the Ronald Reagan Medical Center.

The Oxford University Women's Boat Race team was rescued by the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) on Wednesday after their boat was overcome by choppy waters on the Thames during training for the Boat Race scheduled for Saturday, April 11. Crew members from the Chiswick RNLI station came to the assistance of the Oxford crew and their cox when strong winds against the tide created successive waves that flooded their boat beyond what the bilge pump could manage. The rowers were safely returned to Putney and their sunken eight was recovered and returned to Oxford's base.

Paris Saint-Germain playmaker Lucas Moura has revealed he is "obsessed" with the way fellow South American Lionel Messi plays football, despite the traditional rivalry between Brazilians and Argentines. Moura singled out Messi for special praise ahead of PSG's Champions League encounter against Barcelona, calling the Argentine "the best player in the world" and his longtime idol. The Brazilian acknowledged it will be very difficult to play against Messi when the teams meet on Wednesday night.

Over the past couple of weeks, Zayn Malik's departure from One Direction has made headlines, but so has his personal life, as his relationship with Little Mix singer Perrie Edwards has come under scrutiny following accusations that the 22-year-old has been cheating on his fiancée. Swedish model Martina Olsson recently claimed she slept with Zayn while he was holidaying in Thailand, marking the fourth time he has been accused of infidelity since he and Perrie began dating in 2011. The article draws comparisons between their troubled relationship and that of Cheryl Fernandez-Versini and Ashley Cole, noting that despite the ongoing cheating allegations, Perrie continues to stand by Zayn as they reportedly embarked on a "make or break" holiday together.

The article discusses how major businesses, including the NCAA, Apple, and even Marriott International (run by a dedicated Mormon who follows his church's teachings but separates personal faith from business), swiftly opposed Indiana and Arkansas's "religious freedom" bills through boycott threats. Companies like Marriott launched campaigns in June to make transgender travelers and LGBT customers "feel comfortable," recognizing the $200 billion LGBT travel market, while citing the Bible's injunction of unconditional love as justification for going beyond personal beliefs. The piece argues that with millennials increasingly supporting same-sex marriage and America becoming more diverse, businesses and politicians can no longer afford to tolerate discrimination as it threatens their bottom line.

TOWIE star and footballer Jake Hall scored a vital goal with his first touch after coming off the bench during Boston United's Conference North match on Monday, impressing his on-screen girlfriend Chloe Lewis who was watching from the stands. The goal helped keep the Pilgrims on course for the Conference North play-offs in their 2-0 win over Tamworth, with fellow TOWIE co-star James 'Arg' Argent also celebrating in the crowd.

Lt. Colonel John Schwemmer is on his sixth tour in Iraq, where he and other U.S. military personnel are training often ill-equipped Iraqi government troops in the familiar task of fighting ISIS. Dozens of Western foreigners, including Americans, have volunteered to join the fight against ISIS, supplementing official U.S. military training efforts by working with Kurdish forces and militias in Iraq and Syria. While some organizations provide training and logistical support to Kurdish Peshmerga forces, U.S. officials maintain confidence that their current military mission of working through Middle Eastern partners is sufficient to degrade and defeat ISIS.

Seventy years ago this week, the British Army liberated the Nazi concentration camp Bergen-Belsen, where an unlikely love story blossomed between 24-year-old British Sergeant Norman Turgel and 20-year-old emaciated Polish inmate Gena against all odds. Their romance was made possible by the kindness of British commanding officer Major Leonard Berney, who helped the couple stay in touch during the post-liberation chaos, leading to their marriage and a nearly 50-year union with three children before Norman's death in 1995.

CNN reports from near the epicenter of Nepal's devastating earthquake, describing a challenging six-hour journey through winding mountain roads to reach Gorkha district, where international medical teams are treating injured patients in much less than ideal circumstances. The district hospital is overwhelmed with about 20 patients lying on mattresses in a makeshift tarpaulin shelter, serving the 200,000 people living in the northern part of the district who suffered injuries including broken arms and legs. Despite the difficult conditions, Swiss and German humanitarian teams have arrived to provide medical support and search and rescue operations for the resilient Nepalese people in need of extensive help.

Indonesia's President Joko Widodo, who took office in October, has maintained a tough stance against drug smugglers and rejected clemency appeals for two Australian members of the "Bali Nine" drug smuggling group. Andrew Chan, 31, and Myuran Sukumaran, 33, face execution by firing squad after an Indonesian court on Monday rejected their last-ditch clemency effort for their roles as alleged ringleaders in a failed heroin smuggling plot a decade ago. The Australian government continues to pursue diplomatic options to prevent the executions, citing the extensive rehabilitation both men have undergone during their time on death row.

A new paper suggests that early Earth may have collided with a Mercury-like body about 4.5 billion years ago, a dramatic event that could explain why our planet has a hot core that gives it its magnetic field. The collision could also explain why certain rare-earth elements in Earth's mantle do not seem to originate from the planet's other building blocks like meteorites. This Mercury-sized impactor would have been rich in sulfur and poor in oxygen, providing the radioactive materials needed to generate heat for Earth's core dynamo.

Red Bull has struggled since their dominant Formula One era ended in 2013, falling further behind Mercedes and other rivals in the 2015 season, with Daniel Ricciardo managing only a sixth place finish in Australia and tenth in Malaysia. The popular 25-year-old Australian driver participated in a martial arts training session at Guyi Garden as a PR event before the Chinese Grand Prix, learning stances and poses that may help him cope with what could be a frustrating season. While the new skills won't provide the speed needed to challenge Mercedes drivers Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg at the front of the grid, the discipline from the training may help Ricciardo deal with Red Bull's current performance struggles.

A four-propeller, 50-centimeter wide drone carrying small traces of radioactive material (likely caesium, which is harmless to the human body) landed on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister's office in what is suspected to be a protest against the government's nuclear energy plans. The drone was spotted by a member of the Prime Minister's staff, prompting police and the bomb squad to be called to investigate the incident. This apparent act of protest reflects growing public opposition to Japan's nuclear policies following the 2011 Fukushima disaster, as the government pushes to restart nuclear reactors despite safety concerns.

ISIS is a brutal terrorist organization that combines radical Islamic ideology with a power-driven structure largely composed of former Saddam Hussein military officers, thriving primarily due to Sunni-Shiite sectarian conflicts in Iraq and Syria. While the group presents itself as a global threat, its main focus appears to be establishing a caliphate in the Middle East rather than directly attacking the West, though it has revolutionized terrorism through sophisticated online messaging and recruitment tactics. The organization's greatest long-term weakness may be the growing disenchantment of people living under its brutal rule, similar to other radical groups like the Taliban.

Following a leaders' debate, numerous memes were created featuring the political figures, including David Cameron and Nick Clegg superimposed on the Gogglebox sofa and Ed Miliband in a Kate Winslet Titanic pose with the caption "debate me like one of your French girls." Other popular memes showed Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon with a sceptical expression and Mr Miliband superimposed over London rapper Plan B issuing a "come at me bruv" call, referencing his direct challenge to the Prime Minister for a one-on-one debate.

A handful of Manchester City fans were ejected from Old Trafford during Sunday's 4-2 derby defeat for allegedly mocking the Munich Air Disaster by making airplane wing gestures to taunt home supporters. Stewards quickly removed the group who were making the sick reference to the 1958 tragedy that killed 23 people, including members of Manchester United's team. Despite this incident, police praised the overwhelming majority of fans for their good behavior, with only eight arrests made at the match.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has confessed that his academy players are not ready to step into the first-team squad, hinting that City may look to cherry-pick the best youngsters from their top-flight rivals. This comes in the same week that Liverpool's Raheem Sterling spoke about his unwillingness to agree a new contract at Anfield, with Pellegrini's comments suggesting City may invest heavily in other teams' homegrown talent like Sterling to meet Premier League homegrown player quota requirements. City currently faces a shortage of suitable homegrown players, with only defender Dedryck Boyata emerging from their academy as a viable first-team option.

A heavily pregnant Jehovah's Witness named Jenny-Lee, 28, died along with her baby after she refused a blood transfusion required for cancer treatment, having been diagnosed with leukaemia seven months into her pregnancy. Her family defended the woman, saying she put her baby's life above her own and believed the chemotherapy would harm her unborn child. However, doctors stated that 83% of pregnant leukaemia sufferers go into remission with treatment, and her refusal of blood transfusion made it impossible to perform a caesarean section or provide life-saving care.

Mohammad Liaqat, a Muslim father, stormed into Mount Carmel Catholic School and launched a racist tirade against white teachers after two 14-year-old Muslim pupils were banned from lessons for refusing to shave their beards in accordance with the school's uniform policy. During his rampage, Liaqat racially abused staff in front of shocked parents and assaulted headteacher Xavier Bowers, then continued his abusive behavior at a nearby primary school where he also assaulted that headmaster. Liaqat was found guilty of assault and racially aggravated behavior charges and will be sentenced in June, despite the original beard issue having already been resolved by the school.

Chinese police arrested more than 133,000 people and seized 43.3 tons of illegal narcotics during a six-month nationwide anti-drug campaign, the country's Ministry of Public Security announced. Authorities also handled 115,000 drug-related crimes such as robbery and 606,000 cases of drug use during the campaign, with figures nearly double compared to the same period the previous year. The crackdown came at a cost, with nine police officers killed and 657 wounded during the operations.

A new species of glass frog named Hyalinobatrachium dianae has been discovered in the mountains of eastern Costa Rica, featuring translucent skin on its underside that allows its internal organs to be visible while maintaining a brilliant lime green color on its back like other glass frogs. The creature is distinguished by its distinctive metallic whistle-like call, black and white eyes resembling Kermit the Frog, and long thin feet, making it unique among the 149 known glass frog species in Central and South America.

The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have moved back to Kensington Palace to prepare for the imminent birth of their second child, who is due on Saturday, MailOnline revealed today. The couple returned to their London base on Sunday night after spending the weekend at Kate's family home in Berkshire, positioning themselves just minutes away from the private Lindo Wing at St Mary's Hospital where Kate plans to give birth. Prince William has completed his air ambulance pilot training earlier than expected, allowing him to take approximately six weeks off work to be with his wife for the birth and subsequent paternity leave.

Maurice Thibaux, a 67-year-old angry neighbor, stormed onto the catwalk at Sydney's Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week while fashion designer Kym Ellery was taking her bow, causing quite a stir at Sunday night's opening show. Thibaux compared the noise made at the event to a jumbo jet taking off, claiming the rumbling bass from the electronic music was so loud it shook his house next door to the Carriageworks venue. The French native was eventually escorted off the runway by security, though he later apologized for disrupting the show while maintaining his complaint about the excessive noise levels.

America's elite FBI crime investigators, who are used to tackling crime, have been told they now have a new enemy to battle: calories. Expanding waistlines and lack of mobility among many agents has led to the introduction of compulsory fitness tests for all 135,000 FBI personnel. Those who fail the tests will have the marks noted on their annual performance reviews and could be moved from assignments requiring physical activity.

A volcano in Chile that had laid dormant for more than 40 years suddenly erupted, causing a thick plume of ash to cloud the sky and forcing thousands of people living in its shadow to flee their homes. Volcano Calbuco, considered one of Chile's three most dangerous volcanoes, erupted without warning around 6pm local time, prompting authorities to evacuate approximately 1,500 residents from the nearby town of Ensenada and establish a 12.5-mile exclusion zone. The spectacular eruption sent ash and smoke several kilometers into the sky, visible from up to 100 miles away in neighboring Argentina.

David Cameron defended his government's austerity and welfare policies against criticism from Church of England bishops in an Easter message to Christians. The Prime Minister insisted that the Coalition had spent five years "trying to lift people up" by making work pay and encouraging responsibility, arguing that disagreement with their policies doesn't mean they lack moral content. This response came after bishops published a guide questioning the morality of welfare cuts and austerity measures, which they claimed unfairly burdened the most vulnerable in society.

Protests are growing in Baltimore following the death of Freddie Gray, who died from a severe spinal cord injury allegedly suffered while in police custody after being arrested on April 12. Protesters have echoed claims from Gray's family attorney that police lacked probable cause to pursue him and chased him for "running while black," while Baltimore Police union attorney Michael Davey told reporters Wednesday that officers had every right to chase Gray, citing a Supreme Court case allowing police to pursue suspects who flee unprovoked in high-crime areas. The case has raised numerous questions about what happened during Gray's arrest and transport, with protesters demanding answers and calling for the officers involved to face charges.

Brandon Afoa, a 33-year-old airport worker from Puyallup, Washington, was awarded $40 million in compensation for a freak runway accident that occurred over seven years ago at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. The accident happened in December 2007 when Afoa was operating a tug to push aircraft and the brakes and steering failed, causing him to crash into a luggage lift and leaving him paralyzed from the waist down. After years of legal battles, a King County jury ruled in favor of Afoa, with the Port of Seattle being assigned 25% of the blame for failing to maintain a safe workplace.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal has scheduled a lunch appointment with Sir Alex Ferguson in the coming weeks, jokingly hoping Ferguson will pay while more seriously hoping to discuss genuine progress at the club. Van Gaal expressed optimism on Friday as United's recent victories over Tottenham and Liverpool have positioned them well in the race for Champions League qualification, with a potential win over Aston Villa on Saturday possibly moving them above Manchester City into second place. The current manager hopes to have tangible achievements to share with Ferguson, who has been waiting for positive news since leaving the club to David Moyes.

A passenger flying from Newcastle Airport to Gatwick was pulled aside by security staff who mistook his six tubs of pease pudding (a traditional North East delicacy) for Semtex plastic explosive. The part-time actor, who had previously appeared in BBC's Blackadder, was going through customs to board his EasyJet flight when airport staff discovered the pudding containers along with several Greggs pies in his hand luggage. After security told him the pudding's consistency could "technically" be classified as Semtex, he was eventually allowed through with a warning to pack such items in hold luggage next time.

The West Indies have named a 14-man squad for the first Test against England, with uncapped duo Shai Hope and Carlos Brathwaite included under new coach Phil Simmons who began work last week. The islanders cut six names from their first training camp, with Sheldon Cottrell, Miguel Cummins, Shane Dowrich, Shannon Gabriel, Leon Johnson and Veerasammy Permaul all being stood down for the opening game of the three-match series starting in Antigua on Monday. Denesh Ramdin will captain the side with Kraigg Brathwaite as his deputy.

Rejean Hermel Perron, a 43-year-old Canadian man, has been charged with holding a 27-year-old woman captive for five days in Toronto, Canada, and subjecting her to multiple sexual assaults after allegedly forcing her into his home at gunpoint. The woman was rescued by dog walker Peter Hamilton, who used nail clippers to free her from handcuffs after finding her bound, bruised, and naked from the waist down on a home's veranda pleading for help. Police have arrested Perron on charges including sexual assault with a weapon, kidnapping, and forcible confinement, and believe there may be additional victims.

A family with teenagers seeking more excitement than traditional beach holidays decided on a California road trip, driving the Pacific Coast Highway from San Francisco to Los Angeles over three weeks. The journey took them through diverse landscapes and attractions including San Francisco's cable cars and Alcatraz, the dramatic coastline of Big Sur, the quirky Madonna Inn, Santa Barbara's palm-lined streets, Hearst Castle, and finally to the beaches of Los Angeles and Huntington Beach. The trip offered a perfect blend of classic American road trip adventure and California's varied scenery, from urban attractions to wild coastlines and Hollywood glamour.

A furious row erupted between the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives after Lib Dem minister Danny Alexander released details of what he claimed were secret plans drawn up by the last government to cut Child Benefit and Child Tax Credits for families. Prime Minister David Cameron flatly rejected the claims, arguing the plans were drawn up by civil servants on Alexander's orders, while the Lib Dems accused Cameron of plotting to slash support for families and keeping benefit cuts secret until after the election. The clash represents the worst dispute between the former coalition partners and raises doubts about future cooperation, with the Conservatives under pressure to explain how they will achieve promised £12 billion welfare savings.

Sergio Garcia is focused on winning his first PGA Tour title since 2012 at this week's Shell Houston Open, despite the upcoming Masters being just around the corner. The 35-year-old Spaniard, who finished third at Houston 12 months ago but then missed the cut at Augusta, insists he's concentrating on ending his victory drought rather than thinking about next week's major championship. Garcia emphasized that while the Masters is in the back of players' minds, he wants to focus on playing well and getting into good rhythm for this week's tournament before turning his attention to Augusta.

The Nepali Pranksters, an Internet comedy series team, were in the middle of shooting an episode when a magnitude-7.8 earthquake struck Nepal on Saturday, turning their video shoot into a serious documentation of the disaster. The team kept their camera rolling for 18 minutes as they moved through crowded streets, surveying destruction to homes and historic sites while capturing scenes of people pulling survivors from rubble and the collapse of landmarks like the Dharahara tower. What began as a lighthearted prank video became an important record of the earthquake's immediate aftermath and the heroism amid the chaos.

Fashion designer Max Azria's sprawling 30,000 square foot Los Angeles mansion is now on the market for a whopping $85 million price tag. The luxurious home is spread across three acres in Holmby Hills, one of the three affluent neighborhoods that makes up the city's "Platinum Triangle," and features an impressive two-story-tall chandelier made of 150,000 crystals, 22 bathrooms, 17 bedrooms, and extravagant amenities including a private movie theater, tennis court, and multiple themed gardens.

A tragic accident occurred in Fuzhou, China, when 50-year-old driver Mei Ru accidentally killed her 53-year-old husband Song Ming while they were going shopping at a local supermarket. CCTV footage captured the moment when Song Ming climbed out of the passenger side and walked behind their parked car, just as his wife reversed the vehicle, knocking him down and running over his body. Song Ming was rushed to the hospital but died from massive internal bleeding and broken ribs, while his grief-stricken wife is being treated for shock.

NBC News has changed its account of how chief foreign correspondent Richard Engel was kidnapped in Syria in 2012, now saying he was most likely taken by Sunni rebels who tried to convince their victims they were government militants. The broadcaster had previously reported that Engel's five-day kidnapping was carried out by forces associated with President Bashar al-Assad, but new analysis suggests the captors were actually a Sunni criminal group who staged an elaborate ruse and may have even faked his rescue for propaganda purposes.

Lidia Quilligana, a nanny in Danbury, Connecticut, was arrested last month after being caught on camera allegedly beating, choking, and burning a 3-year-old girl in her care on a hot stove. The family had set up a nanny cam in December 2014 after suspecting something was wrong, and police viewed the video which prosecutors called the "worst" they had ever seen. Quilligana is charged with first degree assault of a child under 10 and has been held on $1 million bail, though her defense claims the charges are false.

During the annual Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work Day at the White House on Wednesday, a little girl named Anya Brodie asked Michelle Obama her age during a question and answer session. When Obama replied that she was 51 years old, the girl exclaimed in amazement "You look too young!" which so flattered the First Lady that she asked Anya to repeat the compliment and then invited her on stage for a hug.

Philip Garrod, a 43-year-old paramedic, was caught by a speed camera doing 105mph on his motorbike while on his way to start a shift with the Welsh Ambulance Service. To avoid a driving ban at Dolgellau Magistrates Court, he lied by claiming he was rushing to respond to a fake 999 emergency call about an injured cyclist on the A470 in north Wales, even creating false patient records to support his story. Garrod was ultimately struck off after ambulance bosses discovered no such emergency call existed on the day he was caught speeding.

While most people might believe that being covered in face tattoos would make it impossible to land a job, one inked-up Canadian man's decision to cover his head, neck and arms in crude body art has actually earned him a lucrative career as a model. Vin Los, 24, from Montreal, has landed a campaign with underwear brand Garçon Model, showcasing his extensive tattoos that include phrases like "scream my name" and "iconic face" across his face and body. The heavily tattooed model, who has 24 tattoos on his face alone, believes his body art embodies pop culture and will help him achieve his goal of becoming the most famous man in the world.

At 85 years old, Sir Stirling Moss—widely regarded as history's greatest all-round racer—recently drove around a track in a car he hadn't operated in over 50 years, demonstrating he has lost none of his racing pedigree. The legendary driver, who won 212 races during his 14-year career, revealed his unusual daily routine for maintaining his impressive longevity: performing 77 press-ups (from a kneeling position) and drinking half a bottle of Chardonnay each day. Despite his high-speed racing past, Moss now drives a modest electric Renault Twizy with a top speed of just 50mph around London, where he lives with his wife of over 40 years.

Taylor Lynn Fast, 21, was arrested after her 17-month-old daughter Layla was found beaten to death at their Missouri home on Sunday, with the mother allegedly claiming a spider bite caused the fatal injuries. Police found Layla had severe injuries consistent with the worst child abuse they had ever seen, and paramedics determined she had been dead for several hours when they arrived. A three-year-old boy with severe bruising and a broken leg was also found at the home, while authorities are searching for Fast's unnamed boyfriend, though neither has a criminal past.

Officer Jared Forsyth, 33, a member of the Ocala Police Department since 2012, was accidentally shot and killed by a coworker during firearms training at 3:30pm on Monday at a gun range at the Lowell Correctional Institution. Despite wearing a bulletproof vest, the round entered through his arm and went through his chest, and he died hours later at Ocala Regional Medical Center after surgery. Few details have been released as the Florida Department of Law Enforcement is still investigating the incident.

Police have released an image of a bearded, brown-haired man wearing a black top who they want to speak to in relation to a suspected arson attack on St Mary's Catholic Church in Dandenong, Melbourne, which occurred at 2:15am on April 1. The church was once presided over by now-deceased paedophile priest Father Kevin O'Donnell, who was convicted of abusing children and served at the church from 1958 to 1986. Detectives are investigating whether this fire is connected to two other suspicious blazes at Catholic churches in Brighton and St Kilda that also had links to paedophile priests.

Shaquille Omar Hallisey, a 20-year-old thug, was jailed for four years after hitting a stranger over the head with a bottle in Cardiff, leaving his victim Matthew Leeke with a fractured skull. The attack was described by a judge as "a savage demonstration of violence in a public place," and occurred when Leeke was walking home alone after being out with friends. Hallisey pleaded guilty to wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm at Cardiff Crown Court.

According to a new study, the average pet spends a staggering 21 hours a week watching TV, with owners admitting they spend hours watching with their animals and even leave it on when they're out to keep them company. The nation's cats, dogs, and pigs show a marked preference for animal-related programming, with Paul O'Grady's "For the Love of Dogs" being the top favorite, while reality shows like "Keeping Up With The Kardashians" are strongly disliked by pets.

Four sisters - Claire, Emily, Christine and Lily Vincenti - were caught in the middle of a bitter custody battle between their parents that spanned two continents, and have now told their side of the story three years after being dramatically removed from their Australian home. The girls were originally taken from their Italian home by their mother Laura Garrett in 2010, who claimed she was fleeing an abusive partner, but they were forcibly returned to Italy in 2012 after her story fell apart. Now living settled lives with their father in Italy, the two eldest sisters expressed regret about how they handled the traumatic situation and acknowledged they may have exaggerated some claims because they didn't want to leave Australia.

Former teacher Mary Kay Letourneau, 53, and her student-turned husband Vili Fualaau, 31, revealed in an interview with Barbara Walters how their relationship became sexual when he was just 12 years old. Speaking on the eve of their 10th wedding anniversary, the couple discussed their rape trial and marriage, explaining how their affair began when she was his sixth grade teacher in 1996. Despite the controversial circumstances that led to Letourneau serving seven and a half years in prison, the couple married in 2005 and have two teenage daughters together.

Carl Froch's promoter discusses the boxer's future plans after Julio Cesar Chavez Jr's unexpected loss to Andrzej Fonfara over the weekend, which eliminated the possibility of a Las Vegas fight that Froch wanted. The promoter has held talks with Gennady Golovkin's team and identified several potential opponents emerging from upcoming fights in the next two months, with James DeGale appearing as the most likely next opponent if he wins his IBF title fight on May 23. Froch, who hasn't fought since beating George Groves at Wembley in May 2014, remains in shape at 12st 7lbs and training regularly, but needs to return to the ring in 2015 or may retire permanently.

A nine-year-old girl named Annabel Beam plummeted 30ft headfirst inside a hollow tree and claims she "went to heaven and sat in Jesus's lap" while unconscious after the fall. Her mother, Christy Wilson Beam, 42, has spoken of her amazement that Annabel not only survived the horrifying accident unscathed but also miraculously woke up cured of a devastating illness that had plagued her childhood. The family believes Annabel's religious vision during her unconscious state was connected to her remarkable physical healing, as she can now eat solid food for the first time and no longer requires most of her previous medications.

Bradford have launched an investigation into reports that three cars were vandalised and broken into during Sunday's Ladbrokes Challenge Cup fifth-round defeat by Hull KR. The incidents occurred in the Richard Dunn Sports Centre car park, which is situated opposite Bradford's Provident Stadium at Odsal. The Championship club is working with Bradford Council, the sports centre, and West Yorkshire Police to identify those responsible and ensure improved security for future match days.

A mid-air altercation over legroom escalated into a brawl on Oman Air flight 102 from London Heathrow to Muscat, after one passenger decided to move seats on the not-full plane and another passenger objected to him sitting nearby. The fight broke out when one man allegedly attacked the other with punches and used his shoe as a weapon, forcing other passengers and crew to intervene. Upon landing in Muscat, one man was taken away by police for questioning, with the airline stating that crew managed the situation professionally and no safety risk was posed to other passengers.

An Iranian military observation aircraft flew within 50 yards of an armed U.S. Navy helicopter over the Persian Gulf this month, sparking concern among U.S. officials that top Iranian commanders might not be in full control of local forces, CNN has learned. The incident, which has not been publicly disclosed, troubled U.S. military officials because the unsafe maneuver could have triggered a serious incident. U.S. commanders believe the aggressive action may have been locally ordered by a field commander who was subsequently reprimanded, as Iranian forces have generally conducted operations professionally in recent months.

A mocked-up image has been created of Britain's ideal dog, comprising different parts from several breeds to create the perfect furry friend, based on a survey of 2,000 pet owners. While the composite dog looks like an ordinary pet at first glance with its bright, inquisitive eyes and wagging tail, it actually combines the best features from multiple breeds including an English bulldog's coat, a King Charles spaniel's ears, an Irish setter's tail, a border collie's body size, a labrador's snout, and a beagle's eyes. The research revealed regional preferences for dog sizes, with Londoners favoring smaller lap dogs while East Anglians preferred larger breeds like Great Danes.

Two soldiers, including a Buckingham Palace guard, walked free from court yesterday despite being caught on CCTV inflicting a brutal drunken beating on helpless civilians. Scots Guard Shaun Smith, 25, was filmed stamping 18 times on his victim's head while Welsh Guard Jason Collins, 22, repeatedly punched the man's body during the shocking attack near their barracks. Despite the severity of the assault, which a judge called "deeply unpleasant and inexcusable," both soldiers received suspended sentences and community orders rather than jail time, in what the judge himself described as an "extraordinary" decision.

West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has defended Leicester City boss Nigel Pearson, whom he had on his coaching staff when he was Newcastle United manager in 2007, and the pair will be reunited when West Ham face Leicester at the King Power Stadium on Saturday. Despite Pearson being involved in several controversial incidents this season, including grabbing a Crystal Palace player by the throat and losing his temper with a reporter, Allardyce admires him for being "his own man" and believes he has done an "unbelievable job" as a manager. Allardyce feels Pearson's performances don't warrant Leicester's bottom position in the Premier League, attributing their struggles to failing to convert chances at critical moments.

Eighteen-month-old twins Silas and Eli Keslar drowned in Arizona after their mother Alexis Keslar let go of their stroller while trying to fend off a bee, causing it to roll into a canal, according to police. Despite Keslar's attempts to rescue her sons from the canal, she was unable to overcome the steep sides, deep water, and strong current that swept the stroller away. The twins were found after more than an hour of searching but were pronounced dead at the hospital.

Terry McCarty, an American who suffered third-degree burns to 70 percent of his body at age six when his brothers accidentally knocked over a bowl of burning kerosene that engulfed him in flames, overcame his childhood trauma and fears by becoming a firefighter at age 29. Despite enduring 58 operations and years of bullying, McCarty successfully completed firefighter training in 2012, confronting fire for the first time since his accident. He later left firefighting to work with burned children and now plans to open his own foundation to support programs for child burn victims.

A fund-raising drive by Help for Heroes has raised £10,000 in just four days to help Second World War veteran Robert Clark remain in his own home in Burnt Oak, North London, after Brent Council said it was no longer able to afford paying for his live-in carer. Despite the fact that the 99-year-old former prisoner of war had already spent £50,000 of his life savings on care, the council refused to increase its £350 weekly contribution toward the £960-per-week cost of his ongoing care. The campaign aims to prevent Mr Clark from being moved to a care home, which his son says would be like asking his father to return to a "prisoner of war camp."

A Conservative Party office in Aberdeen, Scotland was vandalized with graffiti including a swastika and the word "scum" sprayed in white paint on the windows, along with a "Q" on the front door. Tory councillor Ross Thomson blamed "nationalists" for the attack and said it showed "the ugly face of nationalism," claiming some people cannot accept the Scottish referendum result. Police Scotland is investigating the incident, which occurred six months after similar vandalism targeted buildings and polling stations during the Scottish independence referendum campaign.

Lucas Matthysse won a majority decision against Ruslan Provodnikov in a 12-round super lightweight bout on Saturday night, with two judges scoring it 115-113 for Matthysse while one scored it a 114-114 draw. Matthysse (37-3) landed the majority of punches early and opened a cut near Provodnikov's left eye, though Provodnikov (24-3) had success in the middle rounds, landing two hard right hook-left hook combos in the fourth round. Despite Provodnikov's power punches in the later rounds, Matthysse used his three-inch reach advantage to keep his opponent at bay and secure the victory.

Ferrari team principal Maurizio Arrivabene has revealed he uses a carrot-and-stick approach with Kimi Raikkonen to maintain the driver's motivation to stay with the team, while Lewis Hamilton has yet to sign his new Mercedes contract as he negotiates the finer details. Following Raikkonen's strong second-place finish at the Bahrain Grand Prix - his first podium in 26 races - Arrivabene indicated the Finn deserves to have his contract option renewed, but emphasized he wants to keep Raikkonen "awake" and performing at his best through psychological pressure.

Gender equality in the workplace remains a hotly contested subject, with recent statistics from a US research firm Expert Market showing that little has changed over several years. The study revealed that out of 108 countries worldwide, only three countries - Jamaica (59.8%), Colombia (53.1%), and Saint Lucia (52.3%) - have workplaces where you are more likely to have a female boss than a male boss. Despite some progress, the research highlights persistent global gender inequality in management positions, with countries like Pakistan ranking lowest at just 3% female managers.

Australian teenager Violeta Tupuola, who lives near Canberra and already has naturally beautiful lips, joined the puffy pout craze by using a shot glass to pump up her lips to ridiculous proportions. She placed the opening of the shot glass over her mouth and sucked in until the vacuum of air caused her lips to excessively swell as part of the #kyliejennerchallenge. When Violeta removed the shot glass, she got the shock of her life with such protruding lips that social media users compared her to a duck.

Rangers suffered their first defeat under new manager Stuart McCall, losing 3-0 to Queen of the South in the Championship, with goals from Derek Lyle, Gavin Reilly, and a Lee Wallace own goal. Despite the setback, McCall remained defiant and urged his team to bounce back immediately in their next match against Raith Rovers on Sunday, insisting that confidence would not be affected by the loss. The defeat was Rangers' biggest-ever loss to Queen of the South, though they remain third in the table behind Hibernian on goal difference.

The LAPD is searching for a person who tagged police horse Charly with graffiti while the horse was patrolling Venice Beach with his handlers on Tuesday. The vandal managed to spray paint "RBS" and an arrow on the horse's flank in broad daylight without being seen by the officers, and authorities believe the answer to finding the perpetrator may lie in deciphering the graffiti tag itself.

Queens Park Rangers chairman Tony Fernandes expressed his despair after watching his team twice throw away leads in a 3-3 draw against Aston Villa at Villa Park, viewing the match on his iPhone from Malaysia. Christian Benteke's hat-trick, including a crucial equalizer just seven minutes before full-time, denied QPR all three points despite goals from Matt Phillips, Clint Hill, and what appeared to be a late winner from Charlie Austin. Fernandes praised his team's fighting spirit and hinted at potential changes to his own future at the club, while QPR remain in the relegation zone ahead of their upcoming match against Chelsea.

Harry Kane scored his 30th goal of the season for Tottenham in their 3-1 win over Newcastle United at the weekend, earning him the top spot in this week's EA Sports Performance Index following another round of Premier League action. The 21-year-old striker, who is nominated for both PFA Player of the Year and PFA Young Player of the Year awards, achieved a Game Index score of 55.1 after netting Spurs' third goal at St. James' Park. Kane is followed in the rankings by his Tottenham teammate Christian Eriksen in second place and Chelsea's Eden Hazard in third.

A protective dad devised a creative way to keep boys away from his young daughter by printing his muscly torso on a t-shirt and making her wear it, with the message "Stay Clear Boys, This is my dad!" warning potential suitors. The image went viral after being shared on social media, receiving hundreds of thousands of likes and shares, though reactions were mixed with some applauding the father's creativity while others criticized the approach.

An unnamed New York woman was found dead Sunday morning after hanging herself from a third-floor fire escape of her apartment building on Utica Ave. in Crown Heights, with her body left dangling for more than an hour, police say. Witnesses were traumatized by the scene, with one passer-by initially believing it was a Halloween prank because the body looked fake. Neighbors described the woman as social and nice but noted she had been struggling with mental health issues.

David Raven, a 30-year-old player from Liverpool who was recently released by Shrewsbury and Tranmere, became the hero of Scottish football over the weekend by scoring the winning goal that took Inverness Caledonian Thistle to the Scottish Cup final, defeating Celtic in the semi-final. The article criticizes Celtic for writing a complaint letter to the SFA about a penalty decision and argues that Scottish football is in decline, with poor attendance at matches and low-quality play. The author suggests major restructuring is needed, including a larger top division and better wealth distribution, to revive Scottish football's fortunes.

Real Madrid's last victory against city rivals Atletico Madrid came in the Champions League final less than a year ago, but since that win in Lisbon, Carlo Ancelotti's side has failed to win any of their last seven encounters against Diego Simeone's men. Over this period, Atletico has dominated the rivalry with four victories and three draws, outscoring Real Madrid 12-4 across all competitions including La Liga, Copa del Rey, Spanish Super Cup, and Champions League matches. The most recent meeting was a goalless draw in last week's Champions League quarter-final first leg, continuing Real's winless streak against their cross-town rivals.

Instead of spending your holiday at another nondescript hotel, you could stay on your own island at a 19th century lighthouse for the same price as a B&B. Ile Louët is perched in Morlaix Bay, France, just 1,148 feet from shore, and provides the perfect secluded retreat for up to 10 guests at only €200 (£145) for two nights. This former lighthouse keeper's cottage offers spectacular ocean views but requires guests to arrange boat transport and sacrifice some modern comforts like hot running water.

Boobesh Palani, a 26-year-old Indian student, died at Wellington Hospital in New Zealand after being rescued from Wellington Harbour by two brave teenage girls, Kelly McKay (15) and Payge Olds (16), who heard his cries for help and swam out to save him from shark-infested waters. Police initially posted his photo online to identify him since he had no identification, and after successfully identifying him through public appeals, his friends and family were able to be by his side during his final days. Despite the heroic rescue efforts by the teenagers, who performed CPR until paramedics arrived, Mr. Palani ultimately passed away surrounded by loved ones.

Scientists at the University of Bath and Yale University have made a breakthrough in clean hydrogen power development by creating a new molecular catalyst that can efficiently generate hydrogen from water through electrolysis. While hydrogen fuel is appealing for applications like cars, its production has been incredibly difficult and required huge amounts of energy, but this new material significantly reduces energy losses in the water-splitting process by making the oxygen production half of the reaction much more efficient. The breakthrough could make hydrogen production from renewable energy sources like solar and wind power much more economical and practical for energy storage.

Ed Miliband made his first appearance on the campaign trail in three days this morning in Bristol after going to ground over the Easter weekend to spend time with his family. While the Labour leader took the weekend off, his political rivals including David Cameron, Nick Clegg, and Nigel Farage wasted no opportunity to drum up support with just a month to go before polling day. Cameron embarked on a whirlwind tour of all four UK nations while Miliband remained absent from public campaigning on Sunday and Monday.

According to CNN, Yemeni officials reported that Saudi airstrikes targeting a military base on Tuesday accidentally hit a nearby school in Ibb province, injuring at least six students and reportedly killing three others. The information came from officials in the governor's office and Houthi sources, who said the Al Bastain School was struck when the Saudi coalition targeted the Al Hamza military base about 500 meters away. This incident highlights the growing civilian casualties in Yemen's conflict, where at least 74 children have been killed since the Saudi-led bombing campaign began on March 26.

Julieane Jablonski, a 38-year-old Colorado mother, was arrested Wednesday and charged with providing marijuana to a minor and witness tampering after allegedly giving her teenage son a pot brownie that caused him to jump out of a third-story window. Her 19-year-old son Austin Essig suffered non-life-threatening injuries from the fall and later wrote on the Fort Collins police department's Facebook page describing his strange "trip" from the brownie. Police allege that Jablonski told her son to lie about where the marijuana came from after he was hospitalized for his injuries.

Belgium striker Divock Origi, who was signed by Liverpool in a £10million deal after impressing at the 2014 World Cup, has revealed that watching the progress of young players like Jordon Ibe and Raheem Sterling this season has left him counting the days until he makes his Anfield debut. Origi, currently on loan at Lille, praised manager Brendan Rodgers for his ability to develop young talent and believes the challenging season he has experienced will make him a stronger player when he joins Liverpool. The striker expressed confidence that the support of Liverpool fans will help elevate his game, citing how feeling appreciated by supporters gives him an extra boost on the field.

ESPN sports reporter Britt McHenry, a 28-year-old self-professed champion of women's rights, was suspended for a week after being caught on camera verbally abusing a parking lot attendant, telling her to "lose some weight, baby girl" and making classist remarks about her education and job. The incident shows a stark contradiction to McHenry's blog posts where she advocates for women's empowerment and speaks against appearance-based discrimination. Despite her subsequent apology, the video has sparked widespread backlash and calls for her termination from ESPN.

A new global trend has emerged of adults engaging in coloring books, with Scottish illustrator Johanna Basford's "Secret Garden" selling over 1.4 million copies and being translated into 22 languages. Adults are attracted to this activity because it offers an analog, screen-free creative outlet that helps them decompress from modern life's stresses, with coloring groups forming where grown-ups meet to color together like book clubs. Experts say this trend represents a kickback against technology-driven leisure time, allowing people to rediscover creativity and find peace through the simple pleasure of staying within the lines.

A damning analysis has found that the NHS handed out 404,500 prescriptions for suncream at a cost of £13 million in 2014, along with 4.7 million prescriptions for indigestion pills costing £29 million. The NHS is spending millions on prescriptions for basic household items like suncream, toothpaste, and other bathroom cabinet essentials that are cheaply available at local chemists.
