Critics have called this practice "ludicrous" given that the NHS is facing financial constraints and rationing routine treatments while some patients appear to be abusing the system by demanding prescriptions for everyday items.

Mark Vanhoenacker's book "Skyfaring" (Chatto & Windus £16.99) has become unwittingly timely following the Germanwings flight 9525 tragedy, where a co-pilot deliberately crashed the plane into the French Alps, sparking ongoing debates about airline vetting procedures and pilot mental health. The book, written by a British Airways senior first officer, offers a passionate and insightful look into the world of aviation, sharing the secrets and mystique of flying that continues to captivate pilots despite recent events that have given aviation a more morbid flavor. Vanhoenacker provides reassurance that flying remains an exhilarating experience for experienced pilots, while revealing fascinating details about cockpit life, flight procedures, and the technical poetry of aviation.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew believes Manchester City can still come from behind to snatch the Premier League title from Chelsea, despite currently being six points behind with Chelsea having a game in hand. Pardew pointed to City's previous title wins where they overtook Liverpool with one match to go last season and won on goal difference in 2012 with Sergio Aguero's dramatic last-minute goal. The Palace boss insists the title race is far from over, emphasizing that victories can never be taken for granted in the Premier League.

Manchester United midfielder Michael Carrick has revealed he wants to pursue a career in motorsport, specifically Formula One, when his playing days are over. The 34-year-old former West Ham and Tottenham star has enjoyed a renaissance this season as Louis van Gaal's side overcame their stuttering start to secure a place in the Champions League positions. Despite his age, Carrick says he feels as fit as ever and hopes to continue playing for several more years before potentially trying his hand at F1 racing, which he describes as his passion outside of football.

An animal welfare charity called Wood Green has partnered with a cleaning app called Handy to offer a unique solution for homeowners dealing with mouse infestations - lending them cats for temporary fostering periods. The charity claims that the presence of a cat and the scent it leaves behind through pheromones is often enough to scare away rodents without the cat needing to actually catch any mice, providing a humane alternative to traps. The service allows London homeowners to choose from over 200 cats available for fostering, with the hope that some temporary placements will become permanent adoptions.

Coachella, the arts and music festival in the Californian desert known as "the festival that fashion forgot," saw celebrities and revellers leading a bad-taste brigade with increasingly outlandish outfit choices this weekend. Even among the typical array of exposed flesh, lame pieces, and mesh dresses, stars like Jaden Smith, Kylie Jenner, Paris Hilton, and Khloe Kardashian managed to stand out with particularly dubious fashion choices including floral tunics, nude hot pants with hiking boots, rose-petal cat ears, and heavily fringed outfits. Fellow festival-goers embraced the anything-goes atmosphere with neon tutus, mummy costumes, Peter Pan outfits, and various clashing prints and bizarre accessories.

The trophy room at Sandringham, the Queen's Norfolk estate, has removed all 62 pieces of hunting memorabilia including stuffed rhino heads, gleaming white tusks, tigers, and leopards from public display, replacing them with trinkets and bric-a-brac. The removal was particularly embarrassing for animal welfare crusader Prince William and came amid legal questions about the display of unworked ivory and stuffed animals dating from before 1947, which potentially violated European Council regulations. The age of political correctness appears to have caught up with what was once considered a relic of a bygone era, with even the blood-red walls being repainted white to mark the break from the past.

For years, residents and tourists in Venice have enjoyed their local, laid-back prosecco, while Britain has long seen prosecco as a second choice to champagne. However, according to industry figures released this month, British tastes are taking an Italian turn, with UK prosecco sales overtaking champagne for the first time at £181.8 million compared to £141.3 million. The rise is attributed to word-of-mouth promotion during celebratory occasions like the Jubilee and Olympics, prosecco's lighter and sweeter taste profile, and its significantly lower production costs compared to champagne.

Former Adelaide doctor Tareq Kamleh, who fled Australia to join ISIS and appeared in the terrorist group's latest propaganda video urging foreign medics to join the cult, is still allowed to practice medicine in Australia despite his public support for the terrorist organization. The Medical Board of Australia has refused to deregister the blue-eyed doctor, who remains licensed to practice until September 30, even though he featured in ISIS recruitment materials while wearing surgical scrubs and handling babies in a maternity ward. If Kamleh returns to Australia, he could face up to 25 years in prison for his involvement with the terrorist group.

A heartbreaking family photo showing 9-year-old William Kulk with his arm around his little sister Piper, 8, looking out at blue water captures their unbreakable bond and makes their tragic deaths even more devastating. The devoted siblings died within hours of each other following a fatal crash on a rain-soaked road on the NSW Central Coast, when their grandmother's car aquaplaned and collided head-on with a ute while returning from the Royal Easter Show in Sydney. Piper died Sunday morning and William died Sunday evening, while their older brother Daniel and mother remain hospitalized.

Italian former policeman Dino Maglio has been found guilty of raping a 16-year-old Australian girl after luring her to his home via the Couchsurfing website, and was sentenced to six and a half years in prison following his trial in Padua, northern Italy. Prosecutors proved that Maglio drugged the teenager by spiking her drink with a tranquillizer before assaulting her, despite his claims that the encounter was consensual. The case emerged as part of a broader investigation that revealed 14 women had come forward with similar allegations against Maglio, who used the couch-surfing platform to target vulnerable travelers.

Ed Miliband says sexting is "not advised for politicians," while Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg describes it as "risky if you are young, dodgy if you are older" when both men were asked their opinions on the practice of sending sexy text messages in a Cosmopolitan magazine quiz. Their cautious responses reflect the political scandals that have resulted from sexting, including those involving former MP Brooks Newmark and Tory official Iain Corby, demonstrating why politicians should avoid such risky behavior.

Tracy Walters, 48, died after her husband Ian's car veered off the M1 motorway and crashed into a tree at 84mph last year. Ian Walters, 51, a church treasurer and driving test examiner, is accused of deliberately killing his wife by smashing his 4x4 vehicle into the tree following relationship problems centered around sexual demands and alleged abuse. Walters denies murder, claiming he may have fallen asleep at the wheel due to antidepressant medication, while prosecutors argue he purposely crashed to show his wife "who was in charge."

Manchester Airport was forced to temporarily suspend flights for about 20 minutes today after a drone was reported buzzing around the area, causing disruption for hundreds of travelers. The potential drone sighting raised fears that the unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) could collide with a passenger jet, leading to flight delays and diversions to other airports while police conducted a helicopter search. After the search found no evidence of a drone, flights resumed, but the incident highlights growing concerns about drone safety near airports as these devices have become increasingly popular for aerial photography.

China has developed a new cyberweapon called the "Great Cannon" that attacks servers outside its borders, including in the United States, to prevent Chinese citizens from accessing Western news websites and consuming content that bypasses the Great Firewall. This highly visible denial of service attack capability will probably draw international ire, but Beijing may have counted on that risk, said researcher John Scott-Railton. The weapon uses unsuspecting web users' browsers to launch massive distributed denial of service attacks against targets like GitHub and GreatFire.org, which help Chinese citizens circumvent government censorship.

Ciudad Real airport in Spain, built in 2009 at a cost of over €1 billion during Spain's economic boom, is now being sold for just one pound after closing in 2012 due to financial difficulties. The airport, which was designed to handle 5 million passengers annually and serve as overflow for Madrid's Barajas airport, has sat empty since its last commercial flight in 2011, making it one of several "white elephant" airports across Spain. While the purchase price is only one pound, new owners would need to pay off hundreds of millions in debt.

NYPD Detective Patrick Cherry was caught on video screaming at an Uber driver in an incident that went viral with over three million views on YouTube, leading to him being stripped of his shield and gun and placed on administrative duty. Cherry appeared on NBC 4 New York to publicly apologize, saying "I sincerely apologize" and that he let his emotions get the better of him during what started as an attempt to be courteous but escalated into an argument. The incident occurred when the Uber driver honked at Cherry's unmarked car in the West Village, prompting the detective to pull over the cab and launch into a tirade that included mocking the driver's accent and questioning how long he had been in the country.

Former Manchester United goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar is convinced that Louis van Gaal will bring the glory days back to Old Trafford, as United head to Chelsea on Saturday in top form after winning six successive matches. Van der Sar believes that while the title may be beyond United's grasp this season, Van Gaal's philosophy and potential summer signings could help the club challenge for the championship next year. A victory at Stamford Bridge would put United within five points of league leaders Chelsea, though the Blues remain favorites to lift the Premier League trophy.

Bournemouth and Sheffield Wednesday played out a dramatic 2-2 draw at Dean Court, with the match featuring multiple lead changes and late drama. Sheffield Wednesday took the lead through Kieran Lee's header before Yann Kermorgant equalized for Bournemouth, who then went ahead through Matt Ritchie's spectacular free-kick despite being reduced to 10 men after Simon Francis was sent off. However, Chris Maguire converted a penalty deep into stoppage time to salvage a crucial point for Sheffield Wednesday, leaving Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe "heartbroken" after his team failed to secure what would have been a vital three points in their promotion push.

Billy-Anne Huxham, an 18-year-old woman from Caboolture, Queensland, was kidnapped at knife-point by her 32-year-old ex-boyfriend Carl Garry Chapman and was found by police at 9.45pm after she made contact with a family member. Chapman has been charged with multiple offenses including assault, torture, and deprivation of liberty, and was out on bail at the time of the abduction. Huxham reportedly escaped from her captor and fled to a local restaurant where she contacted her parents, who then alerted police.

Ronald Koeman has delivered a clear message to his Southampton players to forget about others, focus on themselves, and start scoring goals after the Saints' stellar season has stuttered in recent weeks. Southampton's struggles are largely due to their impotence in front of goal, having scored just seven times in their last 10 league matches, though they remain seventh in the Premier League with European football still within reach.

Teller Lake in Boulder, Colorado has become a giant fish bowl after being invaded by thousands of goldfish that wildlife officials say started when someone dumped four or five pet goldfish into the water two or three years ago. The goldfish population has now exploded to an estimated 3,000-4,000 fish, threatening native species by consuming their resources and potentially spreading diseases. Colorado Parks and Wildlife is now considering draining the 12-acre lake or using electrofishing to remove the invasive goldfish and restore the natural ecosystem.

Tim Howard is adamant that the Europa League is not to blame for Everton delivering what might be their worst season in nine years, rejecting the conventional wisdom that European competition has negatively impacted their Premier League performance. The goalkeeper defended the team despite their disappointing elongated campaign, which has seen them fall 25 points behind their position after 32 games last season and potentially finish in the bottom half of the Premier League for the first time since 2006. Howard argued that blaming European competition is just a "blanket statement" and that teams playing in the Champions League face similar scheduling demands without using it as an excuse.

Al Horford and DeMarre Carroll each scored 20 points to help the Atlanta Hawks match a franchise record with their 57th win, defeating the Brooklyn Nets 131-99 on Saturday night. However, the Hawks lost forward Paul Millsap to a right shoulder injury after a collision with Brooklyn's Earl Clark with 1:52 left in the first half, forcing him to leave the game early.

UK mobile phone companies promised that 4G services launched in autumn 2012 would be "five times faster" than existing 3G networks, but a new official study by Ofcom reveals the actual speed improvement is only 2.5 times faster on average (14.7 Mbit/s compared to 5.9 Mbit/s for 3G). The study also indicates that 4G speeds are likely to get worse as more users connect to the networks, with evidence showing speeds have already declined from around 19 Mbit/s when services first launched to the current average of 14.7 Mbit/s.

Jimmy Anderson was presented with a special silver cap after reaching his 100th Test match for England, joining an elite list of fast bowling centurions that includes Courtney Walsh (132), Glenn McGrath (124), Chaminda Vaas (111), Shaun Pollock (108), Wasim Akram (104), and Makhaya Ntini (101). The article also covers tributes paid to the late Richie Benaud, with both teams observing a minute's silence in his honor, and notes Chris Gayle's absence from the West Indies team as he chose to play in the IPL instead.

Ellia Beasley, who as a teenager enjoyed singing along to "Rooftops" by Lost Prophets, got a tattoo of the lyrics "scream your heart out" on her belly in 2012 because she loved the song so much. After the band's lead singer Ian Watkins was imprisoned for 35 years in 2013 for child sex offences, Ellia became ashamed of having his lyrics on her body and sought to cover the tattoo. She eventually found tattooist Kevin Paul who successfully covered the original tattoo with an owl design after other artists said it was too bold to obscure.

A taxi driver named Teng Jiazhi, known as "Uncle Teng," from Shenyang, North China, has entered the Chinese record books by taking 30,000 selfies with his passengers. He came up with this unique tipping system ten years ago after picking up a couple of tourists who had been waiting in -30°C weather, and when they offered him a tip, he declined but agreed to take a photo instead. Uncle Teng, who starts work at 3am daily and picks up around 80 passengers per day, continues to ask for selfies rather than tips and has become one of the most recognized faces in the region through his social media posts.

Mindy Kaling has denied knowing anything about her brother Vijay Chokal-Ingam's controversial decision to pretend to be African American when applying to medical school in the late 1990s. A representative for the comedienne told US Weekly that she has been estranged from her brother "for years" and was not aware of his decision to apply under a different name and race. Chokal-Ingam, who is promoting his new book "Almost Black," claims he shaved his head and altered his appearance to pose as a black applicant, ultimately gaining admission to St. Louis University School of Medicine before dropping out, though he admits his sister told him she is "ashamed" of his actions.

Julie McKenzie, a 53-year-old administrator and divorced mother of two grown-up children, experienced persistent lower back pain that her GP initially attributed to scoliosis, but she sought a second opinion when the pain wouldn't go away and would cause sharp, breath-taking sensations that forced her to stop activities. An MRI scan revealed a malignant tumor in her coccyx, which was successfully removed in October 2013, and she is now considered cured after what could have been a much more serious outcome if left undiagnosed.

Ryan Burns of Eureka, California, discovered a disgruntled French Bulldog continuously honking a car horn after being left alone in a vehicle, prompting him to film the moment when he went to investigate the persistent beeping sound. The footage shows the dog standing with its front paws pressed firmly on the horn, refusing to stop even when filmed. Burns' video has been viewed over one million times, though the dog's owner claims the pet wasn't alone for long and was left in safe conditions with food, water, and ventilation on a cool day.

Anthony Barbour, a 33-year-old photographer from Liverpool, creates mind-bending 360-degree photographs that transform typical British locations including parks, villages, and beaches in areas like Dorset, New Forest, and North Wales into surreal individual "planets." He spends hours slowly rotating in one spot, spinning around three times to capture 50 pictures using his Canon 1100d DSLR, which he then stitches together using Photoshop. Barbour has found photography to be an important artistic escape while managing his recently diagnosed autoimmune disease, Ulcerative Pan Colitis.

Waheed Ahmed, the 21-year-old son of Labour councillor Shakil Ahmed, was arrested on suspicion of terrorism offences after being stopped at the Turkish border while allegedly trying to sneak into Syria with eight relatives. Ahmed and five other family members were detained by anti-terrorism police when they returned to the UK from Turkey, but have now been released without charge. Greater Manchester Police confirmed no evidence was found to suggest any imminent threat to UK communities.

A 32-year-old Massachusetts man, Carlos Colina, is facing murder charges after another man's remains were found in a duffel bag four days earlier, authorities said Wednesday. The Middlesex District Attorney's Office announced that Colina will be arraigned on the morning of April 14 in connection with the remains of Jonathan Camilien, 26, which were discovered Saturday in Cambridge. Police found the body parts in multiple locations after being alerted to a suspicious duffel bag, with surveillance video leading them to additional remains in a nearby apartment building.

In-form winger Aaron Murphy scored twice in a seven-try romp as Huddersfield secured a dominant 38-14 Super League victory against Catalans Dragons, ending their three-match losing run. Murphy, who was named player of the month for February and March, opened the scoring with a try in the left corner on 15 minutes and continued his excellent form with six tries in his last five appearances. The Giants controlled the match with strong kicking from Danny Brough and clinical finishing, outscoring Catalans seven tries to two in a comprehensive victory.

A gang of at least three people poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger and lit it on fire at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles early Saturday morning after attempting to carjack the driver. The man's grandmother said the suspects came up asking for the car, pulled out a gun, and when her grandson ran, they took the gas tank and started spraying fuel before igniting it, ABC 7 reported. No one was hurt in the incident, but surveillance video is being used in the arson investigation as the suspects remain at large.

Although Hillary Clinton boasts a robust 3.6 million Twitter followers, according to two popular online measuring tools, only 44 percent of her Twitter fan base consists of real people who are active in using the social media platform. The analysis found that at least 15 percent of her followers are completely fake, while 41 percent are inactive accounts that never tweet or engage with content. This comes amid additional concerns about artificially inflated social media metrics, including reports that over 46,000 of her Facebook fans list Baghdad, Iraq as their hometown.

Andrea Dossena, a 33-year-old former Liverpool player who the club shelled out £7million for, has been arrested on suspicion of shoplifting at Harrods on Tuesday. The Italian defender, whose crowning moment came when he scored the winner against Real Madrid in the Champions League and also netted against Manchester United in 2009, now plies his trade with League One strugglers Leyton Orient. He was later bailed pending further enquiries by police.

Rescue workers from Animal Rescue Corps freed almost 100 dogs that had been kept locked in a blacked-out barn in Tennessee on Saturday, discovering them in deplorable conditions living in complete darkness surrounded by their own waste. The emaciated dogs, many with acid burns and infections from light deprivation, were so dirty that some breeds were hard to tell apart, and workers found 10 dead dogs piled in a wheelbarrow covered in maggots. After being rescued, the traumatized animals shot their noses up to the sky to absorb sunlight and oxygen before being sent for treatment at a shelter in Lebanon, Tennessee.

Michael Easy, 29, from Southampton, went on the run in 2013 after attacking a woman at a party and taunted police by posting Facebook photos of himself wearing a silver wig and Dame Edna-style sunglasses under the profile name "Michelle." After being caught and jailed for 15 months, he went on the run again upon release in December and has now been sentenced to four months in prison for breaching a restraining order and assaulting two prison officers.

Harold Ekeh, an 18-year-old Long Islander, faces a tough decision after being accepted to all 13 colleges he applied to, including every Ivy League school. The Nigerian immigrant, who moved to the U.S. at age 8, achieved this remarkable feat with straight A's and a 2270 SAT score, crediting his success to his parents' resilience and his essay about his family's struggle to fit in America. His achievement comes a year after another Long Island student, Kwasi Enin, accomplished the same rare feat of acceptance to all eight Ivy League schools.

In an intensely personal interview, David Cameron revealed that he and his wife Samantha were "falling apart" under the pressure of caring for their disabled son Ivan, who was born with a rare brain disorder called Ohtahara Syndrome. Cameron admitted they were struggling with "coping with the nights and everything," while Samantha said in a separate interview that the stress of caring for Ivan pushed their relationship to "breaking point" within the first year. Ivan, who required round-the-clock care and suffered from severe epileptic fits, died at age six in 2009, with both parents describing the experience as life-changing and emotionally devastating.

BBC iPlayer users are frustrated that the final minutes of radio dramas and shows like Dad's Army and Hancock's Half Hour are being cut off due to problems with the BBC's automatic recording system. The corporation blames the issue on live programming causing start and end times to shift, which confuses their recording technology, and admits this has been an ongoing problem for at least three years. The BBC has now announced they will add two minutes to the end of all recordings to try to resolve the issue, as catch-up listening becomes increasingly popular with 57 million requests made in February alone.

This is a description of the April 3, 2015 episode of CNN Student News, which covered various international and domestic topics including events in Switzerland, Kenya, and the Pacific Ocean, California's drought and mandatory water usage cuts, two religious holidays being celebrated worldwide that weekend, and subjects related to U.S. National Parks. The page also provides access to the show's transcript, a weekly news quiz with 10 questions covering recent global events, and instructions for schools to request mentions on the program's Roll Call segment.

Daniel Sturridge faces a fight to be fit for Liverpool's FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa on Sunday after being left out of their squad for Monday's match against Newcastle United due to an injury sustained at Blackburn Rovers. Manager Brendan Rodgers confirmed that his star striker's fitness will be monitored ahead of the Wembley clash, as the Cup represents Liverpool's last hope for silverware this season. Meanwhile, Manchester City's recent 4-2 defeat has given Liverpool hope of closing the gap in the race for a top-four Premier League finish.

The family of teenage burglar Thomas Buckett, who was left seriously injured after falling 15ft through a school roof during a break-in, has been ordered to pay a £150,000 legal bill after unsuccessfully suing the council for failing to secure the premises. Buckett, who was 16 at the time, plunged through a glass skylight onto a concrete floor after friends dared him to jump on it during the 2010 break-in at Clayton Hall Business and Language College, sustaining life-changing head injuries that left him in a coma for two weeks. The court rejected the family's claim under the Occupiers Liability Act, ruling that the school could not reasonably have prevented the trespass, and ordered the family to pay the council's legal costs.

Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho, 52, believes he is continuously improving in every aspect of his job after winning league titles in all four countries he has managed - Portugal, England, Italy and Spain. However, the manager insists his one problem is that he cannot help but be truthful when addressing the media, which regularly lands him in hot water with the Football Association regarding his comments and has resulted in multiple fines.

Two black candidates were among three people elected to the Ferguson City Council on Tuesday, tripling African-American representation in the St. Louis suburb where poor race relations have been a focal point since the August shooting death of an 18-year-old black man by a white police officer. The election means that half of the six-member city council in Ferguson, where two-thirds of the 21,000 residents are black, will now be African-American. Voter turnout increased substantially to 29.4 percent compared to just 12.3 percent in the previous election, coming just over a month after a Justice Department report detailed a culture of racism and abuse among city officials and police.

Chelsea will face Paris Saint-Germain in a pre-season friendly in North Carolina on July 25, marking a rematch against the French team that knocked them out of the Champions League at the last-16 stage following a 2-2 draw on away goals this season. This match is one of three games Mourinho's side will feature in during their US tour as they gear up to defend their probable Premier League title, with Chelsea currently 10 points ahead of Arsenal with four games remaining.

Burnley manager Sean Dyche has attempted to protect out-of-sorts striker Danny Ings by calling on the rest of his team-mates to share the goalscoring burden to keep the team in the Premier League. Ings, who is strongly linked with moves to Manchester United or Liverpool when his contract expires in summer, hasn't scored since February 11 and missed a key chance in Burnley's 1-0 defeat at Everton that left them bottom of the table. Dyche insists it's unfair to pin the club's survival hopes on one player, emphasizing that the whole team must step up as they have scored just one goal in their last seven matches.

English photographer John Chapple has traveled around the world creating stunning panoramic images using a film camera, specifically a Linhof Technorama 617s III that produces large 6x17 centimeter negatives. He has captured diverse landscapes including grassy fields in England, major US cities, and sandy beaches in Australia, transitioning from news and showbusiness photography to landscape work. Chapple, who is self-taught and failed art in school, is motivated to document the changing world for future generations and dreams of making a living from his landscape photography.

Celebrities and fashionistas are increasingly carrying controversial statement bags that feature inappropriate slogans and imagery, with Madonna recently showcasing a mock crocodile "dealer" purse that has sparked criticism. Many stars including Rihanna and Rumer Willis have been spotted with clutches and handbags emblazoned with gun motifs, drug references, and other provocative designs, while designers are incorporating weapons, naked women, and other offensive elements into their luxury accessories. This trend of controversial statement bags has become widespread across the fashion industry, with various designers pushing boundaries through shock value rather than tasteful design.

ABC's World News Tonight with David Muir has officially overtaken NBC's Nightly News in the ratings war for the first time in more than five and a half years, ending NBC's 288 consecutive week winning streak that stretched back to September 2009. The ratings shift comes two months after NBC anchor Brian Williams received a six-month suspension for misleading viewers about his coverage of the Iraq War in 2003. ABC attracted 84,000 more viewers than NBC for the week ending April 3, with veteran anchor Lester Holt continuing to fill in for Williams during his suspension.

Robert Downey Jr has been accused of making a racist remark about Oscar-winning Mexican director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu during an interview while promoting his new film Avengers: Age of Ultron. When asked about Inarritu's claim that superhero movies were "cultural genocide," Downey Jr said "for a man whose native tongue is Spanish to be able to put together a phrase like 'cultural genocide' just speaks to how bright he is," which sparked a furious backlash on Twitter with critics calling the comments racist and ignorant. The controversy adds to other recent issues during the Avengers press tour, including Downey Jr walking out of a Channel 4 interview when asked about his past drug abuse and prison time.

A prisoner who rode in a police van with Freddie Gray on April 12 told investigators that he believed the 25-year-old was trying to hurt himself inside the vehicle, according to a leaked police affidavit. The anonymous prisoner, who was jailed for violating a restraining order, claimed he could hear Gray "banging against the walls" and "intentionally trying to injure himself," though he could not see what Gray was doing due to a metal partition separating them. However, Gray's family attorney rejected the self-inflicted injury claim, and local reporters found inconsistencies with the leaked report, as police had originally said the second prisoner described Gray as "mostly quiet."

Never-before-seen photos from Sir Paul McCartney's 2002 wedding to Heather Mills have emerged, showing what should have been a happy celebration with family and friends after the couple tied the knot. However, a closer look at the wedding party picture reveals that McCartney's daughters Stella and Mary appear notably unhappy, foreshadowing the bitter divorce that would follow in 2008. The rare images, belonging to McCartney's late housekeeper's family, are now being auctioned and provide a glimpse into the secretive Irish castle ceremony that was attended by 300 guests including Ringo Starr.

Sebastian Vettel is determined to ensure that Ferrari's long-standing victory rituals, which returned after the team's first win in 35 grands prix at Malaysia 11 days ago, are not a one-off this season. The victory ended Vettel's own 20-race drought and allowed Ferrari to revive traditions not seen at their Maranello factory for almost two years, including raising a Ferrari flag at the entry gate and celebrating with all factory staff. Vettel expressed hope that the team will be able to add more flags throughout the season, though he remains realistic about the challenges ahead against strong rivals like Mercedes.

Long Island mother Iona Costello, 51, and her daughter Emily, who went missing last month, have been found safe and well in New York City's Upper West Side neighborhood. The pair were recognized by a hotel front desk manager where they were staying and were located by NYPD officers at 3am on Sunday. The disappearance occurred amid a legal battle over Iona's late husband's estate, with her 45-year-old stepson George Costello Jr currently in jail in Florida on unrelated charges, though police do not suspect foul play in the missing persons case.

A tragic incident occurred on a rubber dinghy carrying around 100 African refugees across the Mediterranean when Nigerian Muslims became angry at a Christian passenger who began praying for his life, with one Muslim saying "Here, we only pray to Allah." When the Christian refused to stop praying, a violent fight ensued that resulted in 12 Christians being thrown overboard and drowning by the Muslim refugees. This incident comes amid reports that 10,000 refugees fleeing war and persecution in Africa have been rescued by Italian ships in the past week, with Italian police arresting 15 people suspected of the killings.

Four-month-old baby Evan Summerfield from Devon died from meningitis just 12 hours after laughing for the very first time, leaving his family devastated. The baby had just learned how to giggle and take his dummy out by himself, but hours later developed a rash and was rushed to Derriford Hospital in Plymouth where he was diagnosed with meningococcal septicaemia and died despite doctors' efforts to save him. His parents Shannon Summerfield, 17, and Kris Adams, 19, along with the rest of the family are struggling to comprehend how quickly the illness took hold of their beloved baby.

A 24-year-old Chicago Cubs fan named Krista Dotzenrod from Minnesota managed to catch a foul ball directly in her cup of beer during Saturday afternoon's game against the San Diego Padres. After the lucky catch, which she described as "pure luck," Dotzenrod immediately chugged the beer with the ball still inside to the delight of surrounding fans. The Cubs won the game 7-6 in 11 innings, and Dotzenrod's remarkable catch quickly gained attention on social media.

A Czech prankster named Erik Meldik got painful comeuppance after his girlfriend Dominika Petrinova glued him naked to a chair with wax strips following his viral prank where he told her he had accidentally put her dog in a washing machine. The 27-year-old woman from the Czech Republic was furious after her boyfriend's joke, which he posted online and went viral, caused her to burst into tears before he revealed the dog was safe. Petrinova exacted her revenge by tricking her blindfolded, naked boyfriend into sitting on the booby-trapped chair, leaving him screaming in pain as he had to rip himself free, losing skin and hair in the process.

Hull City are targeting QPR centre-back Nedum Onuoha, with the 28-year-old being one of several players poised to leave Loftus Road as the club considers streamlining their squad. Onuoha, who has 15 months left on his contract and has played regularly under Chris Ramsey, was in the starting eleven for QPR's crucial 4-1 win over West Bromwich Albion at the Hawthorns. Hull are also interested in West Bromwich Albion striker Victor Anichebe, while other clubs including Stoke, Everton, and West Ham are also showing interest in Onuoha.

London is set to open yet another single-item menu eatery this week with the Oshun Café, which will serve £6 bowls of Brazilian superfood acai berries, following the trend of specialized restaurants like cereal cafes, porridge pop-ups, and toastie restaurants. The sparse menu offers four variations of acai berry bowls with different toppings including bananas, granola, honey, and various fruits and spices. This continues London's growing movement of niche food establishments that focus on serving just one type of dish or ingredient.

Haunting images show the partially-submerged ruins of St Ivan Rilski Church, the only remaining evidence of the community of Zapalnya, Bulgaria, where residents lived until they were forced to leave their homes in 1965 to make way for a dam built by the Communist regime. The town was swallowed by an artificial lake when the settlement and surrounding area were submerged, with most inhabitants moving to neighboring villages that were not affected by the man-made reservoir. The crumbling church, built in 1895, now cuts a ghostly figure in the water and has become a popular destination for tourists and photographers.

Real Madrid demolished Granada 9-1 in a dominant La Liga performance, with Cristiano Ronaldo scoring five goals (including a seven-minute hat-trick), Karim Benzema netting twice, and Gareth Bale adding another goal along with a Diego Mainz own goal. Robert Ibanez scored Granada's only consolation goal in what became the biggest win of the La Liga season. The comprehensive victory helped Real Madrid bounce back from their El Clasico defeat to Barcelona and represented a ruthless display against the second-bottom Granada side.

Everton hosts Southampton in a Premier League clash at Goodison Park on Saturday, with both teams dealing with injury concerns as Romelu Lukaku faces a late fitness test for Everton while Southampton's Steven Davis is doubtful after suffering a groin injury on international duty with Northern Ireland. The Saints have struggled at Goodison Park historically, winning none of their last nine Premier League visits, while Everton has scored just eight goals in 30 Premier League games this season compared to 16 at the same stage last season. Southampton could equal their best ever Premier League points tally of 56 with a victory, having dropped just two points from leading positions all season.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto has admitted he is still considering whether to join Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer, after club president Naoki Ogane revealed earlier this month that the Blues made an offer of around £4million for the Japan international. The 22-year-old, who scored the winner against Shonan Bellmare last week, said he wants to carefully consider his options and join a club where he can "play and develop" regularly. Chelsea would reportedly loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season if the transfer goes through.

Kick It Out has welcomed the successful prosecution of John Wild from Wotton-under-Edge, Gloucestershire, who was issued a three-year banning order and ordered to pay compensation after being found guilty of racially abusing former Wales goalkeeper Jason Brown during a football match last October. The organization sought to address Brown's criticism that they "did nothing about it" by detailing their involvement, including meeting with Brown the day after the incident and offering support, though they claim Brown subsequently stopped responding to their follow-up attempts. Despite the successful court outcome, Brown remained critical of anti-racism groups, saying he hopes they will one day "actually do what they say they will" and provide equal support to all players regardless of league level.

Just days after Bruce Jenner's powerful interview with Diane Sawyer, another transgender person is making a monumental television appearance as Scott Turner Schofield becomes the first transgender man to have a recurring role on a daytime soap opera when he appears on The Bold and the Beautiful starting in May. Schofield will play Nick, a mentor to the character Maya Avant who is struggling with her gender identity, marking his television acting debut after being known for his transgender-focused one-person shows and advocacy work.

Researchers have warned that children should not be encouraged to play rugby at school because it is too dangerous, with as many as 1 in 8 players suffering injuries serious enough to require missing at least seven training sessions or matches. Professor Allyson Pollock from Queen Mary University of London expressed concern about government plans to increase rugby participation in schools, arguing that inadequate injury surveillance systems fail to protect children from risks including concussion, fractures, and spinal cord damage. While the Rugby Football Union maintains that rugby's benefits outweigh the risks and has safety rules in place, Pollock advocates for safer alternatives like touch rugby instead of contact rugby for school children.

Tiger Woods, the 14-time major winner who has played just three tournaments this year, took a break from competition to give golf lessons to 7ft 6in former NBA star Yao Ming at Nike's headquarters in Shanghai. Despite facing many huge challenges during his career, Woods appeared dwarfed by the towering Chinese basketball player as he helped him work on his swing. Woods has since confirmed his return to the PGA Tour at the Players Championship on May 7, allaying fears about a wrist injury he suffered at the Masters.

Andy Murray advanced to the semi-finals of the Miami Open after a challenging 3-6, 6-4, 6-1 victory over 21-year-old Austrian Dominic Thiem, nearly giving himself extra preparation time for his wedding next week before ensuring he still has unfinished tennis business to attend to. The world No. 4 received a scare from the talented young Austrian, who pushed Murray hard before ultimately falling in an hour and three-quarters match. Murray also commented on the recent citizenship change of Slovenian-born Aljaz Bedene to British, encouraging fellow British players to use it as motivation rather than complain about the new competition.

Vincent Kompany, the Manchester City captain and winner of two Premier League titles, has revealed that his mother prevented him from joining Manchester United when he was 17 years old. The Belgian defender was the subject of an inquiry from Sir Alex Ferguson while breaking through at Anderlecht, but his mother insisted he finish his education before moving to England. Kompany eventually joined Manchester City in 2008 and says "everything has played out perfectly" as he prepares for Sunday's derby against his former suitors at Old Trafford.

Despite the Duchess of Cambridge's global fashion influence, with whatever she wears selling out within minutes among women across the globe, leading author Margaret Atwood has dismissed Kate as an "uneventful" dresser. The 75-year-old author said Kate hasn't lived up to the fashion icon reputation of her husband's late mother, Princess Diana, suggesting the duchess is cautious with her clothing choices and likely told what to wear by advisers. Atwood believes Kate is right not to follow in Diana's footsteps, though she joins other high-profile female writers who have criticized the duchess's public persona.

Martyn Uzzell, 51, was killed during a charity cycle ride from Land's End to John O'Groats when he hit a four-inch deep pothole on the A65 near Giggleswick, North Yorkshire, which threw him into the path of a car. Despite police reporting the dangerous pothole to the council a month before the tragedy, North Yorkshire County Council failed to repair it after inspections deemed it non-urgent. His widow Kate Uzzell has now won a six-figure settlement from the council, though they refuse to accept liability or apologize for the road conditions that led to her husband's death.

Cristiano Ronaldo dominated Spanish sports papers on Monday after scoring five goals in one game for the first time in his illustrious career, as Real Madrid crushed Granada 9-1 to keep their title hopes alive. The front pages of major publications like Marca and AS featured the beaming Portugal international, celebrating his unstoppable performance that included an eight-minute hat-trick. Meanwhile, league leaders Barcelona maintained their four-point advantage with a 1-0 victory over Celta Vigo.

Holland manager Guus Hiddink slammed his own supporters for booing Spanish midfielder Andres Iniesta during Holland's 2-0 victory over Spain on Tuesday night at the Amsterdam Arena, branding their behavior a "disgrace." Iniesta, who started on the bench as part of Spain coach Vicente del Bosque's experimental lineup, was jeered by home fans when he entered the match in the 76th minute. Hiddink defended the Barcelona star as "a world class player and a wonderful person," expressing disbelief at the treatment likely stemming from Iniesta's decisive goal against the Netherlands in the 2010 World Cup final.

Hillary Clinton's trusted aide Huma Abedin, 38, was spotted enjoying another Mexican meal in New York with her husband, disgraced former congressman Anthony Weiner, and their young son, just days after her Chipotle lunch with Clinton became a media storm during the early stages of the presidential campaign. The notoriously low-profile staffer appeared to be relishing her final taste of freedom before the campaign intensifies, opting for a more upscale Mexican restaurant called Tortaría rather than the Chipotle chain that had generated controversy earlier in the week.

Football Shirt Friday got into full swing as celebrities showed off their favourite kits in support of The Bobby Moore Fund for Cancer Research UK. Fans were asked to unite against bowel cancer by donning a football shirt – old or new – in memory of 1966 World Cup-winning captain Bobby Moore, who died from bowel and liver cancer in 1993. This third annual event takes place in April during Bowel Cancer Awareness Month, with celebrities like Clare Balding and Rob Lee showing their support on social media.

Quinton 'Rampage' Jackson has admitted he's already been through the wringer before stepping back into the Octagon, returning to the UFC after two years with Bellator to face Fabio Maldonado in Montreal on Saturday night. The former light-heavyweight champion had to first endure a protracted legal battle before being permitted to compete at UFC 186. Jackson expressed that the preparation period was extremely stressful but he's glad to be back fighting for the fans who wanted to see him return to action.

A pregnant woman was saved after being left clinging to the hull of their overturned trimaran in the English Channel off the coast of Kent, when her partner ensured she was safe then dived under the capsized boat to retrieve an emergency flare. The couple was spotted in the water a mile from Dungeness Point and rescued by coastguard and RNLI crews who responded to help within minutes. Both were wearing lifejackets and were taken to hospital, described as cold and shaken but unharmed from the ordeal.

A 17-year-old teen named Cassandra C. has completed her chemotherapy treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma and left Connecticut Children's Medical Center on Monday, according to her attorney Josh Michtom. Cassandra had been living at the hospital since December after a judge ordered her into state custody when she ran away to avoid the forced chemotherapy treatment. The temporary custody order has now ended with the completion of her treatment, and she is reportedly in remission.

Pierre Collins, the father of 10-year-old Barway Collins whose body was found in the Mississippi River over the weekend, was arrested Monday on suspicion of second-degree murder in his son's death. This arrest came less than a month after Pierre Collins had appeared at a vigil tearfully pleading for his son's safe return. Police say they have electronic evidence placing the father in the area where the boy disappeared on March 18, and the case is now being treated as a homicide investigation.

As rescue efforts continue to find survivors beneath mounds of rubble across Kathmandu, the grieving Nepalese nation has begun the grim and daunting task of cremating thousands of earthquake victims. With the death toll now standing at over 4,000, mass cremations are taking place along the Bagmati river, where plumes of white smoke rise from hundreds of burning pyres as families give their loved ones traditional Hindu send-offs. The sacred cremation sites are overwhelmed, with the Pashupatinath Temple receiving 500 bodies per day compared to the usual 30, while volunteers help comfort mourners and carry out the ceremonies amid flames and desperate grief.

A horse named Cody became stuck in thick mud after wandering into a bog in Belvedere, south-east London, requiring animal rescue experts to spend over an hour freeing him on Friday afternoon. Despite being covered head to hoof in mud and shaken by the ordeal, Cody was otherwise unharmed after being dragged to safety by rescue crews. Borough Commander for Bexley Richard Welch said crews worked hard to save the horse, adding that "it won't be running in the Grand National tomorrow" and that Cody was taken back to the stables to be seen by a vet.

Karen Bell, a 42-year-old mother from Hull, has been jailed for 12 months after blackmailing a man she met on dating website Plenty of Fish. Bell threatened to post videos of their sexual encounters online unless he paid her money, initially demanding £25 and eventually extorting a total of £55 from the victim. She pleaded guilty to blackmail at Hull Crown Court, where the judge ruled that despite the relatively small amount involved, the serious nature of blackmail warranted a custodial sentence.

Following his inspired charity work, Chelsea forward Didier Drogba has been awarded the Barclays Spirit of the Game trophy for setting up the 'Didier Drogba Foundation in Africa.' The 37-year-old hopes to inspire the next generation of footballers in Africa to fall in love with the game, drawing from his own experiences growing up poor in the Ivory Coast where he played football in the streets without shoes. The foundation provides educational and health support, including a medical clinic in Abidjan that will open later this year, funded partly by a recent charity ball that raised £400,000.

Mohammad Qamaruzzaman, assistant secretary general of Bangladesh's Jamaat-e-Islami party, was executed by hanging on Saturday night after being convicted of crimes against humanity during the 1971 independence war. He had led a militia group that collaborated with the Pakistani army and was responsible for killing approximately 120 unarmed farmers during the conflict. His execution has sparked controversy, with his party calling for nationwide strikes and international organizations questioning whether his trial met fair standards.

The article follows a journalist's visit to Washington D.C. to explore the real-world political intrigue that inspired the hit US TV series House of Cards, featuring Francis Underwood played by Kevin Spacey. The journalist discovers that Washington's political culture of feuds, power-broking, and manipulation has been controlling America since the capital was established in 1790, when Maryland and Virginia agreed to donate land for the District of Columbia. Through visits to venues like the Capital Grille's private dining rooms and the working political building of the United States Capitol, the article reveals how the city's atmosphere of political scheming mirrors the dark dealings portrayed in the television series.

Leo Bernal, an 8-year-old boy from Culver City, California, is lucky to be alive after an intruder shot him in the head while he lay in bed with his 17-year-old brother during a terrifying home invasion over the weekend. The brave child was released from the hospital on Friday with 23 staples in his head after doctors had to open his skull to remove the bullet. Police are still searching for the gunman who fired 14 shots into the family's home, and Leo is now scared to return home after the traumatic incident.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in the eastern Afghan city of Khost on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker who was participating in the demonstration, police said. The protesters were on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor when the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time. The Taliban denied responsibility for the bombing, and no other group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

The third World Happiness Report released by the UN's Sustainable Development Solutions Network ranks the world's happiest countries, with Switzerland taking the top spot followed by Iceland and Denmark. The concept of World Happiness Day originated in 2011 when Bhutan's Prime Minister proposed it to the United Nations, leading to its official designation in 2012. The report highlights that happy countries share characteristics like longer life expectancies, social support, generosity, freedom, low corruption, and higher GDP per capita, with travel destinations ranging from Switzerland's Alps to Australia's Tasmania (located 149 miles off the mainland coast).

The family of four-year-old Austin West, a North Carolina toddler who drowned in a pool last Saturday after slipping while chasing a bumblebee, discovered that scammers had already set up fake GoFundMe pages in his name when they tried to create their own online fundraiser for funeral costs. The fraudulent fundraisers have since been removed, but the family's legitimate campaign has only raised $315 of their $10,000 goal as of Friday evening. Austin's grandfather expressed frustration at people trying to "make a buck off of a child" during their time of grief.

The family rift in France's National Front deepened when 86-year-old founder Jean-Marie Le Pen withdrew from regional elections after infuriating his daughter Marine, the party's current leader, with racist and anti-Semitic remarks including calling the Holocaust "a detail of history." Le Pen announced that his 25-year-old granddaughter Marion Marechal-Le Pen should stand in his place for the December elections, saying he would make this sacrifice to avoid weakening the far-right party. The move allows Le Pen to avoid potential formal exclusion by the party's political bureau while keeping the candidacy within the family.

Andrew Getty, the 47-year-old grandson of oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, died Tuesday afternoon at his home in Los Angeles, according to a statement from his parents Ann and Gordon Getty. The Los Angeles County coroner's office indicated that Getty's death appears to be from natural causes or an accident, with medication found at the scene, and his family has requested privacy during this difficult time.

The Wisden–MCC Cricket Photograph of the Year 2014 was won by Getty Images photographer Matthew Lewis for his stunning image of West Indies player Dwayne Bravo taking a spectacular catch to dismiss Australia's James Faulkner during last year's ICC World Twenty20 competition in Bangladesh. The shortlist featured diverse cricket photography from around the world, including children playing on a rubbish tip in Bangladesh, England's Danny Briggs bowling in Hobart Australia during a Twenty20 International match, and players competing at Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania. Other notable images captured dramatic moments such as England bowler Stuart Broad being hit in the face by a ball that broke his nose after squeezing through his helmet's grille, and Joe Russell of Bexley Cricket Club making an athletic boundary catch attempt.

A Reddit thread asking users to submit the worst baby names they've encountered attracted over 18,000 comments in 24 hours, revealing shocking examples of poor parental naming choices. Some of the most horrendous names shared include "Airwrecker" (an alternative spelling of Erica), "Orgasm," "I'munique," "Britney Shakira Beyonce," and "Gennah Tyles" (which sounds like "genitals"), demonstrating how some parents make questionable decisions when naming their children.

The number of hayfever sufferers in the UK is predicted to reach 20 million this summer, representing a third increase from last year as warm weather bathes the country. While many will welcome the glorious sunshine and promise of temperatures warmer than the Mediterranean this week, millions face impending misery from pollen-related symptoms including streaming eyes, sneezing, and throat irritation. Experts warn that five million people are expected to experience hayfever symptoms for the first time, with the situation expected to worsen due to longer pollen seasons and climate change effects.

Raheem Sterling, still just 20 years old with a Wembley tattoo from 2007 marking his tender years and dreams of professional football, has turned down a new £100,000-per-week contract offer from Liverpool and expressed his intention to wait until summer before deciding on his future. The England international, who made his Liverpool debut in 2012, was seen training at the club's Melwood headquarters on Thursday as they prepared to take on Arsenal, while his contract situation continues to dominate headlines after his recent BBC interview where he sought to express his views on the ongoing negotiations.

TV star Karren Brady, a businesswoman and Apprentice judge, agreed to help David Cameron announce 16,000 new apprenticeships today on the campaign trail, though she might have been hoping to steal a little of the limelight from the Prime Minister. However, Brady was relegated to a supporting role, helping Cameron with his jacket before sitting on the sidelines. The announcement included signed agreements with major companies like Costa Coffee and Morrisons to train thousands of apprentices across the country, as part of Cameron's pledge to create three million more apprenticeships over the next five years if the Conservatives win the election.

One daredevil decided to take extreme skiing to a whole new level by hitting the slopes of the active Tolbachik volcano on Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula, while his friend Fredrik Schenholm photographed the incredible feat in amazement. The volcano, which erupted in November 2012 after lying dormant since 1976, regularly emitted jets of lava up to 656 feet high, creating a stunning contrast against the white snow as the skier descended the dangerous slopes. The photographer captured the dramatic images showing the extreme temperature differences, with air temperatures around -25°C while lava temperatures exceeded 1,000°C.

Newcastle head coach John Carver says he will use a "whip" to motivate his players ahead of Sunday's Tyne-Wear derby at the Stadium of Light, after the Magpies have lost their last four matches against North-East rivals Sunderland. Carver, who was assistant to Alan Pardew during that wretched run, admits that Sunderland have out-worked Newcastle in those previous encounters and is determined to prevent it from happening again. The Newcastle boss insists his team has "everything to play for" despite their comfortable mid-table position compared to relegation-threatened Sunderland.

The Scottish Football Association failed in their attempt to increase the punishment for Rangers goalkeeper Steve Simonsen, who had received a one-game ban after admitting to breaking the SFA's zero-tolerance gambling rules by betting on 50 games over a year. SFA compliance officer Tony McGlennan challenged the original decision as "unduly lenient," but an appellate tribunal rejected the appeal, confirming that the 35-year-old's suspension would not be extended further.

The article discusses the controversy surrounding Newcastle goalkeeper Tim Krul congratulating Sunderland striker Jermain Defoe at half-time after Defoe scored a brilliant goal, comparing it to the famous 1970 World Cup embrace between Pele and Bobby Moore that has long been celebrated as the pinnacle of sportsmanship. While critics like Jamie Carragher condemned Krul's gesture as inappropriate during an intense derby match, the author argues that football has become too devoid of humanity if players can't acknowledge great technique and show basic sportsmanship, even during competition. The piece suggests that the criticism may be unfairly harsh partly because Krul is a foreign player, questioning whether the same condemnation would have occurred if an English player had made a similar gesture.

President Barack Obama and his wife Michelle paid more than $93,000 in federal taxes last year on an adjusted gross income of more than $477,000, according to tax returns released Friday by the White House. Their effective tax rate was 19.6 percent, and they reported nearly $160,000 in itemized deductions including $70,712 in charitable donations. The White House also released Vice President Joe Biden's returns, showing he and his wife paid over $90,000 in federal taxes on an adjusted gross income of nearly $389,000.

Saracens have announced that 31-year-old Argentina centre Marcelo Bosch has signed a contract extension, following his heroic performance in their European Champions Cup quarter-final where he secured a 12-11 victory over Racing Metro in Paris by booting a penalty with the game's final kick. The 33 times-capped international joined Saracens from Biarritz in 2013 and has been praised by rugby director Mark McCall for his hard work and constant improvement since arriving at the club.

High-powered human rights lawyer Amal Clooney held a press conference at the National Press Club in Washington DC on Thursday at 10am, calling for the release of imprisoned former Maldives president Mohamed Nasheed. She was accompanied by Laila Ali, the wife of the jailed politician, and Jared Genser, founder of the organization Freedom Now. Nasheed, who came to power in 2008 as the Maldives' first democratically elected leader, was sentenced to 13 years in prison last month under anti-terror laws in what human rights activists describe as a politically motivated "sham trial."

Paula Radcliffe, the 41-year-old mother-of-two who has won the London Marathon three times, says she'll be happy just to finish this weekend's race regardless of her position after battling back from injury. The three-time London Marathon champion, who set the still-unbeaten world record of 2:15:25 in 2003, will be running with the masses rather than the elite field as she brings her professional career to a close. Despite describing herself as "unfit and unprepared," Radcliffe is delighted to take part in the 26.2-mile race in the capital one more time after surgery in 2012 allowed her to return to running.

Aaron Ramsey dedicated his recent goal against Burnley to his late grandmother Eileen, who passed away a few weeks ago and had been a major source of support throughout his career. The Welsh midfielder reflected on Arsenal's FA Cup victory last year, where his extra-time winner ended the club's nine-year trophy drought, and expressed optimism about the team's current form as they prepare for another FA Cup semi-final against Reading. Ramsey believes Arsenal are in a stronger position this year without the pressure of their previous trophy drought, though he emphasized the importance of not underestimating their opponents.

Teenager Lily Sharp from the UK decided to play an elaborate prank on her mother by faking her own kidnapping through text messages, pretending a "decorator" had entered their home and then impersonating the kidnapper who demanded £4000 ransom. The prank escalated to the point where her panicked mother called the police before Lily revealed it was all a joke by sending a photo of herself at home. While her mother was not amused by the cruel trick, the screenshots of their text conversation went viral on Twitter with 18,000 retweets and 25,000 favorites.

Sicily has become a "promised land" destination for thousands of destitute migrants and refugees making desperate journeys from North Africa to Europe's Mediterranean coast, with more than 10,000 people arriving from Libya since last weekend alone according to the Italian Coast Guard. The current migrant crisis differs from previous waves due to increased numbers and the absence of control from Libyan ports following Moammar Gadhafi's overthrow, as he had previously regulated migrant flows through agreements with Italy. Italy has struggled to manage the influx through various rescue operations like Mare Nostrum, but many migrants continue their journey to other European countries rather than remaining in Italy.

Sam Allardyce responded to West Ham co-owner David Sullivan's criticism that the team has been "exceedingly disappointing" by telling Sullivan not to judge the team based on their 2015 form alone. West Ham have picked up just 11 points in the Barclays Premier League since the turn of the year, but Allardyce argues the overall season has been successful as they've already surpassed last year's point total with seven games remaining. Allardyce emphasized that while recent results have been disappointing, the season as a whole should be considered "terrific" rather than being judged solely on their poor recent form.

The school exam season is nearly upon us, creating a nerve-jangling time for parents and children alike, as many youngsters dread the thought of sitting at a single desk with nothing but white paper and a ticking clock nearby. A new study by Edge Hill University found a direct link between exam anxiety and performance, showing that students who worry about their exams are more likely to achieve lower grades than those who are less anxious. To help students cope, experts recommend creating structured revision timetables, finding quiet study spaces free from distractions, using practice questions and revision aids like flashcards, while parents should actively engage by testing their children and ensuring they eat well and exercise regularly.

Edinburgh's European Challenge Cup hopes have been severely damaged after Scotland international centre Matt Scott was ruled out for the rest of the season following his second shoulder operation in a year. The 25-times-capped player, who hasn't played since injuring himself during Scotland's Six Nations match against Ireland last month, is now also doubtful for September's World Cup. Edinburgh will face Newport Gwent Dragons in the Challenge Cup semi-final at BT Murrayfield on Friday without their key centre, relying instead on less experienced players like Phil Burleigh and Andries Strauss.

The divorce between celebrity chef Bobby Flay, 50, and actress Stephanie March became more contentious after the New York Post's Page Six alleged on Sunday that Flay had been having a three-year affair with his 28-year-old assistant Elyse Tirrel. According to the report, March discovered the affair after Thanksgiving 2014, with a friend claiming she arrived "sobbing uncontrollably" upon learning about the relationship. Flay's business partner dismissed the allegations, while the chef's representatives suggested the claims were being used to renegotiate their prenuptial agreement amid their bitter divorce proceedings.

Emma Louise Connolly, known as the bombshell girlfriend of Made in Chelsea's Ollie Proudlock, shows off her incredible figure while modeling Ann Summers' first bridal wear lingerie collection. Billed by the brand as "perfect for every blushing bride," the underwear and loungewear collection comes in soft palettes of ivory and nude, priced between £14 and £85. This marks Ann Summers' first foray into bridal wear, expanding beyond their typical mainstream erotic lingerie offerings.

The UN's World Meteorological Organization removed "Isis" from the official list of future Pacific hurricane names on Friday, with the WMO Hurricane Committee deeming the name inappropriate due to its association with the ISIS militant group. While Isis was originally included as the name of an ancient Egyptian goddess for the 2016 hurricane season, the committee decided to replace it with "Ivette" because of the negative connotations with the terrorist organization that has captured territory in Iraq and Syria. The WMO spokeswoman announced the decision from Geneva, noting that names are typically removed from the rotating six-year list when they are considered inappropriate or have caused significant damage and death.

Game of Thrones fans who didn't want to wait to legally watch HBO's hit series leaked the first four episodes of season five online before tonight's scheduled premiere. Online pirates unveiled nearly half of the show's next season on torrent sites starting Saturday night, with the episodes believed to have originated from review copies given to the press. The leaked episodes had been downloaded more than 550,000 times by early Sunday morning, adding to Game of Thrones' status as the world's most illegally downloaded TV series.

A new ComRes poll reveals that more than half of UK voters (54%) do not want Nicola Sturgeon involved in the next British government, with 59% opposing any SNP role in running the country. This comes as Sturgeon launched the SNP's manifesto today, setting out demands including extra spending, an end to austerity, and scrapping Trident as the price for propping up a potential Labour government. Despite Sturgeon's promise of offering a "hand of friendship" to the rest of the UK, the poll shows the SNP is the least popular potential coalition partner among British voters.

Jeremy Scott's spring/summer 2015 Moschino collection caused an "Insta-stampede" and nearly broke the internet when he sent models down the Milan runway dressed as human Barbie dolls in bright pink leather and super girly dresses, with the designer famed for making kitsch cool positioning himself as the ultimate dictator of trends. To test whether the look works in real life, journalist Olivia Phillips wore the Barbie-inspired pieces around Dubai and found that while everyone smiled at her and she received positive attention, the outfits sparked conversations and nostalgia, proving the collection's mood-enhancing capabilities and perfect fit for our current Instagram-filtered existence.

Chelsea are planning a victory parade through the streets around Stamford Bridge should they stay on course to claim the Premier League title in May, with Jose Mourinho's side currently nine points clear at the summit of the table with six games remaining. Hammersmith and Fulham council has delivered letters to residents outlining the schedule for the planned celebrations, which would take place on May 25 if Chelsea wins the title. The parade would start at Stamford Bridge and travel through local streets, with the team facing Arsenal at the Emirates on Sunday as they continue their title push.

Jack Henry Doshay, 22, the troubled son of an influential San Diego businessman, was arrested last week for allegedly attempting to kidnap a 7-year-old girl from a local elementary school. Doshay appeared in court on Friday and pleaded not guilty to charges of kidnapping, false imprisonment with violence, and child cruelty after allegedly grabbing the girl at Skyline Elementary School and trying to cover her mouth with packing tape. The girl was freed when teachers and parents heard her screams for help, and Doshay faces up to 11 years in prison if convicted.

Sri Lanka's sports minister Navin Dissanayake asked batsman Kumar Sangakkara on Wednesday to reconsider his decision to retire from limited overs cricket and continue for another year. Sangakkara retired from one-day cricket on March 18 after Sri Lanka's World Cup quarter-final defeat to South Africa, having scored a record four successive centuries during the tournament. The 37-year-old will continue playing Tests and take up a contract with English county side Surrey this season.

Nicola Sturgeon declared that raising the retirement age is unfair to Scottish pensioners because they die younger than those in other parts of the UK, with the SNP demanding the retirement age be frozen in a move that would cost billions of pounds. This represents the latest price for the SNP's potential support in propping up Ed Miliband in Downing Street in the event of a hung Parliament. Sturgeon also called for the state pension to increase from £113 to at least £160 per week, citing Scotland's lower life expectancy rates compared to England and Wales.

Kentucky judge Olu Stevens is facing calls to be removed from office after he criticized a couple's victim impact statements during the sentencing of Gregory Wallace, who robbed their home and held their 3-year-old daughter at gunpoint before stealing $1,100 and other items. The judge accused the parents of fostering racist stereotypes in their daughter after they wrote that the child was now "in constant fear of black men," and he sentenced Wallace to five years' probation despite the family's request for prison time. Stevens defended his comments on Facebook, arguing that the parents were attributing their own racist views to their child, while the family and their supporters are calling for the judge to be removed from the bench.

While many people apologize to loved ones after arguments through conventional ways like romantic meals, chocolates, or flowers to win over an angry partner, one hapless Romeo or Juliet decided a public declaration was necessary. Mysterious handwritten cardboard signs with messages like "please forgive me," "I love you," and "we need to talk" appeared throughout the Surrey village of Milford, sparking local speculation about the identity of the lovelorn author. This follows a similar incident in Manchester where a man wore a sandwich board saying "I am sorry I lied" until his partner eventually appeared and walked off with him.

The families of five Chinese feminists who have been detained by police for over a month on charges of "picking quarrels and provoking trouble" have issued a plea to authorities for their release. The female activists were arrested the weekend before International Women's Day as they were preparing to distribute leaflets about sexual harassment on public transport, and now face up to five years in prison if formally charged. Their detention has sparked international condemnation, with the U.S., Britain, and the European Union calling for their release, prompting China to lodge formal protests against what it considers interference in its internal affairs.

More than 10,000 Australians and New Zealanders gathered in reverence on the shores of the Gallipoli peninsula for a formal ceremony to honour the diggers who fought and fell there a century ago. The vast sea of pilgrims attended the dawn service marking the 100th anniversary of the bloody Gallipoli landings, with Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott, New Zealand Prime Minister John Key, and British royals Prince Charles and Prince Harry in attendance. Similar commemorative services were also held at locations like the Delhi War Cemetery in New Delhi, as the world remembered the 130,000 men who died during the eight-month Gallipoli campaign that began on April 25, 1915.

Fernando Torres scored his first ever league own goal on Saturday when the Spanish striker inadvertently headed a corner at the near post over his own line, pulling Malaga back into the game just before half-time during Atletico Madrid's 2-2 draw. Torres has found goals difficult to come by since his January return to Atletico, having scored just four times for the club. Despite Antoine Griezmann scoring twice for Atletico, the match ended in a draw that kept Diego Simeone's side in third place.

Danny Lennon's interim appointment as Scotland Under 21 coach has officially ended, with reports claiming he will be named as Alloa Athletic boss on Tuesday. The former St Mirren manager has reportedly agreed to a deal to take charge of the Scottish Championship side until the summer of 2016. Lennon successfully managed Scotland's Under 21 team for one match, securing a 2-1 victory against Hungary last month before transitioning to club management.

The battered, rusted remains of a bus and train covered in overgrown weeds lie abandoned in the Great Smokey Mountains of North Carolina, where they were used to film one of Hollywood's most memorable action scenes from the 1993 film "The Fugitive." The unremarkable looking vehicles were part of the dramatic sequence where Harrison Ford's character escapes from a prison transport moments before it collided with an onrushing train, a scene that cost an eye-watering $1.5 million to shoot using real vehicles with minimal CGI. The wreckage has remained on location for over two decades and has since become a popular tourist attraction for fans of the film.

Greg Gibbins, a 28-year-old rugby player, was fatally stabbed outside a pizza store in the early hours of Easter Monday after spending the night with friends at The Beachcomber Hotel in Toukley, NSW. Police believe the "spontaneous" knife attack around midnight may have been related to an earlier incident where Mr Gibbins had helped a woman who was being harassed. A 20-year-old man, Bradley James Brooks, has been charged with murder in connection with what police described as an unprovoked attack on the "good citizen."

A new Reddit thread has garnered over 10,000 comments offering fascinating insights into the strange lives of men who have purchased mail-order brides from Russia and the Philippines. The discussion asked users to share what surprised them most about living with their spouses, revealing stories of lacking emotional connection, awkward social dynamics, and relationships that often felt transactional rather than romantic. Despite mixed and often troubling accounts from both sides, the mail-order bride business continues to boom with sites like Russianbrides.com boasting over one million users.

Joe Hart described Sunday's 4-2 defeat to Manchester United at Old Trafford as "one of my worst days in a Manchester City shirt," with the England goalkeeper appearing devastated after the final whistle. The morale-sapping derby loss left Manuel Pellegrini's side four points behind their rivals and effectively ended City's bid to retain their Premier League title, as they now sit 12 points behind leaders Chelsea. Hart acknowledged the team's dramatic decline in form since the new year and admitted City must now focus on securing third place rather than challenging for the title.

A Northern Territory mother, labourer Noeleen Foster, was lost for words when she spotted a phallic-shaped cloud during her work break last week above Zuccoli, 25km southeast of Darwin. Foster was thrilled to capture the suggestively shaped formation and said she couldn't believe her eyes, noting that "even mother nature has a sense of humour." While they say every cloud has a silver lining, this cloud certainly had an unusual outline that made it memorable for the mother of four.
