Loren Mathieson filmed her pet Boston Terrier, Gizmo, performing an impressive gravity-defying stunt at home after he tried on a new set of booties. The skillful pooch mastered the art of paw-stand walking, planting his front paws on the ground and walking forward on his front legs with his back legs in the air. The video of Gizmo's circus-like trick, which he performed because he was unsure how to walk in his new boots, has been viewed more than 80,000 times.

Porto enters their Champions League quarter-final first leg against Bayern Munich as the tournament's only undefeated side, but manager Julen Lopetegui has warned that his team still has plenty of room to improve, stating the team "hasn't stopped growing." The match will pit Lopetegui against his former Barcelona teammate Pep Guardiola in a clash between the two highest-scoring sides in the competition so far. Despite Porto's strong defensive record and clinical 4-0 victory over Basel in the last round, Lopetegui emphasizes that many new players are still meshing with the squad and the team continues to develop.

Nine-year-old schoolboy Frankie Franz successfully emulated Barcelona star Martin Montoya by scoring an audacious 27-yard goal into a basketball hoop, achieving the feat twice after watching the Spanish right-back pull off the same staggering trick shot in a viral video recorded at Barcelona's Ciutat Esportiva training ground earlier in the month. The young academy player with Dagenham and Redbridge Football Club managed to replicate Montoya's impressive shot on his first attempt, leaving himself and his family amazed by the achievement.

Financially-troubled CSKA Sofia's Latvian goalkeeper Maksims Uvarenko has not been paid for three months since joining the Bulgarian club on an 18-month contract in January, forcing him to ask his parents to send him money to pay his rent. Despite the severe financial problems affecting the debt-ridden club, which has issued desperate pleas to fans for emergency funding to avoid expulsion from Bulgaria's top division, Uvarenko remains impressed by CSKA's passionate supporters. The club has struggled financially since 2006 when former owner Vasil Bozhkov sold the team, leaving them with significant debts while still competing near the top of the Bulgarian league.

Pete Bennett, the 33-year-old Big Brother winner from Brighton who won £100,000 in 2006, revealed on the Jeremy Kyle show that fame and fortune from reality TV changed his life but not necessarily for the better. He admitted to squandering his prize money on the animal tranquilizer ketamine and is now homeless, spending nights sofa surfing. The article also provides updates on what happened to other Big Brother winners from the show's various seasons, showing how coming first can make or break contestants' careers and lives.

Parma pulled off the biggest surprise of the season as the crisis-hit club beat runaway leaders Juventus 1-0 in Serie A, inflicting only the second defeat of the campaign for Massimiliano Allegri's side. Jose Mauri scored the only goal of the game on the hour mark to secure the memorable victory for the bankrupt club that hasn't paid its players all season. Elsewhere in Italy, Inter Milan ended their seven-match winless run by beating Verona 3-0.

CNN reports on photographer Simon Brann Thorpe's "Toy Soldiers" project, which was driven by concerns about how images of war and conflict are splashed across desktops, plastered on TV screens, and scattered through mobile news feeds, causing people to become calloused and desensitized to such imagery through mainstream media outlets. Thorpe photographed real soldiers from the Polisario Front in Western Sahara posed like green plastic toy figurines against the desert landscape to create a fresh perspective on how we digest images of war. The project aims to raise questions about how war imagery will be consumed in the future amid ever-diminishing attention spans and increased competition for viewers' attention.

A seven-year-old boy was raped and set on fire by two youths in Bhiwandi, a suburb of Mumbai, after he went to buy food and was taken to an isolated place. When the boy resisted, the attackers set him on fire, causing 30 percent burns to his body, according to Inspector Sasthe. The boy managed to escape and is being treated at Thane Civil hospital while police investigate and work to identify the accused.

Jurgen Klopp, the 47-year-old coach, confirmed in an emotional press conference that he will leave Borussia Dortmund at the end of the season after seven years in charge, officially ceasing to be Dortmund manager on June 30 as he seeks a fresh start elsewhere. The announcement has put England's top clubs on alert, with Klopp being linked to several English teams including Manchester City and Liverpool, though he stated he has had no contact with other clubs yet. Klopp said he believed Dortmund needs a change of manager next season, making the announcement before joining his players for a training session.

Father-of-three Sean McCabe got devastating news that he had just two months to live and set about organising his funeral, choosing music to be played and even writing a goodbye letter for his partner Lisa Williams to read to their kids. However, after making a remarkable recovery, his cancer went into remission and he changed his church reservation - the same venue he had rebooked for his funeral is now where he plans to marry Lisa Williams, surrounded by their three children.

An eight-year-old boy died a day after his family's car hurtled off the road into a Los Angeles harbor, while his 13-year-old brother Abdelkrim Elmezayen was pulled dead from the water at the scene shortly after 6pm on Thursday. The boys' parents survived the incident and are in stable condition at the hospital. The cause of the accident remains under investigation, with authorities uncertain whether it was accidental or intentional.

Qatar significantly expanded its London real estate empire this week by acquiring a majority stake in Coroin, the company that owns luxury hotels including Claridge's, The Berkeley, and The Connaught, adding to an impressive portfolio that includes The Shard, Harrods, and Canary Wharf as illustrated on maps of the city. The Gulf state, which owns more London property than the Crown Estate, also holds stakes in major British companies like Sainsbury's and British Airways owner IAG, while the Qatari royal family is converting three properties in Regent's Park into what will become the UK's first £200million home and their own British palace in the capital.

Akon Guode, a 35-year-old Sudanese mother, has been released from custody after being interviewed by police as part of an ongoing investigation into the deaths of three children when her car crashed into a lake near Melbourne. The incident occurred when Guode's Toyota Kluger plunged into the water at Wyndham Vale, killing one-year-old Bol and four-year-old twins Madit and Anger, while a five-year-old girl survived and remains hospitalized. Police are continuing their investigation to determine whether the crash was deliberate or accidental, with the children's father defending Guode as a "good mother" who loved her children.

Scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology claim that computer keyboards could be a powerful new tool in the battle against Parkinson's disease, as researchers believe a person's keystrokes may reveal a huge amount of information about their motor skills. The team is working on creating technology that can tell doctors if someone has the neuron impairment by analyzing typing patterns, specifically measuring "key hold time" - how long keys are pressed before being released. Preliminary results from studies of about two dozen Parkinson's patients suggest their algorithm can distinguish between people who have the disease and those who don't, potentially enabling much earlier diagnosis than current methods allow.

Raheem Sterling moved closer to leaving Liverpool after revealing in a BBC interview on Wednesday night that he is not ready to sign a new £100,000-a-week contract, admitting he would have signed for "a lot less" a year ago. The 20-year-old said it was "quite flattering" to be linked with Arsenal, whom Liverpool face on Saturday in the Premier League, in an in-depth TV discussion that the club knew nothing about until it was aired. Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers responded by insisting Sterling will not leave in the summer and that the interview was conducted without the club's permission, surprising everyone at the club.

Stoke City manager Mark Hughes has dismissed recent reports linking goalkeeper Asmir Begovic with a move to Real Madrid, calling the speculation untrue despite fresh claims from Spain suggesting talks had opened between the clubs. Hughes remains optimistic that the 27-year-old Bosnia international, whose contract expires in 2016, will sign a new deal with Stoke this summer, with negotiations scheduled for the coming weeks. The manager acknowledged that speculation is inevitable around quality players but emphasized his hope that Begovic will remain at the Britannia Stadium.

Aston Villa defeated Tottenham Hotspur 1-0 at White Hart Lane, with Christian Benteke scoring the decisive goal in the 35th minute of the first half, continuing his excellent form after netting a hat-trick in Tuesday's 3-3 draw with Queens Park Rangers. Villa manager Tim Sherwood celebrated ecstatically without his trademark gilet, savoring victory against the club that sacked him last summer, as his team took a crucial step toward Premier League survival. The match saw several players booked including Tottenham's Bentaleb and Rose, with Villa's Carlos Sanchez sent off late in the game, but Sherwood's tactical approach proved effective in securing three vital points.

Gerard T. "The Frenchman" Ouimette, a 75-year-old former mob enforcer from Rhode Island with ties to late New England crime boss Raymond L.S. Patriarca, died in a federal prison in North Carolina according to the Federal Bureau of Prison's website. Ouimette, who was suspected of having a role in up to eight murders and controlled a criminal network involved in gambling, loansharking, and extortion, had been serving a life sentence since 1996 under the federal "three strikes" provision and spent a total of 46 years behind bars. He died in his sleep after being recently diagnosed with lung cancer at the medium-security facility in Butner, North Carolina.

After helping Sale Sharks to a 23-6 victory against Gloucester last Saturday, where Danny Cipriani contributed 13 points from the boot, the fly-half has taken advantage of a rare free weekend from rugby by jetting off to Dubai for a short break. Cipriani, who made impressive cameos for England against Italy, Scotland and France during the Six Nations, will return to action on April 12 when Sale face London Irish as they look to secure a top-six finish in the Aviva Premiership.

Owen Farrell hopes to be in contention for Saracens' European Champions Cup semi-final against Clermont Auvergne on April 18, after being out of action since suffering a knee ligament injury against the same opponents in January. Farrell missed the entire RBS 6 Nations as a result, with George Ford filling the number 10 shirt in accomplished fashion for England. The fly-half is hoping to be fit for the semi-final, saying his knee is feeling good after completing full training including running, kicking, and tackling.

Officer Michael Slager, 33, is being held in isolation at Charleston County jail after being charged with murder for shooting Walter Scott, 50, during a traffic stop in North Charleston, South Carolina on Saturday. Slager is housed in a room with one small window and has no interaction with other detainees, with the entire cell block being cleared whenever he needs to be moved due to safety concerns. The case has drawn national attention after video footage showed Slager shooting Scott in the back as he ran away following the traffic stop over a broken tail light.

Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino believes goalkeeper Michel Vorm has the strength of character to put his Capital One Cup final disappointment behind him and prove an able deputy for the injured Hugo Lloris when Spurs face Burnley at Turf Moor on Sunday. The 31-year-old Dutchman will stand in for France international Lloris, who is sidelined with a knee injury, despite having been benched for the League Cup final at Wembley after playing in earlier rounds. Pochettino praised Vorm's professional attitude and expressed confidence in his ability to perform when called upon.

An Uber customer named Jaime Hessel was hit with a huge $16,000 bill for her 7-mile nightmare journey across New York boroughs, during which she said her driver was on his phone, cut across lanes, and even driven down a bus lane during the 35-minute trip from her East Williamsburg apartment to Midtown East. After initially receiving a normal $56.40 bill and complaining about the inefficient route, Hessel was shocked to receive a follow-up email stating she owed over $16,000, which Uber later said was a clerical error and that she was never actually charged the outrageous sum.

A cloud formation resembling the Wi-Fi symbol recently appeared in the sky over Xiangtan city in central China's Hunan Province, with locals joking that Mother Nature was lending a helping hand to those wanting to get online but lacking wifi coverage. The unusual cloud, which perfectly mimicked the global Wi-Fi symbol with one dot and three curved lines, was photographed by a university student and quickly went viral on Chinese social media. Chinese internet users shared thousands of comments about what could be the world's largest "Wi-Fi cloud," with some joking about the password and coverage area of "God's router."

Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere was left starstruck when he met Brazil legend Pele at a launch party on Thursday evening, despite regularly rubbing shoulders with stars like Alexis Sanchez and Mesut Ozil on a daily basis. Wilshere was given the opportunity to interview the three-time World Cup winner during the 10Ten Talent launch event, sharing photos and updates about the meeting on Twitter. During the interview, Pele discussed Brazil's "disaster" performance at the 2014 World Cup, calling their 7-1 semi-final defeat to Germany something that "nobody can explain," while praising Brazilian Premier League players like Oscar and Ramires for bouncing back this season.

Italy is coping with a rising wave of desperate migrants from Africa and the Middle East hoping to make it to Europe, with a total of 8,480 migrants rescued from Friday to Monday according to the Italian coast guard. On Tuesday, Save the Children told CNN that 400 migrants could be missing after survivors reported their ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea about 80 miles off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard has not yet confirmed this incident. At least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of 2015, with Italy registering more than 10,000 migrant arrivals in the first three months of the year.

Saracens flanker Jacques Burger has been cited for alleged foul play during last Sunday's European Champions Cup quarter-final match against Racing Metro in Paris, which Saracens won dramatically 12-11 at Stade Yves-du-Manoir. European Professional Club Rugby announced that Burger is accused of striking Racing scrum-half Maxime Machenaud, following a complaint made by match citing commissioner Eugene Ryan. The 31-year-old Namibia international will face a disciplinary hearing on Thursday and could face a ban ranging from two weeks to 52 weeks depending on the severity of the offense.

Chile's Calbuco Volcano erupted for the third time since last week on Thursday, according to the National Service of Geology and Mining, though a local resident who has been documenting the eruptions described Thursday's event as spectacular but less severe than the two prior ones. The eruption prompted the evacuation of about 1,500 people and maintained a 20-kilometer exclusion zone around the crater, while authorities continued security measures as part of ongoing contingency plans. This marks the most significant volcanic activity in the region since the last major eruption in 1962, with ash spreading across the area and reaching Argentina during previous eruptions.

Six people - five men and one woman - were arrested at Dover port at approximately 8am on suspicion of Syria-related terrorism offences, according to West Midlands Police. The suspects, including four men in their 20s from Birmingham, were detained in the departure zone of the south coast port and are currently being questioned at a West Midlands police station. The arrests come a day after nine Britons were detained in Turkey for allegedly trying to cross into Syria, though police have not confirmed whether the two cases are linked.

Vincent Nogueira scored in stoppage time to give Philadelphia Union their first Major League Soccer victory of the season, beating New York City FC 2-1 on Saturday. The winning goal came in the 92nd minute when NYC goalkeeper Josh Saunders collided with Conor Casey inside the 6-yard box while defending a cross, allowing Nogueira to toe-poke the ball home. In other Saturday MLS action, the New York Red Bulls drew 2-2 with DC United after Lloyd Sam's 90th-minute equalizer.

A British evangelical preacher, Eric Isaiah Adusah, 28, is being held on suspicion of murdering his pregnant wife Charmain Adusah, 41, whose body was found face down in a hotel bathtub in Ghana after lying there for four days. According to local reports, the couple had argued during their stay, and Adusah allegedly left the hotel hurriedly on the day she is believed to have died, telling hotel managers his wife was ill and didn't want to be disturbed before flying back to London. The couple had married in September following a whirlwind romance, and Adusah later returned to Ghana where he was arrested after hotel staff discovered his wife's decomposed body.

Ethan Czahor, a former aide to Jeb Bush who was fired for posting offensive tweets, has developed an app called 'Clear' that helps users identify and remove social media posts that might cause problems with current or future employers. The app uses IBM's Watson supercomputer to analyze tweets through sentiment analysis and provides users with a safety rating between 0 and 100, allowing them to delete potentially problematic content before it can harm their careers. Czahor created the app after his own experience of being dismissed from his role as chief technology officer for Bush's potential 2016 presidential campaign due to sexist and homophobic remarks he had posted on Twitter.

Justin Rose plans to follow Rory McIlroy's example of summer success after kickstarting his season with a second-place finish at the Masters, posting 14-under-par despite having missed the cut in three of his previous five PGA Tour tournaments. Rose arrived at Augusta National struggling for form but left with renewed confidence and enthusiasm, hoping to emulate McIlroy's 2014 summer winning streak during the upcoming major championship season from April to September.

An unidentified college student managed to get away without any kind of punishment after cops caught her drinking underage at a Texas music festival because she beat them at a game of Rock Paper Scissors. A video posted on social media site Vine by a user known as Old Row shows the girl facing three officers who challenged her to the game, which she won by choosing "rock" while one officer chose "scissors." The clip has been viewed over 500,000 times since being posted, with many commenting on the unusual leniency of the officers at the notoriously strict Chilifest festival.

Police are desperately searching for 14-year-old Sally Gordon-Smith, a teenage schoolgirl who went missing near Melbourne on Friday afternoon after being last seen leaving her school in Keilor East around 3pm. Victoria Police described her as caucasian, 150cm tall, with blue eyes and brown shoulder-length hair, wearing blue jeans, a black jumper and black shoes. Police confirmed she was still missing early Saturday morning and expressed concern due to her age, with her family and authorities appealing for anyone with information to contact them immediately.

Crystal Palace manager Alan Pardew insists he is not interested in raiding his former club Newcastle for goalkeeper Tim Krul and is disappointed that reports emerged suggesting he was planning such a move. Pardew, who took over at Palace in January and led them away from the relegation zone, is planning a busy summer in the transfer market but maintains he is happy with current goalkeeper Julian Speroni and has had no contact with Newcastle or Krul regarding a potential transfer.

British photographer John Daniels, 61, with decades of experience working with animals, has captured adorable images of puppies and other young animals using clean white studio backgrounds and comedy props. The photographer also experiments with unusual animal pairings to create charming photographs that celebrate National Pet Day. John said he prefers using his studio over outdoor shoots due to unpredictable British weather and past cancellations, as the controlled environment prevents animals from escaping or being frightened by the big outdoors.

Hilary Border, a 54-year-old mother-of-three, stole £20,000 from her 83-year-old dementia-stricken mother instead of using the money to pay £300-a-week care home fees. Care home staff reported her to police after two years of unpaid debts, despite the fact that prosecutors alleged she actually took £39,500. Border was sentenced to 16 months in prison, suspended for two years, after pleading guilty to the fraud.

David Suchet, best known as the star of TV series Poirot, looks every inch the proud grandfather as he cuddles his beautiful baby grandson Todd, but behind the smiles he is battling hard to help the little boy face the future with an incurable genetic disease called Tuberous Sclerosis Complex. The actor has criticized NHS "disorganization" for preventing his grandson from accessing potentially helpful treatments and has launched a campaign called #Fight4Treatment to advocate for better access to rare disease medications. Despite the challenges, Suchet remains hopeful about finding ways to manage his grandson's condition, which was diagnosed when Todd was just a few weeks old after he began having seizures.

Yorkshire have signed India international Cheteshwar Pujara until the end of May after cancelling the contract of Younis Khan, who was originally set to be Yorkshire's overseas signing for 2015. The Pakistani batsman is now looking to be part of Pakistan's potential touring party to Bangladesh, which would rule him out of county championship playing time. Pujara, a highly-rated Test cricketer with six centuries, will fill the role temporarily until Australian Aaron Finch becomes available after his Indian Premier League commitments.

US Army Staff Sgt. Julian McDonald welcomed 4-year-old Layka, a heroic Belgian Malinois army dog, into his Columbus, Ohio home this week after fighting for two years to adopt her. Layka lost her entire front leg after being shot four times at point-blank range while clearing a Taliban compound during patrol in Afghanistan in 2012, where she saved McDonald and his team's lives. McDonald felt obligated to give Layka a new home with his family, saying she was the reason he was able to return alive to his wife and son.

For years medical experts and the American Heart Association have warned that excess salt consumption contributes to the deaths of tens of thousands of Americans annually, but new research is now questioning this conventional wisdom and warning instead about the dangers of consuming too little salt. A major study published in the New England Journal of Medicine found that people who follow current recommended salt limits (2,300 milligrams) actually experience more heart trouble, with researchers arguing that low sodium intake may stimulate harmful hormone production. While the average American consumes about 3,500 milligrams of salt daily—well above current guidelines—salt skeptics believe healthy people can safely consume up to 6,000 milligrams per day and that intake below 3,000 milligrams may actually raise health risks.

US lawmakers revealed on Tuesday that DEA agents in Colombia were participating in alleged sex parties with prostitutes funded by drug cartels as early as 2001, years earlier than previously known. The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform released a DEA report summary describing "literally dozens of parties with prostitutes" involving several agents in Bogota, with some agents admitting to the misconduct and receiving suspensions of only 2-10 days. This revelation follows a separate March report that found at least 7 DEA agents admitted to sleeping with prostitutes during overseas assignments between 2005-2008, raising significant security concerns about the agency's conduct abroad.

A 36-year-old Louisiana sheriff's deputy, Cpl. Burt Hazeltine of St. Charles Parish, was shot three times in the face, elbow, and eye while directing traffic in a school zone on US 90 near Louisiana Street in Paradis, just west of New Orleans, Thursday morning. The shooting stemmed from a road rage incident after 56-year-old Paul Devillier, a former TSA worker, became angry that the deputy refused to stop traffic to allow him to make a turn. Hazeltine was hospitalized in stable but guarded condition and may lose sight in one eye, while Devillier was arrested shortly after the ambush.

Lord Janner signed a letter expressing his desire to remain a peer in the House of Lords just one week before being ruled unfit to face child sex charges due to dementia. Abuse campaigners have angrily questioned how the suspected paedophile could be considered well enough to continue as a legislator while being deemed too frail to be brought before court. The controversy has intensified criticism of the Crown Prosecution Service's decision not to prosecute Janner over 22 sexual offences against children, despite having sufficient evidence for charges.

Turkey blocked access to Twitter and YouTube after the platforms refused a Turkish court's request to remove pictures of prosecutor Mehmet Selim Kiraz, who was held hostage and killed during an armed siege by far-left militants last week. The Turkish court imposed the blocks because the images shared on social media "deeply upset" the prosecutor's wife and children, according to officials who said the platforms failed to respond to removal requests.

David and Victoria Beckham have won a planning battle against their next-door neighbour over proposals to install air-conditioning in five rooms of their £31.5 million west London mansion, including their luxury gym and large wine cellar. While one neighbour was furious about the plans, claiming they would affect the historic character of the Victorian street, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council approved the proposals after determining the air-conditioning would have minimal impact on the Grade II listed building. The A-list couple are currently restoring the Holland Park property, which they purchased in 2013, and it is expected to be worth £42 million when completed.

California Governor Jerry Brown ordered a 25 percent overall cutback in water use by cities and towns on Wednesday, as the state faces its fourth summer of drought with no relief in sight. Photos taken on Saturday show the ongoing drought is already taking its toll on California's once-Technicolor landscape of lush yards, emerald golf courses, and aquamarine swimming pools. The mandatory restrictions come after voluntary conservation efforts yielded only mixed results, with some affluent Southern California communities using over 300 gallons per person daily compared to 70 gallons in some Bay Area communities.

Universal's "Furious 7," the final film from the late Paul Walker, is expected to make history by grossing $115 million or more during its opening weekend at the North American box office, which would be the top showing ever for an April title. The film is getting the widest release in Universal's history with roughly 4,003 theaters and is poised to achieve the biggest opening of 2015 to date. Production was halted in November 2013 when Walker died in a car crash, but resumed in April 2014 with CGI and voice effects used to complete his scenes.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, 27, is experiencing his accepted trend of struggling in the second half of the season, with his form significantly dropping from earlier when he looked set to break the Premier League assists record. Despite expressing happiness about playing regularly in England and Chelsea's likely success with a Capital One Cup win and Premier League title race position, Fabregas has managed just one assist in his last five games after a brilliant start to the season. His poor form continued in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland, raising concerns about his durability as Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho seeks to guide the team over the line in the title race.

Victims of a horrific medical experiment conducted by the United States in Guatemala from 1945 to 1956, in which individuals were deliberately infected with syphilis to test drugs and study the disease, are now suing Johns Hopkins University in a $1 billion lawsuit with 750 plaintiffs including victims and their families. The experiment, led by Dr. John Cutler, infected approximately 700 people including children, orphans, soldiers, prisoners, and mental patients, with many victims dying from the disease or passing it to their children who were born with severe disabilities. The lawsuit claims Johns Hopkins officials approved, planned, and monitored the study, though the university denies involvement and calls the suit an attempt to "exploit a historic tragedy for monetary gain."

Hip-hop star Nelly, the 40-year-old rapper from St. Louis who shot to fame 15 years ago, was arrested on drug charges in Tennessee after a state trooper pulled over the private bus in which he was traveling, authorities said according to CNN. The trooper initially stopped the bus for missing transportation stickers but then detected marijuana odor, leading to a search that uncovered methamphetamine, marijuana, drug paraphernalia, and several handguns including a gold-plated .50-caliber Desert Eagle pistol. Nelly was charged with felony drug possession and other related charges, but later posted bond and was released from jail.

A Japanese woman got sweet revenge on her cheating boyfriend by submerging his entire Apple collection, including an iMac, iPhone, iPad, and accessories, in a bathtub filled with water. The unnamed heartbroken girlfriend knew exactly how to hit her lying lover where it hurts most, photographing the gadget "Jacuzzi" and sending the images to him. The boyfriend then tweeted the photos, which were retweeted over 15,400 times, with mixed reactions from users - some supporting the woman's creative revenge while others felt destroying expensive electronics was too harsh.

Jurgen Klopp conceded that Bayern Munich were the better team after they defeated his Borussia Dortmund side 1-0 on Saturday in a Bundesliga clash at the Westfalenstadion. Robert Lewandowski scored the winning goal against his former club, as the hosts struggled to create chances throughout the match. The charismatic Dortmund manager admitted his team "lacked punch" and deserved to lose, though captain Mats Hummels disagreed with Klopp's assessment of the performance.

President Barack Obama became the first American president to visit Jamaica since Ronald Reagan in 1982, receiving enthusiastic crowds and cheers across the country on Thursday. Jamaican Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller expressed her love for Obama and told him he was very popular in Jamaica, while also requesting that he consider exonerating black nationalist leader Marcus Garvey. Obama then traveled to Panama for the Summit of the Americas, where he signaled he would soon remove Cuba from the U.S. list of state sponsors of terrorism ahead of his historic meeting with Cuban President Raul Castro.

In his traditional Easter Mass address, Pope Francis called for an end to violence and bloodshed in conflict zones around the world, specifically mentioning Iraq, Syria, Ukraine, Yemen, Nigeria, South Sudan, Kenya, and Libya. The Pope also addressed economic oppression and exploitation by criminal groups, drug dealers, corrupt officials, and arms dealers, while calling for resumed peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. He concluded his "urbi et orbi" (to the city and world) speech by offering consolation to the marginalized, poor, sick, and suffering.

Russian supermodel Irina Shayk, 29, stars in a steamy new campaign for Linda Farrow eyewear where she poses in swimsuits and is filmed writhing around a pool with hunky male model Jarrod Scott. The shoot comes after Shayk split from footballer Cristiano Ronaldo in January after five years together, saying she felt "ugly standing next to the wrong man." The behind-the-scenes video shows the newly-single model looking stunning in plunging metallic swimsuits while modeling the brand's SS15 sunglasses collection.

Polish prince Janek Zylinski, the aristocratic son of a Polish war hero who fought the Nazis in 1939, has challenged Ukip leader Nigel Farage to a sword duel in Hyde Park over his anti-immigration stance. Brandishing his sword in an online video, Mr Zylinski said "Enough is enough, Mr Farage" and declared he would like to challenge him to resolve their differences with swords, though he offered a "duel of words" as an alternative. The prince, who lives in Ealing, West London, said he had "had enough of the discrimination against Polish people in this country" and cited Farage's blame of migrants for traffic jams as particularly idiotic.

The Calbuco volcano in southern Chile erupted twice in spectacular fashion, sending ash and lava over six miles into the air and covering nearby towns like Puerto Varas in thick layers of abrasive soot, forcing the evacuation of 4,000 people. Emergency officials were caught off guard as the volcano, one of Chile's most dangerous, had not been under special observation before suddenly springing to life, with residents reporting seeing columns of smoke rising from their windows. A volcanologist from Oxford University stated it is impossible to predict what will happen next, noting that previous eruptions at Calbuco have continued for up to a week.

Dani Alves posted a picture of himself with his trousers down on his Instagram account on Thursday, amid conflicting messages from the player's camp and Barcelona about his contract situation. With his Barcelona contract expiring on June 30, there are different versions emerging about renewal terms - Barcelona claims they offered a two-year deal while Alves' camp says it's only a one-year deal with conditional extensions. Manchester United has reportedly made him a three-year offer, though Alves appears to prefer staying in Barcelona where his children live, hoping the club will improve their offer given their FIFA transfer ban prevents them from signing replacements.

Kate Temple, a 33-year-old hairdresser dubbed the "Ear biter," was jailed for 20 months after admitting to inflicting grievous bodily harm by ripping off a chunk of another woman's ear with her teeth during an argument at a charity hog roast party. The attack occurred after victim Shelley Williams called Temple a "homewrecker" and accused her of having an affair with her partner, leading to a scuffle that left Williams covered in blood and requiring reconstructive surgery. Temple initially denied the attack but later pleaded guilty, with the judge noting that she left the victim with a permanent disability caused by using her teeth as a weapon.

Jenson Button believes McLaren has made significant progress after their improved performance in Malaysia, where they were able to race competitively with other midfield cars like Force India, Sauber, and Lotus, despite both drivers retiring from the race. Button expressed satisfaction that McLaren can now fight with other cars in the pack rather than being stuck at the back, though he acknowledges the team still has much work to do with both downforce and the Honda power unit ahead of the Chinese Grand Prix.

Claudia Martins, a 33-year-old mother-of-five, has been convicted of manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility for killing her newborn baby daughter by suffocating her with toilet paper stuffed in her mouth. Martins gave birth alone at her sister's flat in Bristol, keeping the pregnancy secret, then wrapped the baby's body in towels and hid it in a suitcase for three days before it was discovered. She was acquitted of murder but convicted of the lesser charge, with the court noting she has an extremely low IQ.

AP McCoy's mount Mr Mole has been installed as one of three 7-2 co-favourites for Saturday's Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, bracketed alongside Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, with the Paul Nicholls-trained Mr Mole being the same horse that McCoy rode to victory at Newbury in February when he ironically announced his retirement from professional racing.

A woman who cannot swim frantically struggled to stay afloat after tumbling from a punt in Cambridge when her boat collided with another vessel, with terror clearly visible on her face as she disappeared under the water several times before being rescued by her friends. The incident occurred on Saturday as Britain experienced its hottest day of the year so far, with temperatures reaching nearly 21°C, prompting families to flock to parks, beaches, and waterways to enjoy the unseasonably warm Easter weather.

The article discusses how Jason Holder's performance in Antigua and Marlon Samuels' century demonstrate the discipline and character that new West Indies coach Phil Simmons is trying to instill in his team's culture, similar to how Mike Atherton inspired others with his famous batting performances against Allan Donald and in Johannesburg. The author argues that while West Indies are losing players to the lucrative Indian Premier League, Test cricket provides far greater satisfaction and mental challenges than shorter formats, and that Simmons is building a foundation of pride and discipline that will help the team stay competitive in five-day matches.

North Charleston police are facing growing accusations that officer Michael Slager would have gotten away with covering up his fatal shooting of Walter Scott if not for bystander video that emerged, as questions arise about his colleagues' conduct after the incident. Seven fellow officers responded to Slager's call for backup after he shot the handcuffed Scott five times in the back, but their subsequent reports claiming they administered CPR contradict the video evidence, which only shows them checking his pulse and standing over his body. The discrepancies between the officers' official accounts and what the video actually shows have led to allegations of a potential police cover-up that would have succeeded without the witness footage.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's hit song "La Vida Loca" video, denied reports that she tried to take her own life and told her followers on Instagram that she was instead treated in a Milan hospital after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Italian media had reported that Moric attempted suicide and was found by her mother in her luxury apartment, but she clarified that she suffered a domestic accident on Saturday night when she fell and hit her head. Moric reassured her fans that she was recovering at home and only needed rest, expressing shock at the suicide claims made about her.

Patrice Evra believes Juventus used quintessential Italian traits to secure their route to the Champions League semi-finals, describing the Serie A side's defeat of Monaco as "ugly" but effective. Massimiliano Allegri's team secured a 0-0 draw at the Stade Louis II on Wednesday night, meaning they progressed 1-0 on aggregate to reach their first Champions League semi-final since 2002-03. Evra praised Juventus's solid, defensive Italian style of play while suggesting French teams like Monaco and PSG need to adopt a more aggressive mentality to succeed at the highest level.

What started as a sweet family moment during a day trip to the Nebraska zoo turned frightening when a little girl began beating her chest at a gorilla while safely separated by a pane of glass. The massive Silverback gorilla at Omaha's Henry Doorley Zoo was less amused by the playful gesture and charged at the glass with such force that it cracked upon impact. The terrified family fled to safety, and the incident, which was captured on video and uploaded to YouTube, has since garnered over 126,000 views.

Classic FM presenter John Suchet is mourning the death of his wife Bonnie, who died peacefully on April 15, 2015, at age 73 following a decade-long battle with dementia. Suchet, who once described their relationship as "made in heaven," had been open about his wife's illness and the toll it took on their marriage, becoming an advocate for dementia awareness and serving as honorary president of Dementia UK charity. The broadcaster had cared for Bonnie himself for three years before she was moved to residential care, and he had recently begun a new relationship with a woman named Nula, who also has a spouse with dementia.

Ben and Shelby Offrink, a married couple from Michigan with two young daughters, are both battling rare and aggressive cancers simultaneously - Shelby has an intramedullary glioblastoma that has spread from her spine to her brain and left her paralyzed, while Ben's Hodgkin's lymphoma has returned after 15 years in remission. Despite receiving prognoses of six months for Shelby and one year for Ben, the couple refuses to give up hope and is seeking access to clinical trials and advanced cancer centers like Harvard or Mayo Clinic that might offer better treatment options than what's available in Michigan. Their community has rallied around them with tremendous support, including international care packages and fundraisers, as they continue fighting for their lives and their children's future.

After Real Madrid scored nine goals against Granada at the weekend, their attacking prowess is clearly not misfiring at present, but this success has created an enviable dilemma for boss Carlo Ancelotti. Spanish papers report that Ancelotti now faces the challenge of trying to fit seven star players into six attacking and midfield spots in his preferred 4-3-3 formation, with all of Isco, Kroos, Modric, James Rodriguez, Bale, Benzema, and Cristiano Ronaldo available for selection. The abundance of talent means one player will inevitably be left out of the starting line-up, with James Rodriguez reportedly favored over Isco due to his superior statistics this season.

Floyd Mayweather, 38, took time out from his training preparations to pose for a picture with Motown legend Gladys Knight at his gym, just four days before his highly anticipated Fight of the Century against Manny Pacquiao at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas on May 2. Knight tweeted about meeting "the champ" and thanked him for the visit, while Mayweather is expected to earn £120m from what is being called the biggest event in boxing history.

Ed Miliband, who has long struggled to convince voters that he is a suitable choice for prime minister, has hired a leadership coaching firm called ExtendedMind to help overcome anxiety and find his 'inner voice'. The consultants drafted by the Labour leader claim to work with politicians to build 'leadership skills' using 'neuroscience' and 'business psychology', offering services including coaching on how to look 'authentic' and tutorials on building alliances. This comes despite Miliband already employing former Obama adviser David Axelrod on a six-figure salary, as he continues to lag behind David Cameron in personal rating polls.

Raymond Townsend, a married manager at US Limousine on Long Island, New York, was found liable for sexual harassment after firing employee Geralyn Ganci for refusing to have sex with him, even sending her a text message stating she lost her job because she "refused to have sex with the General Manager." The harassment continued for over a year with explicit messages and unwanted advances, despite Ganci sitting near Townsend's wife in their office. A judge ordered Townsend and the company to pay more than $700,000 in damages and compensation to Ganci after she won the civil rights lawsuit.

Bayern Munich playmaker Thiago made his first appearance in over a year when he came on as a substitute against Borussia Dortmund on Saturday, marking an emotional return after suffering a serious knee injury in March 2014. The Spanish midfielder thanked the German club, coaches, teammates, and fans for their support during his recovery, stating that seeing the fans' emotional reaction reminded him that "football is my life." Though admitting he's not yet ready for 90 minutes of play, Thiago expressed his happiness to be back and his continued goal of winning games and titles for Bayern Munich.

David Cameron today accused the BBC of peddling "b*******" after presenter Andrew Marr incorrectly claimed during a Sunday interview that the Prime Minister had said foxhunting was his favorite sport. The Tory leader hit back at Marr, who later admitted his mistake on Twitter, saying Cameron was left baffled by the erroneous questions during the interview. This came as Cameron turned the clock back to emulate John Major's election campaign style by climbing on a wooden pallet to address party supporters, though he was heckled by someone claiming "the NHS is dying."

CNN reports that Gwyneth Paltrow, the actress turned lifestyle guru known for promoting detoxes and health cleanses on her site Goop.com, is bringing awareness to the difficulties of living on food stamps. In a Friday tweet, Paltrow showcased an array of leafy greens, dried beans and rice that she purchased for under $30 as part of the #FoodBankNYCChallenge, which asks participants to live on a food stamp budget of $29 for one week. The challenge aims to raise public awareness about the struggles families face affording food on food stamps, especially following recent cuts to the program.

Dozens of staff at Manchester United's Megastore, including mascot Fred the Red, are uncertain about their job security as Nike's agreement with the club expires on July 31, coinciding with United's world-record £750m kit deal with Adidas taking effect. Nike currently employs Fred and numerous other workers at the Old Trafford shop, but staff claim they are being kept in the dark about potential re-employment under the new arrangement. While Nike states they are in consultation with employees and communicating with the club about the transition, many worried staff members are reportedly earning little more than minimum wage and some have already left due to the uncertainty.

Liverpool edged past Blackburn Rovers in their FA Cup sixth round replay to reach their 24th Cup semi-final in the Anfield club's illustrious history. Philippe Coutinho eventually broke the deadlock after 161 goalless minutes across the two games, though Blackburn came close to levelling matters when their goalkeeper Simon Eastwood was denied a dramatic equalizer in stoppage time.

A heart-warming video created by Pandora for Mother's Day shows six real-life children who are blindfolded and asked to identify their mothers from a group of six women using only touch and scent. The sweet youngsters move tentatively along the row, touching hands, hair, and faces until they successfully recognize and embrace their own mothers, demonstrating the unique bond between mother and child. The emotional video has gone viral with 2.8 million views and even caught the attention of celebrities like Ashton Kutcher.

Salford assistant coach Ian Watson is poised to come out of playing retirement at age 38 to answer an SOS from the Red Devils, whose last game was as player-coach in the Championship for Swinton last June. Watson has stepped up his training as Salford faces a severe player shortage with four players suspended and multiple others injured. If he plays against Castleford on Sunday, Watson would become the oldest current Super League player.

21-year-old Jordan Spieth took first-day honors at the 79th Masters with a stunning opening round of 64, becoming the youngest first-round leader in Masters history and holding a three-shot lead going into day two. On a spectacular day of scoring at sun-baked Augusta National, Spieth's brilliant performance included six birdies in seven holes and a 25-foot birdie putt on the 18th, marking a victory for golf's future over its past and present. Other notable performances included Justin Rose, Ernie Els, and Charley Hoffman all shooting 67, while favorites like Rory McIlroy and defending champion Bubba Watson posted respectable but distant scores of 71.

England captain Alastair Cook must block out the distracting turmoil surrounding English cricket, including Paul Downton's dismissal and Kevin Pietersen speculation, to concentrate on what has become one of the most important Test series of his career. Defeat against the West Indies in the three-Test series beginning Monday would be unthinkable for Cook, who desperately needs to avoid being distracted by the seismic changes happening around him. With both Cook and coach Peter Moores under pressure, they cannot afford any slip-ups in what should be England's least challenging assignment in their demanding 17-Test schedule over the next nine months.

The Pentagon announced Tuesday that it would exhume and attempt to identify the remains of nearly 400 sailors and Marines killed when the USS Oklahoma sank during the December 7, 1941 Pearl Harbor attack, after the ship capsized from being hit by nine Japanese torpedoes. The servicemen have been buried as unknowns at Hawaii's National Memorial Cemetery of the Pacific since 1950, but advances in forensic science and DNA technology now make identification possible. Officials plan to begin the exhumation work within three to six weeks and aim to identify up to 388 servicemen within five years, providing closure to families who have waited nearly 75 years.

YouTube entertainer Yousef Saleh Erakat disguised himself as a homeless man and conducted a social experiment where he offered money to strangers on the street, finding that most people reacted with anger, hostility, and rejection. The video, which aimed to "flip the script" on typical homeless-wealthy interactions, revealed how uncomfortable people became when someone they perceived as "lesser" tried to help them, with only two individuals accepting the gesture graciously. Erakat's experiment demonstrated that societal class perceptions often prevent genuine human connection, as most people couldn't accept help from someone they viewed as beneath them in social status.

The grandmother of 18-year-old Anjelica "AJ" Hadsell, a Longwood University student who has been missing from Virginia since March 2, criticized authorities on Sunday for allegedly "doing nothing" to bring the girl home after more than a month of searching. Police are currently searching a pond near Carrsville for AJ's cell phone after receiving a tip, while her stepfather Wesley Hadsell was arrested for breaking into a home he believed contained evidence related to her disappearance. The case remains unsolved with no official suspects, though police have not ruled out foul play in the disappearance of the college freshman who was home for spring break when she vanished.

Researchers from the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology have developed "Joggobot," a drone companion designed to fly alongside joggers to help maintain pace and provide motivation. In tests with 13 runners, the quadcopter flew 13 feet in front of participants at a height of 10 feet, with most runners finding it effective as a "pace keeper" that created a sense of peer pressure similar to running with a human companion. The researchers believe this technology could be expanded to other sports like cycling, skiing, and rowing, though there's no timeline for public availability.

Matthew Bird from Ashburton, New Zealand, went to extreme lengths to avoid a $600-a-month hike in child support by quitting his well-paid job as an agricultural adviser and becoming a mechanic, effectively halving his income from $70,000 to $38,000 annually. This drastic career change reduced his monthly child support payments from $1,900 to $554 following New Zealand's amended child support formula that took effect in April. Bird said he was willing to accept the significant pay cut because he considered the increased payment amount "unreasonable" under the new system.

US authorities suspected that British man Navinder Singh Sarao, 36, was making illicit trades back in 2009, but it has been revealed this week that it took six years for charges to be brought against him for causing the 2010 'flash crash.' Experts are expressing shock at the lengthy delay, as Sarao is now accused of making £26 million from illegal trades over five years and faces extradition to New York for trial. The case involves manipulation of Wall Street markets that wiped nearly a trillion dollars from global share prices in May 2010.

Canadian expat Lisa Webb, a former assistant elementary school principal and author of the blog "Canadian Expat Mom," was initially worried when she moved to France in 2009 and had to send her vegetable-phobic three-year-old daughter to a French school, fearing the child would starve. However, she was shocked to discover that French schoolchildren, including her own daughter, readily ate sophisticated three-course meals featuring dishes like roast beef and turkey cordon bleu using proper cutlery and table manners. After observing lunch periods at the school, Lisa was amazed by how the French education system successfully encourages children to eat healthy, varied meals in a respectful dining environment for just €2.60 per day.

A survey of 1,000 people conducted by personal budgeting software company YouNeedaBudget.com found that shopping with friends is bad for your bank balance, as it encourages people to spend far more than they would when making purchases alone. According to the study, 64 percent of adults confessed that they spend more money when shopping with friends, with the main reasons being "showing off in front of friends" and "succumbing to peer pressure and buying things we wouldn't ordinarily buy." Despite 85 percent of participants setting budgets when they shop, 95 percent admitted they usually spend more than originally planned, with food and clothing being the top categories for overspending.

Ellie Grant, 22, appeared on ITV's This Morning with her deaf fiancé Jordan to discuss how she suddenly developed Tourette's syndrome at age 21 and worried she'd never find a boyfriend who could tolerate her inappropriate outbursts. During the interview, she left presenter Phillip Schofield speechless when she blurted out "silver fox" (his nickname) due to a verbal tic, with viewers calling it "the greatest Tourette's TV moment of all time." The couple explained how they met after Grant's condition began with her shouting "marshmallow" while buying a sandwich after a night of drinking, and how Jordan's deafness makes them a perfect match since he can simply turn off his hearing aid during her loud tics.

Adam Gadahn, a 36-year-old American who became known as al Qaeda's English-language spokesman and was considered the "American mouthpiece" of the terrorist organization, was killed in January during a U.S. counterterrorism operation, the White House announced Thursday. Gadahn had spent years speaking against his native country on behalf of al Qaeda, which has devoted significant blood and resources to attacking America, but he was not specifically targeted in the strike that killed him. Born in California and later converting to Islam, Gadahn rose through al Qaeda's ranks to become one of its most prominent propagandists, appearing in numerous videos threatening attacks and urging lone-wolf terrorism in the United States.

Formula One star Jenson Button completed the London Marathon with an impressive time of 2 hours, 52 minutes and 30 seconds. The 35-year-old McLaren driver told the BBC he was "chuffed to bits" with his performance, though he joked about being disappointed to finish behind former Olympic rower James Cracknell. Button ran on behalf of Cancer Research and described the experience as "really emotional," praising the amazing atmosphere and collective spirit of the 36,000 runners.
